Purpose: To support a series of community outreach concerts. Additional Project Description: The Aiken Symphony Orchestra will provide concerts at a community venue such as a senior care or health care facility. Programming will be presented through partnerships with community organizations such as the Tri-Development Center. Intended Beneficiaries: Residents throughout Aiken will have access to the performances, including individuals with disabilities. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Purpose: To support a composer residency by Brian Nabors including commissions, performances, and educational activities. Additional Project Description: Plans include the completion of two works for orchestra and performances of these and other works by the composer. Nabors will lead master classes in local schools and colleges. Intended Beneficiaries: Programs will benefit the composer-in-residence as well as general audiences in Birmingham, Alabama, and area public school students. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support concerts and outreach activities by the Alabama Symphony Orchestra. Project plans will include performances, instrument petting zoos, and distribution of teacher guides. Repertoire for the concerts may include excerpts from Stravinsky's "The Firebird" or Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 4. The selection of tour venues will focus on underserved communities that do not have direct access to a professional orchestra.

To support Sound Investment, a residency and commissioning project. Plans include two week-long visits by composer Judd Greenstein, master classes for university music students, open rehearsals for school students, a lecture program for adults, and the commissioning and performance of a new work by Greenstein.

To support a performance and outreach activities featuring flutist Joseph FireCrow. A member of the Cheyenne Nation, FireCrow will narrate, play, and sing Jim Cockey's "The Gift of the Elk: A Suite for Native American Flute," a symphonic composition based on a Cheyenne myth. In addition to a performance, the project will also include outreach activities in local schools in rural Southwest Georgia.

Purpose: To support the American Music Festival, including commissions of new works. Additional Project Description: The festival will be a collaborative exploration of Black cultural expression in America—jazz, hip-hop, and Afro-Caribbean—through music, spoken-word, dance, and other art forms. Focusing on the creation and performance of new art by composers and performers of color, the festival will be curated by violinist Regina Carter, spoken-word artist Marc Bamuthi Joseph, and Artistic Director of Ase Dance Theatre Adia Whitaker. Project plans include workshops, a composer reading session, a street dance, and a variety of educational and community engagement programs. Intended Beneficiaries: The festival and educational activities will serve residents of New York and surrounding states in the region. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the American Music Festival, including commissions of new works. Additional Project Description: Composers to be commissioned will include John Corigliano, Bobby Ge, Jack Frerer, Loren Loiacono, and Natalie Draper. Project plans will comprise a composition seminar, a composer reading session, and a variety of educational and community engagement programs. Intended Beneficiaries: The festival and educational activities will serve residents of New York and surrounding states in the region. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the American Music Festival including commissions of new works. Composers to be commissioned may include Molly Joyce, Nina Shekhar, and Christopher Theofanidis. Project plans include a composition seminar, a composer reading session, and educational programs for local school students.

To support planning costs and composer fees for the American Music Festival. The festival's theme will celebrate the completion of the Empire State Trail, 750 miles of cycling and walking trails throughout the state.

To support the American Music Festival. The festival will present the work of living American composers, new commissions, winners of a national call-for-scores competition, and local student artists in the Literacy Through Songwriting partnership program. Other activities will include composer reading and recording sessions, workshops, and symposia. Events will be presented at venues throughout Troy, New York, including Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's Experimental Media  Performing Arts Center and the Troy Savings Bank Music Hall.

To support the American Music Festival. Under the direction of Music Director David Alan Miller, the 20th anniversary festival will take place at the Experimental Media  Performing Arts Center in Troy, New York. The theme of the festival - Musical Tributaries - will focus on bridging diverse cultures, bringing non-Western musical perspectives to concert and community settings. The festival will feature world premieres of commissioned works, a composer reading session, chamber music programs, a composer workshop, and a songwriting project.

To support the American Music Festival. Under the direction of Music Director David Alan Miller, the festival will take place at the Experimental Media  Performing Arts Center in Troy, New York. The theme of the festival will celebrate the bicentennial of the Erie Canal by exploring connections between communities. The centerpiece of the festival will feature world premieres of commissioned works by Katherine Balch and Reena Esmail, as well as works by Christopher Theofanidis, Steven Stucky, and many other composers. Other activities include a composer reading session and chamber music programs.

To support the American Music Festival. Under the direction of Music Director David Alan Miller, the festival will take place at the Experimental Media  Performing Arts Center in Troy, New York. The theme of the festival is environmental conservation. Works to be featured will include "Silent Spring" by Steven Stucky, inspired by the writings of conservationist Rachel Carson; "Beyond the Pipeline" by Jessie Montgomery; and "Phantom Limbs" by Loren Loiacono. The festival will feature works by composers in residence including Aaron Jay Kernis, Montgomery, Stucky, and composers of the Sleeping Giant Collective (Timo Andres, Christopher Cerrone, Jacob Cooper, Ted Hearne, Robert Honstein, and Andrew Norman). Also planned are the premieres of newly commissioned works by Clarice Assad, Conor Brown, and Reena Esmail. Other activities will include a young composer reading session, a solo piano recital, and songwriting projects.

To support the American Music Festival and related educational activities. The festival will focus on human migrations, animal migrations, and immigrant history and culture. Commissions also will include new works by composers such as Chris Cerrone, Jacob Cooper, Robert Honstein, Takuma Itoh, Andrea Reinkemeyer, and Kathryn Salfelder.
To support the American Music Festival: Indigenous Americana. The five-day festival focuses on indigenous arts, folk culture, and roots movements in North America.

Purpose: To support teaching artists fees related to Music STEPS, a free, after-school music education program for pre-kindergarten and elementary school students. Additional Project Description: Professional teaching artists will provide general music classes and instrumental music lessons throughout the school year. Pre-school children will be engaged in singing and creative movement, and elementary grade students will receive free instruments and instruction in strings, percussion, brass, and woodwinds. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit students who attend Title I schools, as well as students served through social service agencies located in underserved communities in Miami Dade County. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

To support teacher salaries for a free, after-school music education program for pre-kindergarten and elementary school students. Through the Music STEPS program, professional teaching artists will provide music lessons to children at Title I schools, community centers, and social service agencies. Pre-school children will be engaged in singing and creative movement, and elementary grade students will receive free instruments and instruction in strings, percussion, brass, and woodwinds.

Purpose: To support initiatives serving emerging composers. Additional Project Description: Activities will include commissions and world premieres of new works by composers Trevor New and Jihyun Kim. Other project plans include the EarShot Readings for composers in collaboration with the Atlanta Symphony, Dallas Symphony, and Naples Philharmonic. EarShot Readings is a program that provides emerging composers the opportunity to work with a professional orchestra to workshop a new score. Additional activities will include commissioning new works and professional development offerings. Intended Beneficiaries: The initiatives will serve emerging composers, audiences, musicians, professional orchestras, schools, and community partners across the country. Intended Outcome: Arts leaders develop professional skills and strategies.

Purpose: To support the SONiC ACTIV8: CoLABoratory Showcase, featuring new audiovisual works by musicians Trevor New and Mendi and Keith Obadike. Additional Project Description: Through the presentation of new media performances, a public art installation, artist lectures, workshops, and virtual jam sessions, the showcase will engage in-person and online audiences with technology-focused creative practices rooted in audiovisual performance. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit the participating artists and general audiences in New York City, as well as online viewers nationwide. Intended Outcome: Arts leaders develop professional skills and strategies.

Purpose: To support initiatives serving emerging composers. Additional Project Description: Activities will include the world premieres of new works by composers Dai Wei, Paula Matthusen, and Inti Figgis-Vizueta. Other project plans include the EarShot Readings for composers in collaboration with the Tucson, Oregon, and Houston Symphonies. EarShot Readings is a program that provides emerging composers the opportunity to work with a professional orchestra to workshop a new score. The project also includes the CoLABoratory composer residencies, a collaborative mentorship program for composers with no orchestral training who are accomplished musicians and performers. Intended Beneficiaries: The initiatives will serve emerging composers, audiences, musicians, professional orchestras, schools, and community partners across the country. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

To support initiatives serving emerging composers. Other project plans include the Underwood New Music Readings and the EarShot Readings for composers in collaboration with Columbus Symphony, Detroit Symphony, and Sarasota Orchestra. In addition, a new Commission Consortium program will be launched where a composer will be chosen for a commission by the ACO and two other orchestras across the country.

Also planned are the Underwood New Music Readings serving emerging composers and the EarShot New Music Readings for composers in collaboration with the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra, Columbus Symphony, and Naples Philharmonic. The Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra and Naples Philharmonic also will host the Jazz Composers Orchestra Institute for jazz composers on writing for orchestra.

To support the artistic and career development of emerging composers and new music readings. Project components include the annual Underwood New Music Readings serving emerging composers, and the EarShot New Music Readings for composers conducted in collaboration with national partners Berkeley Symphony, the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra, and the Chicago Modern Orchestra Project. Other project components will include the third Jazz Composers Orchestra Institute Intensive, held at UCLA's Herb Alpert School of Music. In addition, the American Composers Orchestra will perform the work of a past participant composer at Jazz at Lincoln Center's Rose Hall venue in New York City.

To support the Emerging Composers Laboratory. Through the program, the ACO will develop new repertoire and provide performance opportunities to composers early in their careers. Additionally, Music Director George Manahan will conduct the Underwood New Music Readings at the DiMenna Center, which will feature emerging composers selected through a nationwide search. Project activity also will include EarShot, an orchestra composition discovery program where the orchestra will work with the Detroit and Berkeley Symphonies to replicate the Underwood New Music Readings program in their own communities.

To support the Jazz Composers Orchestra Institute's "New Music Readings." In partnership with The Center for Jazz Studies at Columbia University in New York and the University of California, Los Angeles's Herb Alpert School of Music, the readings will allow up to 20 jazz composers to create up to 20 works for reading-performances by the ACO in New York City; the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra (NY); and the Stockton Symphony and the La Jolla Symphony (CA).

To support a longitudinal a study examining racial/ethnic and gender diversity in the orchestra field. The study will analyze data from 2014/16-2020 collected by the American Symphony Orchestra League through annual surveys it collects from the field. Data points will include the racial and gender diversity of musicians, conductors and music directors, orchestra staff, board members, and CEO/Executive Directors. The report will include a snapshot of equity, diversity, and inclusion expenditures by orchestras. The League will also work with a data consultant to create a model that will allow for continued reporting on this data annually and in the long-term.

column12: Purpose: To support a tour of choral concerts including video recording and related educational activities. Additional Project Description: The concerts, titled "Exile and Resilience: The Music of the Jewish and African Diasporas", are scheduled in Cleveland, Akron, Chicago, New York City, and San Francisco. Inspiration for the concerts will be taken from the Jewish and African traditions, two peoples who were stolen from their homelands and enslaved in faraway lands. Educational activities may include pre-concert talks, a panel discussion, family concerts, and workshops in public schools. The video recording will be accessible on YouTube.com. Intended Beneficiaries: Audiences in Ohio, Illinois, New York, and San Francisco will benefit from the project. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Concerts will take place in Cleveland and Akron, Ohio, and Chicago, Illinois, and may feature guest violinist Rachel Barton Pine. Performances also will be available online through a virtual series. Educational activities will include family and school concerts, a masterclass, pre-concert talks, and post-concert question-and-answer sessions. Intended Beneficiaries: Programming will serve in-person audiences in northeastern Ohio and Chicago as well as audiences worldwide through the virtual series. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

column12: To support performances of Bach's Mass in B Minor on period instruments with related educational activities. As many as four performances will take place, in addition to interactive Family Concerts about the Bach family, lectures by a visiting scholar, a panel discussion, and a baroque trumpet master class for conservatory students. The project will include a performance at the Baldwin Wallace Bach Festival in Berea, Ohio.

column12: To support a semi-staged production and tour of Monteverdi's opera, "L'Orfeo." Performances are scheduled to take place in Cleveland, Ohio; Ann Arbor, Michigan; and in Berkeley and Sonoma, California. The landmark opera of 1607, based on the Greek legend of Orpheus and Eurydice, is considered the earliest work in operatic history that is regularly performed today. The new production will feature as many as 44 performers including soloists, strings, sackbuts, lutes, recorders, renaissance harp, chorus, and period dancers. Artistic Director Jeannette Sorrell will conduct from the harpsichord. Educational activities may include pre- and post-concert discussions, workshops, and master classes.

Pre-concert talks on Beethoven's life will be presented by visiting scholar Thomas Forrest Kelly of Harvard University. Other educational events will include post-concert discussions and family concerts.

Activities will include subscription concerts in the Cleveland/Akron area, lectures by an internationally respected scholar, a mini-festival of contextual events in Cleveland titled "The Monteverdi Experience," and a national tour. Media events will include a syndicated radio broadcast on WCLV-FM and an online video podcast with interviews and background on the composer and his work.

Purpose: To support an orchestral performance with related educational activities. Additional Project Description: The performance, in collaboration with Saint Mark Baptist Church, will feature classical music, gospel, RB, and jazz genres. Educational activities may include demonstrations and performances by symphony musicians for members of the church youth choirs. Project activities also may include a joint performance by the symphony's youth orchestra and the youth choirs. Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed project will benefit symphony and church musicians as well as residents of Little Rock, Arkansas, and the surrounding area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support a composer residency by Tania Leon. Plans include performances of existing works for orchestra and chamber ensemble as well as the premiere of a commissioned work. Community engagement may include lecture-demonstrations, a master class for high school and college students, and a radio interview.

To support virtual concert performances. Guest artist youth violinist Samuel Garcia will perform with the Arkansas Symphony Orchestra. The virtual programs will include artist talks by the conductor and guest artist that are interspersed between the performance pieces.

To support concert performances and related outreach activities. Violinist and former Sphinx winner Gareth Johnson will perform with the Arkansas Symphony Orchestra at the annual Beethoven and Blue Jeans concert. Outreach will include activities such as workshops, artist talks, public dress rehearsals, and lecture demonstrations.

To support the Canvas Festival, which will combine visual arts and the performance of live symphonic music. Plans include concerts and educational activities that thematically combine visual art and symphonic music. Repertoire may include Adam Schoenberg's "Finding Rothko," and Respighi's "Trittico Botticelliano (Three Botticelli Pictures)." Educational activities may include lecture-demonstrations, pre-concert discussions, and open rehearsals. The festival will culminate with a performance of Beethoven's Symphony No. 6, "Pastoral" with visual artist Barry Thomas painting onstage in real time in reaction to the music being played.

To support Mahler: Resurrection and associated outreach activities. Guest artists soprano Kristin Lewis and mezzo soprano Christin-Marie Hill will lead workshops for student musicians and community members, held at schools and community venues serving economically, ethnically, and geographically underserved groups. Lewis and Hill will also perform as soloists in a public performance of Gustav Mahler's "Symphony No. 2, Resurrection" by the Arkansas Symphony Orchestra.

To support a residency that will culminate in the world premiere performance of a composition by D.J. Sparr, featuring guitarist Ted Ludwig. The composition is inspired by Ludwig's flight from New Orleans following Hurricane Katrina. In addition to performances, electric guitarists Ludwig and Sparr will lead workshops for student musicians and community members from central and southeastern Arkansas, including a high percentage of low-income residents.

To support performances, workshops, and related outreach activities featuring violinist Randall Goosby. Goosby, the first-place winner of the 2010 Sphinx Competition, will be in residence in Central Arkansas conducting free workshops and music demonstrations for community members and student musicians drawn from economically disadvantaged schools. The residency will culminate in a public soloist performance with the Arkansas Symphony Orchestra.

To support a residency, commission, and premiere of a new work. Following a week of residency activities by composer Christopher Theofinidis, his new work will be premiered at Robinson Center Music Hall under the direction of Music Director Philip Mann. Prior to the premiere, Theofinidis will work with orchestra musicians as they rehearse. He also will work with underserved high school students in central Arkansas and take part in pre-concert lectures.

To support performances and workshops featuring guest conductor Guillermo Figueroa. In addition to public performances during concerts held at the Robinson Center Music Hall, Figueroa will conduct workshops and a master class for high school and college students from throughout central Arkansas.

Purpose: To support a chamber music series. Additional Project Description: Concerts will take place in community settings including the Orange Peel and the Salvage Station music venues. Repertoire will consist of classical, rock, and pop music. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit audiences in Asheville, North Carolina. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the annual conference for California orchestras. Additional Project Description: The conference will be hosted by the San Bernardino Symphony. The conference's professional development programs typically draw arts administrators who span the full arc of orchestra professionals including board members; executive-level, mid-career, and emerging administrators; retired professionals; volunteers; and students. Session topics and content may include management fundamentals such as fundraising, governance, and financial planning; as well as timely issues such as equity and inclusion, artistic programming, audience development, the career pipeline, and workplace culture. Intended Beneficiaries: The conference will serve a broad variety of California orchestras as well as choruses, classical music festivals, and ensembles. Intended Outcome: Arts leaders develop professional skills and strategies.

column12: Purpose: To support a series of professional development workshops for staff and board members of orchestras. Additional Project Description: Each workshop will feature a presentation from an expert in the performing arts field. Topics may include diversity/equity/inclusion, board development, audience engagement, program curation, and career development. In addition, a one-day seminar will be offered for professionals who work in youth orchestras. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit orchestral professionals in California. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.
To support an annual conference held online. Plans for session and discussion themes may include issues of equity and orchestra management fundamentals.

To support an online conference for California orchestras. The virtual conference will include breakout sessions, peer-to-peer learning and networking, and one-on-one access to experts. It will also include plenary presentations on organizational resilience and thought leadership around the opportunities for innovation and inclusion that orchestras have been given due to the COVID-19 crisis.

To support a statewide conference for California orchestras. The conference will bring together leaders from across the state to strengthen knowledge of key issues, network with peers, and identify strategic actions that will secure a critical role for classical music in the state's future.

To support professional leadership development and technical assistance programs for California orchestras. Plans include Ask an Expert webinar series, a newsletter, online resources, and an annual statewide conference. Professional development topics may include orchestra management fundamentals as well as issues facing the classical music field such as cultural diversity, access, and inclusion.

To support professional leadership development and technical assistance programs for California orchestras. Plans include an annual statewide conference. The programmatic theme for the conference will focus on diversity and engagement.

To support professional leadership development and technical assistance programs for California orchestras. Plans include technical assistance consultations at the annual statewide conference. Additionally, project activities will comprise workshops for artistic and administrative staff, trustees, and volunteers from more than 150 orchestras.

To support professional and leadership development and technical assistance programs for California orchestras. Plans include webinars, "Ask the Expert" conference calls, and an annual statewide conference. Additionally, project activities will comprise workshops for artistic and administrative staff, trustees, and volunteers from more than 150 orchestras.

To support professional and leadership development and technical assistance programs. Plans include Webinars and "Ask the Expert" conference calls; an annual statewide conference; and workshops for artistic and administrative staff, trustees, and volunteers from more than 150 orchestras.

Purpose: To support music education programming and concerts for middle and high school students. Additional Project Description: Project activities will include training for teachers and musician teaching artists, in-school workshops by teaching artists, orchestral and chamber music concerts, a student composition component, and the development of an online learning laboratory. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve students and teachers in the Austin area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Purpose: To support an interdisciplinary learning initiative using music for middle and high school students. Additional Project Description: Through creative exploration, middle school and high school students will examine how music is both a reflection of and a response to cultural adaptation and diversity. Project plans will include training for teachers and musician teaching artists, in-school workshops by teaching artists, orchestral and chamber music concerts, and the development of an online learning laboratory. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve students and teachers in the Austin area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

To support an interdisciplinary learning initiative using music for middle and high school students. Through creative exploration, middle school and high school students will examine how music is both a reflection of and a response to historical events, as well as music's role in society. Project plans will include training for teachers and musician teaching artists, in-school workshops by teaching artists, orchestral and chamber music concerts, and the development of an online learning laboratory.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support an interdisciplinary learning initiative using music for middle and high school students. Through creative exploration, middle school and high school students will examine how music is both a reflection and a response to historical events as well as examining music's role in society. Project plans include training for teachers and musician teaching artists, in-school workshops by teaching artists, and concerts of orchestral and chamber music.

To support an interdisciplinary learning initiative using music for middle and high school students. The theme of the initiative will focus on how adversity affects creativity. Students will examine music of World War II and the Holocaust, and will explore how music is both a reflection and a response to historical events. They also will explore the role music plays in society through creative exploration. Project plans include training for teachers and musician teaching artists, in-school workshops by teaching artists, and orchestral and chamber concerts for high school students. Chosen for thematic appropriateness, orchestral repertoire may include selections from the symphonies of Beethoven and Shostakovich, D'un matin de printemps (Of the Spring Morning) by Lili Boulanger, Erich Korngold's fanfare from Kings Row, and the Festival Coronation March for Alexander III by Tchaikovsky. Chamber concerts may include works composed by prisoners of the Terezín concentration camp as well as Shostakovich and Steve Reich.

To support an interdisciplinary learning initiative for high school students. Focusing on the theme-Overcoming Adversity-the initiative will be an examination of the nature of resilience as it influences and is expressed through music. Project plans may include training for teachers and musician teaching artists, in-school workshops by teaching artists, and concerts for high school students. Chosen for thematic appropriateness, repertoire may include selections from the symphonies of Beethoven and Shostakovich, "D'un matin de printemps (Of the Spring Morning)" by Lili Boulanger, Korngold's "Captain Blood Overture," and the "Festival Coronation March for Alexander III" by Tchaikovsky.

To support Connecting with Music, an interdisciplinary learning initiative for high school students. Focusing on the theme Innovating Music: Exploring Change, the initiative will examine the effect technology has on people's lives. Project plans will include training for teachers and musician teaching artists, in-school workshops by teaching artists, and concerts for high school students.

To support the Connecting with Music: Austin Interdisciplinary Learning Initiative. The project will focus on the theme Romeo and Juliet: The Nature of Conflict. Project plans will include training for teachers and musician teaching artists, in-school workshops by teaching artists, and high school concerts. Repertoire may feature Tchaikovsky's "Romeo and Juliet Overture-Fantasy" and selections from Prokofiev's "Romeo and Juliet Suite Nos. 1 and 2" and Bernstein's "West Side Story."

column9: Challenge America: Arts Engagement in American Communities
column12: To support Young People’s Concerts, educational performances for students in Bakersfield, California. Each concert will be based on a theme, such as the lives of famous composers or the sections of the orchestra. The concerts will be designed for students and youth, and will be presented in partnership with the Kern County Superintendent of Schools and the Bakersfield City School District.

Purpose: To support a subscription concert series with related educational activities that include a focus on Asian American and Pacific Islander (AAPI) culture and artistic contributions to the symphonic field. Additional Project Description: More than 400,000 AAPI people call Maryland home, including 16 percent of the orchestra's own musicians. However, the orchestra's patron base does not currently reflect the region's AAPI representation, and music by BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color) composers—including AAPI—represents only 3.5 percent of the symphonic repertoire. To better promote, reflect, and honor the full diversity present on their stages and in their communities, the orchestra will program AAPI composers, guest artists, and traditional arts in subscription concert programs. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve audiences in the Baltimore City metropolitan area, with a focus on outreach to members of the AAPI community. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support GospelFest, a series of performances, a commission, and related educational activities. Additional Project Description: Each concert will feature the symphony and a choir from historically Black colleges and universities (HBCU) including Morgan State University and Howard University. Plans include the commissioning and world premiere of a new work by Adolphus Hailstork. Educational components will include master classes, a workshop, and community conversations. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve residents of Baltimore and surrounding communities, including students from area HBCUs. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the OrchKids program, a music and mentorship program for students in Baltimore City public schools. Serving as a national model for the U.S. El Sistema movement that emphasizes social change through the arts, professional musicians will provide in-school and after-school music training to students attending Title I schools in Baltimore. OrchKids combines music instruction and social services to help students acquire positive behaviors such as perseverance, cooperation, and personal responsibility. The program is delivered at no cost to participants, and includes musicianship classes, after-school choir and instrumental music instruction, summer programming, and opportunities for the students to perform for audiences around the city.

To support concerts and events in celebration of the 100th anniversary season. Plans include premieres of new works including Percussion Concerto No. 2 by composer James MacMillan with Colin Currie as soloist and "The City" (Symphony No. 5) by Kevin Puts. Also planned are commissions by composers including TJ Cole, Kristen Kuster, Lori Laitman, Libby Larsen, James Lee III, Jonathan Leshnoff, Christopher Rouse, Caroline Shaw, Christopher Theofanidis, Joan Tower, and by composer-in-residence Anna Clyne. Guest artists will include pianists Leon Fleisher and Andre Watts, cellist Yo-Yo Ma, and violinist Joshua Bell. Collaborations planned will include productions of Gershwin's "Porgy and Bess" with Center Stage Theater and the Morgan State University Choir, Copland's "Appalachian Spring" with Baltimore School for the Arts, and a musical adaptation of NPR's Kitchen Sisters.

To support the OrchKids program, a free choral and instrumental instruction program in Baltimore City Public Schools. Serving as a national model for El Sistema in the U.S., a movement that emphasizes social change through the arts, professional musicians provide year-round, in-school and after-school music training to at-risk students in East and West Baltimore. Program components include a Bucket Band, choir classes, wind and chamber instrumental ensembles, and tutoring.

Professional musicians will provide in-school and after-school music training to at-risk students in East and West Baltimore, with a focus on influencing social change through the arts in the city's neediest communities.

Purpose: To support a new production of La Purpura de la Rosa (The Blood of the Rose) by composer Torrejón y Velasco and librettist Pedro Calderon de la Barca, with related educational programs. Additional Project Description: The timeless story of love and loss shared across cultures is thought to be the first opera composed and performed in the Americas (in Lima, Peru, in 1701). The orchestra will create a historically informed musical performance coupled with imaginative staging, and will feature an original prologue and epilogue created by a spoken-word artist. Educational collaborations will include activities with Hispanic-serving institutional partner Metro State University of Denver and with underserved community youth partner El Sistema Colorado. Community programming will include seminars, pre-concert talks, and a video produced for senior living centers. Intended Beneficiaries: Performances will benefit Denver-area audiences and Colorado Public Radio listeners. Livestreams will reach viewers across the United States, Latin America, and Canada, and educational partnerships will reach students from underserved Denver-area communities. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support the creation and premiere of a new work by composers Devin Ferreira and Jacob Gunnar Walsh and related educational activities. The new work will be a multi-sensory concert experience featuring projected images accompanying a live performance of a new orchestral work. The composers will create music featuring 50 youth drummers and dancers with orchestra, while visual artists Ryan Edwards and Sam Okerstrom-Lang will create the images, which will be projected on the architectural structure of the Hatch Shell on Boston's Esplanade and the monuments and trees surrounding the seating area. Educational activities may include drumming workshops for school students.

To support a celebration of the African American Spiritual. In partnership with the New England Spiritual Ensemble, a commissioned work by composer Trevor Weston that employs African-American spirituals and narrated poetry, will serve as a platform for workshops and educational performances. Weston will compose two versions of his new work: a full version to be performed at the Hatch Memorial Shell on Boston's Esplanade and a chamber version for use in educational performances.

Purpose: To support the premiere of Harriet Tubman: When I Crossed That Line to Freedom by composer Nkeiru Okoye. Additional Project Description: The opera follows the title character's evolution from enslaved girl to liberator, through the context of her tightknit family and her relationship with her sister. Previously performed as a song cycle with full orchestra and as a chamber opera, the semi-staged production will feature a new orchestration by the composer. The production is part of a series of five operas by Black composers depicting figures of Black liberation across 250 years of history that will be performed and recorded for commercial release. The project also will provide programs for children, including listening guides to accompany the recordings and residencies that will result in the creation of original work. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve artists, and audience members in the Boston area, as well as online listeners. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support a semi-staged concert performance of X: The Life and Times of Malcolm X by Pulitzer Prize-winning composer Anthony Davis, with related educational programs. Additional Project Description: The performance will feature baritone Davone Tines and will be presented at the historic Strand Theater in the same Dorchester neighborhood where Malcom X lived during his youth. Performances, educational programs, and recordings will be created in partnership with Odyssey Opera, Michigan Opera Theatre, as well as Castle of Our Skins, which will design and execute educational programs related to the opera for Boston Public School students. The production will be part of a series of five historical operas by Black composers depicting prominent figures of Black liberation and thought across 250 years of history. The company will produce semi-staged concert performances of these works alongside commercial recordings released on BMOP/sound for its next five seasons. Intended Beneficiaries: Intended beneficiaries include artists, Boston Public Schools students, and audience members, as well as listeners of the digital streaming on radio station BMOP/radio. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support post-production and release costs for a compact disc recording featuring Charles Wuorinen's Haroun and the Sea of Stories. The CD will feature composer Charles Wuorinen's first opera Haroun and the Sea of Stories and will be available in digital format. The BMOP/sound release of this opera will be the first and only complete commercial recording available of this work.

The world premiere recording of orchestral works by composer Chen Yi will be released on the orchestra's BMOP/sound record label, and distributed internationally by the orchestra and Albany Records.

To support recording and post-production costs for CDs of orchestral works by American composers Chinary Ung and David Rakowski. The world premiere recordings of orchestral works by composers Chinary Ung and David Rakowski will be released on two separate discs.

Purpose: To support concert programs of composers and performers typically underrepresented in classical music, with related educational activities. Additional Project Description: Repertoire may include Samuel Coleridge-Taylor's Petite Suite de Concert, Anthony Davis's You Have the Right to Remain Silent, and Gorecki's Symphony No. 3 "Symphony of Sorrowful Songs". Educational activities may include conversations with artists and scholars. Intended Beneficiaries: The performances will benefit audiences throughout New England. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood Music Center. Additional Project Description: The festival will feature concerts performed by Tanglewood Music Center's fellows. Concerts of new music by women composers will offer new perspectives on the contemporary music field. Each composer will put together a program of her own music and works that reflects musical interests and influences. Select concerts will be available on the symphony's streaming portal. Educational activities may include composer talks and a panel discussion with the composers. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit the resident musicians, partner composers, and audiences in Western Massachusetts, as well as audiences online. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support orchestra musician's and conductor's fees for performances of Benjamin Britten's "War Requiem" with related educational activities. Additional Project Description: The concerts will feature the orchestra led by conductor Sir Antonio Pappano. Intended Beneficiaries: The performances will be promoted to audiences throughout New England. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Purpose: To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood Music Center. Additional Project Description: The festival, curated and directed by soprano Tony Arnold, pianist Stephen Drury, composer George Lewis, and cellist Astrid Schween, will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists. The festival also will include a concert presentation of composer George Benjamin's new opera "Lessons in Love and Violence." Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit the resident musicians, the composers whose works will be performed, and audiences in Western Massachusetts. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.
To support online performances. Titled BSO NOW, programs of chamber and orchestral music will be recorded in Symphony Hall and released online.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood Music Center. The festival, curated and directed by composer, pianist, and conductor Thomas Ades, will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists.

To support a series of performances featuring contemporary works composed by women with related educational activities. Repertoire to be featured may include works by composers Helen Grime, Chihchun Chi-sun Lee, and Anna Thorvaldsdóttir. Educational activities may include interactive and online programs through the Tanglewood Learning Institute.

To support the online Tanglewood Music Festival, an academy for advanced musical study. The training festival, curated and directed by composer, pianist, and conductor Thomas Adès, will feature previous concerts offered online to audiences worldwide by student musicians and guest artists. Professional development activities will include online master classes and discussions for students from remote locations across the country and world by faculty and guest artists.

To support the world premiere performances of works by composers Thomas Adès and Sebastian Currier with related community engagement activities. Adès will conduct the orchestra's performance of his Piano Concerto featuring pianist Kirill Gerstein as soloist. Music Director Andris Nelsons will conduct Currier's Violin Concerto featuring Latvian violinist Baiba Skride as soloist. Community engagement activities may include podcasts and pre-concert lectures.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood Music Center. The festival, curated and directed by composer, pianist, and conductor Thomas Adès, will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood Music Center. The festival, curated and directed by composer, pianist, and conductor Thomas Ades, will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists. Repertoire will include works by Ades, Gerald Barry, Gyorgy Kurtag, Witold Lutoslawski, Conlon Nancarrow, and Poul Ruders.

To support concerts and events in celebration the 100th anniversary of Leonard Bernstein's birth. Repertoire may feature performances of Bernstein's Symphonies No. 2 ("The Age of Anxiety") for orchestra and piano and No. 3 ("Kaddish") for orchestra, chorus, boychoir, soprano, and speaker. Symphony No. 2 was commissioned by former music director Serge Koussevitzky and had its world premiere at Symphony Hall in 1949, conducted by Koussevitsky, with Bernstein as piano soloist. Educational activities may include film screenings, a community chamber music concert, and an archival exhibit.

To support a series of concerts featuring co-commissioned works in Boston and New York City with related educational activities. Composers to be featured will include Julian Anderson, George Benjamin, Sofia Gubaidulina, and Matthias Pintscher. Concerts will take place in Symphony Hall in Boston, and Carnegie Hall in New York City. Engagement activities will include Conversations with the Creators series, and Do You Hear What I Hear? series. Concerts will be broadcast live on WCRB-FM as well as available online on WGBH's BSO Concert Channel and on the BSO's website.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood Music Center. The festival, curated by Tanglewood alumni Kathryn Bates, Jacob Greenberg, and Nadia Sirota, will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists. Each of the curator's selections will reflect their musical influences and interests.

To support concerts and outreach activities exploring repertoire inspired by the works of William Shakespeare. In commemoration of the 400th anniversary of the author's death, Music Director Andris Nelsons will lead the orchestra in performances of both well-known and rarely-heard works by Dvorak, Mendelssohn, Prokofiev, Shostakovich, Strauss, and Weber and of newer compositions by Hans Werner Henze, Hans Abrahamsen, and George Tsontakis. Also planned is the Insights Series of chamber music performances, moderated panel discussions with the artists and composers, screenings of films of Shakespeare's work with original scores by composers such as Dmitri Shostakovich and William Walton, and online educational offerings.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood Music Center. The festival will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists. Works by a wide array of contemporary composers will be highlighted including the U.S. premiere of composer George Benjamin's "Dream of the Song" for orchestra, women's chorus, and countertenor soloist. Established composers will be engaged to curate the chamber music programs.

To support the Insights Series, an exploration of symphonic, ballet, and opera repertoire from the early 20th century with related educational and ancillary events. Guest conductors such as Vladimir Jurowski, Stephane Deneve, and Charles Dutoit will lead the orchestra in performances of works by Stravinsky, Prokofiev, Milhaud, Poulenc, and Debussy culminating in a concert performance of Polish composer Karol Szymanowski's rarely performed opera "King Roger." Also planned are Conversations with Creators, moderated discussions with key artists, and ancillary chamber music performances.

To support the Tanglewood Music Center (TMC)'s 75th anniversary through performances of newly commissioned and established works. In celebration, performances of newly commissioned works will take place at every TMC concert as well as during the week-long Festival of Contemporary Music. Composers including Michael Gandolfi and John Harbison will each curate one day of the festival.

To support Beethoven and the Piano, an initiative exploring the composer's works for piano and orchestra and related educational activities. Plans include a complete cycle of Beethoven's five piano concertos plus the Triple Concerto for Violin, Cello, and Piano during the course of three successive concert programs featuring conductor Christoph von Dohnanyi and pianist Yefim Bronfman at Symphony Hall. The Boston Symphony Orchestra also will partner with the New England Conservatory, the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, and Harvard University to program several free, ancillary public events surrounding the performances such as lecture demonstrations and film screenings.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood Music Center. The festival, directed by composers John Harbison and Michael Gandolfi, will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists. Works by a wide array of contemporary composers will be highlighted including both established and emerging composers.

To support concerts of works by living composers with related educational activities. Plans include world premiere performances of Augusta Read Thomas's Cello Concerto No.3 with soloist Lynn Harrell and the symphony orchestra's first performances of two works by Oliver Knussen, Violin Concerto, Op. 30 and Whitman Settings for soprano and orchestra with the composer conducting.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at the Tanglewood Music Center. The five-day festival, directed by pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard, will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists.

Purpose: To support the Intensive Community Program, an instrumental music training program for young students. Additional Project Description: Project activities will include weekly lessons, ensemble classes, music theory classes, and summer music workshops. Students will have the opportunity to perform in the community. After a few years of intensive study, students may audition for the youth symphony's entry-level orchestra, and many will ultimately progress to the youth symphony's advanced-level orchestras. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve Boston-area elementary school students, with a focus on students from populations historically underrepresented in classical music. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Purpose: To support the Intensive Community Program, an instrumental music training program for young students. Additional Project Description: Project activities will include weekly lessons, ensemble classes, music theory classes, and summer music workshops. Students will have the opportunity to perform in the community. After a few years of intensive study, students may audition for the youth symphony's entry-level orchestra, and many will ultimately progress to the youth symphony's advanced level orchestras. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve Boston-area elementary school students, with a focus on students from populations historically underrepresented in classical music. Intended Outcomes: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

To support the Intensive Community Program, an instrumental music training program for young students. Boston-area elementary school students from populations historically underrepresented in classical music will participate in weekly lessons, ensemble classes, music theory classes, summer music workshops, and will have the opportunity to perform in the community. After a few years of intensive study, students may audition for the youth symphony's entry-level orchestra, and many will ultimately progress to the youth symphony's advanced level orchestras. Programming will be conducted virtually as necessary.

To support the Intensive Community Program, a string instrument training program. Boston-area elementary school students from populations historically underrepresented in classical music will participate in music lessons, music theory classes, master classes, ensemble classes, a summer music workshop, and performances throughout the community. Project activity may take place virtually.

To support the Intensive Community Program, a string instrument training program serving students in Boston communities. Elementary school students from populations historically underrepresented in classical music will be recruited from public schools, churches, and community organizations. The young musicians will participate in weekly music lessons, music theory classes, master classes, ensemble classes, a summer music workshop, and performances throughout the community. After a few years of intensive study, students may audition for the youth symphony's entry-level orchestra and many will ultimately progress to the youth symphony's advanced level orchestras.

To support the Intensive Community Program, a string instrument training program serving students in Boston communities. Elementary school students from populations historically underrepresented in classical music will be recruited from public schools, inner-city churches, and community organizations. The young musicians will participate in weekly music lessons, ensemble classes, a summer music workshop, and performances throughout the community. After a few years of intensive study, students may audition for the youth symphony's entry-level orchestra and many will ultimately progress to the youth symphony's advanced level orchestras.

To support the Intensive Community Program (ICP), a string instrument training program serving students in Boston communities. The program gives access to classical music instruction to students from populations historically underrepresented in classical music. Elementary school students are recruited from public schools, inner-city churches, and community organizations. Students who may not otherwise have access are able to participate in weekly music lessons, ensemble classes, a summer music workshop, master classes and performance opportunities. After a few years of intensive study, students may audition into the youth symphony's entry-level orchestra, and many ICP students progress through to the youth symphony's highest level orchestras.

To support the Intensive Community Program (ICP), a string instrument training program serving inner-city youth. The program offers elementary school children with no previous musical training weekly music lessons, ensemble classes, instrument rentals, and performance opportunities as well as participation in Summer Music Workshop and master classes. The purpose of the program is to provide musical training to students who may not otherwise have access, enabling them after a few years of intensive study to pass the audition into the youth symphony's entry-level orchestra.

To support the Intensive Community Program, a string instrument training program serving inner-city youth. The program offers young elementary-aged children with no previous musical training weekly music lessons, ensemble classes, instrument rentals, and performance opportunities. The purpose of the program is to provide musical training from professional musicians to students who may not otherwise have access, enabling them after two to three years of intensive study to pass the audition into the youth symphony's entry level orchestra.

To support the Intensive Community Program, a string instrument training program. Targeting inner-city youth, the program offers a summer music workshop, followed by weekly music lessons, ensemble classes, and performance opportunities during the school year.

To support commissions and premieres of new works with related educational activities. As many as two commissions may take place. The new works will be scored for chamber ensemble and orchestra. Educational activities may include panel discussions with the commissioned composers, school rehearsals and performances, and opportunities for emerging composers in the area to work with the selected composers.

To support the commissioning and premiere of a new work with related educational activities, an "Imagine Your Parks" project. Composer Stephen Lias will create an orchestral work to accompany projected images that will showcase Rocky Mountain National Park. Concerts will take place in Boulder, Colorado, as well as at the Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C. as part of the SHIFT Festival of American Orchestras. Ancillary events in both Colorado and D.C. will include interpretive musical hikes and public talks featuring the composer that examine the national parks legacy through a musical lens.

To support the Bedford-Stuyvesant Music Series. Plans include a concert featuring singer Erykah Badu, the commissioning and premiere of a new work by composer Ted Hearne titled But "I Voted for Shirley Chisholm," a chamber concert at the Brooklyn Public Library, a family workshop, and in-school music education residencies.

Purpose: To support a community engagement program and concert. Additional Project Description: The Buffalo World Connection program will focus on the local international community. The performance will feature guest violinist Jonathan Okseniuk, winner of the Junior Division of the Sphinx Competition. Prior to the concert, Okseniuk will give lectures at several public schools as well as community recitals at local arts organizations. Intended Beneficiaries: The concert will serve Buffalo-area students as well as students in schools across Western New York through online broadcasts of the concert. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Purpose: To support West Side Connection, a virtual community engagement program and concert. Additional Project Description: The program will focus on the international community on Buffalo's diverse West Side. The virtual performance will feature the guest violinist Amaryn Olmeda, winner of the Junior Division of the Sphinx Competition. Olmeda will give online lectures for area public schools. Intended Beneficiaries: The virtual concert and educational activities will serve audiences in the Buffalo-area as well as students in schools across Western New York. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support virtual community engagement programs and a concert, focusing on the city's West Side. The online program will focus on the international community on Buffalo's diverse West Side. The performance will feature the guest violinist Esme Arias-Kim, winner of the Junior Division of the Sphinx Competition. Educational activities also will be provided online.

To support the West Side Connection, a community engagement program and concert. The program will focus on the international community on Buffalo's diverse West Side. The performance will feature guest cellist Nygel Witherspoon, winner of the Junior Division of the Sphinx Competition. Prior to the concert, Witherspoon will give lectures at several public schools on the West Side as well as community recitals at local arts organizations. The concert will be broadcast online to schools across Western New York.

To support An American Siddhartha, a program of music and dance. Based on Hermann Hesse's novel, the collaborative project will be developed in partnership with the Lehrer Dance Company. The program will represent a re-imagining of a dance concept explored previously by Founder and Artistic Director Jon Lehrer with new choreography set to orchestral music drawn from existing repertoire. Led by Music Director JoAnn Falletta, the performance will take place at the Center for the Arts on the University at Buffalo North Campus in Amherst, New York.

To support the West Side Connection. In partnership with Buffalo Public Schools, the neighborhood community engagement program and concert will focus on the international community on Buffalo's West Side. Activities may include interactive guest artist site visits, preparatory lesson plans in schools, and a concert of culturally relevant repertoire for students in West Side schools, and adults participating in the International Institute of Buffalo and Journey's End Refugee Services. The performance will be recorded and made available online.

To support Charles Ives: An American Maverick, a festival of concerts and educational activities. A collaboration with the University of Buffalo, the Buffalo/Erie County Library, and the Burchfield Penney Art Center, project plans will include orchestral concerts and a performance of the Concord Piano Sonata, featuring readings of the authors for which each of the four movements is named - Emerson, Hawthorne, Thoreau, and Alcott. Accompanying project activities will involve a master class and pre- and post-concert lectures.

To support the world premiere and recording of a new work by composer Miguel del Aguila with related educational activities. Performed in Kleinhans Music Hall, the new work titled "Concierto en Tango" will be conducted by Music Director JoAnn Falletta and feature Principal Cellist Roman Mekinulov as soloist. The work will be recorded on the orchestra's own Beau Fleuve label. Educational activities will include pre-concert lectures, workshops for university students by the composer, and a master class for young musicians by the cellist. The recording will be available on www.CDBaby.com and as digital download on a variety of sites.

To support "The Underground Railroad: An Evening of Spirituals with Kathleen Battle" with related educational activities. The program, conducted by former assistant conductor Michael Morgan, will feature dramatic readings of the words of Frederick Douglass and a local choir and will mark important anniversaries including the founding of American Anti-Slavery Society and Abolitionist Movement (1833), the signing of the Emancipation Proclamation (1863), and the passing of Harriet Tubman (1913).

To support the Music for Minors program. A signature program of the Burlington Chamber Orchestra, Music for Minors will engage a guest conductor to lead the orchestra in its Spring Celebration of Youth concert. In addition, project activities will include the commission of a new musical work from a student composer for the concert, and performance by a young solo artist during the concert. Project activity will also include outreach to public schools in Burlington and surrounding urban communities that have growing numbers of minority, low-income, and immigrant populations.

Purpose: To support the Young American Composer-in-Residence program. Additional Project Description: The orchestra will commission composer-in-residence Viet Cuong to create and premiere a new work developed through reading sessions and feedback from the orchestra's musicians and conductor. Educational activities will include the El Sistema-inspired Sound Minds program, where Cuong will mentor students in music education. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve Contra Costa County residents and youth. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

To support Sound Minds, a music education program. The El Sistema-inspired program will provide after-school music instruction to low-income students in the second through sixth grades. Plans include classes in choral music, musicianship, rhythm, violin or cello instruction, and academic enrichment. High school music students will mentor those in the program by sharing their experiences as young string musicians. Musicians in the symphony will offer a master class as well as a side-by-side rehearsal. The program will culminate in a community concert featuring classical, folk, and popular works with singing in both Spanish and English.

To support a concert performance featuring guest artists Sultans of String. String ensemble Sultans of String will perform with the Catskill Symphony Orchestra in a concert serving a three-county regional of rural upstate New York. Low general admission ticket prices and free tickets for area students will be offered.
To support a concert and lecture-demonstration featuring jazz bassist Ron Carter. The lecture-demonstration will be offered free of charge to students in this rural Upstate New York community.

To support a concert featuring the Celtic music and step dancing of Cherish the Ladies. Under the leadership of flutist Joanie Madden, Cherish the Ladies will perform at SUNY Oneonta's Alumni Field House for audiences drawn from a three-county area in rural Central New York.

To support the North Limestone MusicWorks program. Plans include an El Sistema-inspired intensive training program which will be free for all participants. Students from a Title I school located in Lexington's North Limestone neighborhood will take part in the program. Rehearsals, usually in orchestral groups, will take place each school day. Frequent public performances will take place in the immediate area surrounding the program to help build a sense of community.

Purpose: To support chamber orchestra concerts. Additional Project Description: Project plans include performances with a focus on works by African-American and women composers and soloists. Also planned is a presentation of the opera "Glory Denied" by composer Tom Cipullo based on the true story of America’s longest-held prisoner of war. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit residents of Colorado Springs, Colorado. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support concerts with related educational activities. Plans include performances of Jack Heggie's opera To Hell and Back and a concert of Music of African Diaspora. Educational activities may include post-concert discussions.

To support concerts with related educational activities. Project plans include performances of new arrangements of works by composers who died in the Holocaust as well as works by African-American composers. Educational activities may include pre-concert lectures.

To support concerts that highlight works by African-American and women composers and musicians, with related educational activities. Programming will include works by composers Jessie Montgomery and Louise Farrenc. Educational activities may include workshops and community programs. Activities may be carried out virtually as necessary.

To support performances of composer William Brittelle's Si Otsedoha (We're Still Here) with related educational activities. Using words and poetry by middle and high school students from Cherokee, North Carolina, and sung in the Cherokee language by the Cherokee Chamber Singers (comprising members of the Cherokee Nation), the work will highlight the Cherokee Nation's history and importance in the region. Educational plans may include pre- and post-concert talks and a lecture series.

To support a performance of Igor Stravinsky's "Rite of Spring" in partnership with the Charlotte Ballet and including related educational activities. As many as 80 middle school non-dance students will dance along with professional ballet dancers. Performances will take place at Belk Theater at Blumenthal Performing Arts Center as well as in area high schools. Educational activities may include lectures on the work's controversial premiere performance in 1913. In addition, teacher's guides and supplemental materials including pre- and post-concert lessons and cross-curricular activities will be developed for classrooms.

column12: To support an artist residency program for the Charlotte County Public Schools. The Charlotte Symphony Orchestra's Maestro Raffaele Ponti will conduct a series of master classes at Charlotte County, Florida, public middle and high schools. The participating students will be offered the opportunity to attend a rehearsal of the Charlotte Symphony Orchestra and shadow a musician on stage. The students also will be invited to attend a special free performance by the orchestra.

column12: To support an artist residency program for a Charlotte County Public School. Charlotte Symphony Orchestra's Maestro Raffaele Ponti will conduct a series of master classes for Charlotte High School bands. The student band members will be invited to attend a rehearsal of the Charlotte Symphony Orchestra and shadow a musician. The students will also receive complementary tickets to all Charlotte Symphony Orchestra performances during the 2015-2016 season.

Purpose: To support commissions and premiere performances of new orchestral works with related educational activities. Additional Project Description: Composers to be commissioned include Morgan Krauss and Samuel Scranton. Educational activities will include pre-concert discussions with the composers. Intended Beneficiaries: The performances will benefit audiences throughout Chicago and surrounding communities. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

Purpose: To support the concert "A Tribute to Roy Eldridge," with related outreach activities. Additional Project Description: The orchestra will present this tribute concert to trumpeter Roy Eldridge, often considered the musical “link” between trumpeters Louis Armstrong and Dizzy Gillespie. The Chicago Jazz Orchestra will perform alongside guest artists Jon Faddis (trumpet) and Alyssa Allgood (vocalist). Related outreach will include a pre-concert discussion and an educational performance, as well as small group workshops for students. In partnership with the Jazz Institute of Chicago, at least 100 complimentary tickets will be distributed to underserved public school students and their families. Intended Beneficiaries: Performances and related outreach programming will serve diverse online and in-person audiences, including students and their families who will receive complimentary tickets. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support a tribute concert to NEA Jazz Master Nancy Wilson. The tribute concert at the historical Studebaker Theater will feature the Chicago Jazz Orchestra (CJO) joined by three vocalists, including jazz singer Bobbi Wilsyn. The concert repertoire will feature orchestrations used by Wilson in recordings including that of her now classic rendition of "Guess Who I Saw Today." Plans for related project activities will include an open rehearsal for as many as 100 students from Chicago public schools as well as multi-day master classes, led by as many as five CJO musicians, for jazz students at the Merit School of Music and the Midwest Young Artists Conservatory. A special community concert by the students and the clinician ensemble will be the culminating event.

To support a Dizzy Gillespie centennial celebration. The Chicago Jazz Orchestra will be joined by a featured trumpet soloist for a performance at the Studebaker Theater. Concert program selections will draw from Gillespie's decades-spanning repertoire for big band and orchestra. Plans for ancillary activities include an open rehearsal for as many as 100 students from Chicago public schools; multi-day master classes for jazz students at the Merit School of Music and the Midwest Young Artists Conservatory; and a special community concert featuring the students and clinician ensemble.

To support the 50th anniversary celebration of Duke Ellington's Concert of Sacred Music. For the performance at the University of Chicago's Rockefeller Memorial Chapel, the orchestra will be joined by guest vocalists such as baritone Robert Sims and mezzo-soprano Dee Alexander, and The Lakeside Singers. Ancillary activities will be conducted in partnership with the Merit School of Music and may include an open rehearsal with talkback, master classes, and workshops for underserved public school students.

To support a concert titled A Tribute to Sarah Vaughan. This celebration of the late NEA Jazz Master will feature vocalists performing a program of ten previously unavailable, newly transcribed, selections from Vaughan's classic recordings with the 44-piece Chicago Jazz Orchestra.

Purpose: To support artist fees for the performances of orchestral works. Additional Project Description: Repertoire will include performances of works by composers Samuel Coleridge-Taylor, Aaron Copland, and Antonín Dvorák. Intended Beneficiaries: Musicians and audiences from the Chicago area will benefit from the in-person performances. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support stipends for pre-professional musicians of the Civic Orchestra of Chicago. Additional Project Description: The musical training will include rehearsals, performances, and community engagement activities. The musicians will perform free concerts in Orchestra Hall at Symphony Center as well as in underserved Chicago neighborhoods. Intended Beneficiaries: The professional artistic development program will benefit early-career musicians as well as audiences in the Chicago area. Intended Outcome: Arts leaders develop professional skills and strategies.

Purpose: To support musician's salaries for orchestral performances. Additional Project Description: Repertoire will include performances of works by composers Florence Price and Jessie Montgomery. Other programmed works will include compositions by Ludwig van Beethoven and William Grant Still. Intended Beneficiaries: Audiences from the Chicago area will benefit from the in-person performances. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Purpose: To support stipends for pre-professional musicians of the Civic Orchestra of Chicago. Additional Project Description: Musicians will perform free concerts in Orchestra Hall at Symphony Center as well as in underserved Chicago neighborhoods under the direction of Principal Conductor Ken-David Masur, guest conductors, and members of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. Intended Beneficiaries: The professional artistic development program will benefit early-career musicians as well as audiences in the Chicago area. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

To support musician salaries for a series of online concerts. Plans include performances of chamber works recorded in Orchestra Hall at Symphony Center and made available online through the CSO Sessions series.

To support musician's fees for the Civic Orchestra of Chicago. Activities will include virtual rehearsals, performances, and community engagement activities under the direction of Principal Conductor Ken-David Masur, guest conductors, and members of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. Musicians will perform in virtual concerts released online.

To support artist's fees for the Chicago Symphony Orchestra's celebration of Ludwig van Beethoven's 250th birthday. Plans include performances of his symphonies, concertos, piano works, and chamber pieces. Each program in the series will be preceded by a pre-concert lecture or special educational program to provide additional insight into Beethoven's music.

To support stipends for pre-professional musicians of the Civic Orchestra of Chicago. Musicians will perform free concerts in Orchestra Hall at Symphony Center as well as in predominantly low-income Chicago neighborhoods.
