To support professional development training for pre-professional musicians of the Civic Orchestra of Chicago. Culminating in full orchestra concerts, musical training will include rehearsals, performances, and community engagement activities under the direction of guest conductors and members of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. Musicians will perform free concerts in Orchestra Hall at Symphony Center as well as in predominantly low-income Chicago neighborhoods. Cellist Yo-Yo Ma, the symphony's creative consultant, will guide the development of the Civic Fellowship activities, which encourages and trains musicians in community engagement opportunities.

To support a series of concerts with related educational activities. Conducted by Music Director Riccardo Muti and other guest conductors, the concerts in the series will examine works that pair powerful texts and imaginative stories with music. Repertoire will include the ballets by Stravinsky with the Joffrey Ballet, and a song cycle by Berlioz. The series will close with a concert version of Verdi's Aida.

To support a series of concerts that will highlight individual symphony musicians. Programs include world premieres of new works by American composers Jennifer Higdon and Max Raimi conducted by Music Director Riccardo Muti. Other programs in the series include Mozart's Bassoon Concerto featuring Principal Bassoonist Keith Buncke, Mozart's Sinfonia Concertante with Concertmaster Robert Chen, and Debussy's "Sacred and Profane Dances" with Principal Harpist Sarah Bullen. Educational activities include lectures and school programs.

To support professional development training for pre-professional musicians of the Civic Orchestra of Chicago. Culminating in full orchestra concerts, the musical training program will include rehearsals, performances, and community engagement activities under the direction of guest conductors and members of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. Musicians will perform free concerts at Orchestra Hall at Symphony Center as well as at community venues in predominantly low-income Chicago neighborhoods. Cellist Yo-Yo Ma, the symphony's creative consultant, will guide the development of the Civic Fellowship activities, which encourages and trains musicians in community engagement opportunities.

To support training and stipends for pre-professional musicians of the Civic Orchestra of Chicago. Culminating in full orchestra concerts, musical training will include rehearsals, performances, and community engagement activities under the direction of guest conductors, and members of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. Musicians will perform free concerts at Orchestra Hall at Symphony Center as well as in predominantly low-income Chicago neighborhoods. Cellist Yo-Yo Ma, the symphony's creative consultant, will guide the development of the Civic Fellowship activities, which encourages and trains musicians in community engagement opportunities.

To support a 125th anniversary celebration of composer Sergei Prokofiev. Plans include a film screening of Sergei Eisenstein's "Ivan the Terrible" (1944) with Prokofiev's musical score performed live, conducted by Music Director Riccardo Muti. The program will feature Gerard Depardieu as narrator, mezzo-soprano Sasha Cooke, bass Mikhail Petrenko, Chicago Symphony Chorus, and Chicago Children's Choir. Plans also include performances of Prokofiev's Symphony No. 5 and works by Mikhail Glinka and Antonin Dvorak led by guest conductor Charles Dutoit. Finally, a family concert of Prokofiev's "Peter and the Wolf" will take place with guest conductor Matthew Aucoin, and the Magic Circle Mime Company. To prepare young audiences for the concert experience, materials for classroom groups and families will be offered. An in-school curriculum guide for teachers will be developed to engage students in the study of Prokofiev's life as well as musical components of "Peter and the Wolf."

To support training and stipends for pre-professional musicians of the Civic Orchestra of Chicago. Culminating in full orchestra concerts, musical training for emerging musicians will include rehearsals, performances, and community engagement activities under the direction of conductor Cliff Colnot, guest conductors, and members of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. Musicians will perform free concerts at Orchestra Hall at Symphony Center as well as in predominantly low-income Chicago neighborhoods. Cellist Yo-Yo Ma, the symphony's creative consultant, will guide the development of the Citizen Musician activities, which encourages and trains musicians in community engagement opportunities.

To support a festival commemorating the 400th anniversary of the death of William Shakespeare with related educational activities. Curated and conducted by Music Director Riccardo Muti, concerts will feature the orchestra, the Chicago Symphony Chorus, and guest artists. Repertoire may include musical versions of "Romeo and Juliet" by both Berlioz and Tchaikovsky, "The Tempest" by Tchaikovsky, and a concert performance of "Falstaff" by Verdi. Performances will be supplemented by activities including programs for young audiences, in-school curriculum, and pre-concert lectures.

To support CSO Sounds and Stories. The project is a media portal featuring concerts, podcasts, commentary, and radio broadcasts made available for free public access online. The portal features content such as recordings of the educational program "Beyond the Score," live streaming of concerts, radio broadcasts, artist interviews, and program notes about the season's concerts, festivals, and themes.

To support Reveries and Passions, a festival celebrating and exploring two centuries of French music with related educational activities. Curated and conducted by guest conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen, concerts will feature the orchestra, the Chicago Symphony Chorus, and guest artsts. Repertoire will include Ravel's "L'enfant et les sortileges," Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande," and Messiaen's "Turangalila-symphonie." Guest artists include soprano Chloe Briot, bass-baritone Eric Owens, and pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet. Performances will be supplemented by activities including symposia, lectures, and chamber concerts.

To support training and stipends for pre-professional musicians of the Civic Orchestra of Chicago. Culminating in as many as four full orchestra concerts, musical training for emerging musicians will include rehearsals, performances, and community engagement activities under the direction of conductor Cliff Colnot, guest conductors, and members of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. Musicians will perform free concerts at Orchestra Hall at Symphony Center as well as in predominantly low-income Chicago neighborhoods. Cellist Yo-Yo Ma, symphony's creative consultant, will issue an Artistic Challenge for the Civic, a season-long mastery of a piece of music.

To support CSO Sounds and Stories. The initiative is a media portal through which audiences can listen to concerts, podcasts, commentary, and radio broadcasts. Specific content includes livestreaming of concerts and "Beyond the Score," an educational program with the intent of demystifying classical music. CSO Sounds and Stories also comprises radio broadcasts, artist interviews, and program notes about the season's concerts, festivals, and themes. In addition to the website (www.cso.org), portal content is available through social media and mobile applications, and streaming devices such as Roku and Apple TV.

To support a Schubert Festival. Plans include performances of the complete eight symphonies and the rarely performed choral work, Mass in A-Flat Major, all conducted by Music Director Riccardo Muti at the Symphony Center. A vocal series featuring the song cycles "Winterreise" and "Die Schone Mullerin" will be presented by German baritones Christian Gerhaher and Matthias Goerne. Soprano Susanna Phillips and bass-baritone Eric Owens will present a duo recital featuring songs with obbligato clarinet and horn. Pianist Mitsuko Uchida will perform and conduct a performance of "The Trout Quintet."

To support training and stipends for pre-professional musicians of the Civic Orchestra of Chicago. Culminating in as many as four full orchestra concerts, musical training for emerging musicians will include rehearsals, performances, and community engagement activities under the direction of conductor Cliff Colnot, guest conductors, and members of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.

To support the creation of the "CSO Media Portal," an Internet site through which audiences can listen to concerts, podcasts, commentary, and radio broadcasts. Specific content will include live streaming of concerts; "Beyond the Score," (an educational program with the intent of demystifying classical music) and digital and traditional CD releases. Once completed, content will be available on the website, through social media and mobile applications, and streaming devices such as Roku and Apple TV.

To support training and stipends for pre-professional musicians of the Civic Orchestra of Chicago. Culminating in four full orchestra concerts, the musical training will include rehearsals, performances, and community engagement activities under the direction of conductor Cliff Colnot, guest conductors, and members of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.

To support Rivers - Nature, Power, Culture. The three-week festival under the artistic direction of Music Director Riccardo Muti is the culmination of a season-long exploration of the power and role of rivers in ancient and modern civilizations and will include performances of Mississippi River by Florence Price, a new work by Orbert Davis performed by the Chicago Jazz Philharmonic, and works by Toru Takemitsu and composer-in-residence Mason Bates as well as symposia and lectures.

To support the creation of the CSO Media Portal, a web site through which audiences can listen to concerts, podcasts, commentary and radio broadcasts. Specific content will include live streaming of concerts, Beyond the Score (an educational program with the intent of demystifying classical music), rehearsals, pre-concert lectures, and material from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra archive.

Purpose: To support a composer-in-residence program. Additional Project Description: The program will foster the creation and performance of new works for youth and professional orchestras worldwide while promoting diversity in the orchestral canon. To diversify the repertoire available for young musicians, the orchestra will commission new works by living composers such as Marcus Norris, Wang Lu, Allison Loggins-Hull, Ben Wahlund, and Eric Malmquist. Performances will be recorded and distributed so that youth orchestras and school music programs across the country will have easy access to new music for musicians at beginning, intermediate, and advanced levels. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve current and future students, audiences, a diverse cohort of composers, and the orchestral community at-large. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support the Music Pathways In-School Residency Program. The project is a professional development program serving elementary Chicago Public Schools. Teachers, teaching artists, and administrators will meet in the summer to create lesson plans developed for the specific needs of each school. Professional development, classroom residenciess, and assessment will take place during the school year. The orchestra developed the Music Pathways In-School Residency Program using the Orff Schulwerk teaching model that builds musicianship through singing, playing instruments, speech, and movement. The project will identify schools in low-income neighborhoods that are interested in partnering.

To support a new arrangement and video recording of Camille Saint-Saëns' Carnival of the Animals for school students. The filmed concert lasting approximately 45 to 50 minutes will intermix original and new or re-imagined movements. The work will be broadcast on Cincinnati's public broadcasting station, CET/Think TV, and distributed to schools and other PBS stations across the country.

Purpose: To support Classical Roots, a concert in celebration of Black musical heritage. Additional Project Description: The concert will feature the orchestra along with guest artists and the Classical Roots Community Mass Choir, which comprises as many as 150 singers from local churches. Cincinnati Pops Conductor John Morris Russell will be on the podium and Resident Conductor William Henry Caldwell will prepare the chorus. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will benefit audiences in the Cincinnati metropolitan area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support Classical Roots, a concert in celebration of African-American musical heritage. Additional Project Description: The concert will feature the orchestra along with guest artists and the Classical Roots Community Mass Choir, which comprises as many as 150 singers from local churches. Repertoire for the concert may showcase the culture of the Gullah people, African Americans from the Lowcountry region of Georgia, Florida, South Carolina, and North Carolina. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will be promoted to audiences throughout the Cincinnati metropolitan area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support Classical Roots, a concert in celebration of African-American musical heritage. The concert will feature the orchestra along with guest artists. If necessary, the performance may be recorded and presented online.

To support Classical Roots, a concert in celebration of African-American musical heritage. The concert will feature the orchestra along with guest artists and the Classical Roots Choir, which comprises as many as 150 singers from local churches.

column9: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
column12: To support personnel costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support Classical Roots, a series of concerts and recitals in celebration of African-American musical heritage. The multi-day event will include choral concerts, a youth concert, and a community sing for amateur singers. The culminating concert, led by conductor John Morris Russell, will feature the orchestra along with guest artists and the Classical Roots Community Mass Choir, which comprises more than 130 singers from local churches.

To support Classical Roots, a series of concerts and recitals in celebration of African-American musical heritage. The multi-day event includes choral concerts, a young people's concert, and a community sing for amateur singers. The culminating concert, led by conductor John Morris Russell, will feature the orchestra along with guest artists and the Classical Roots Community Mass Choir, which comprises singers from local churches.

To support the Classical Roots concert. Under the direction of Cincinnati Pops conductor John Morris Russell, the concert will feature the orchestra along with guest artists and the Classical Roots Community Mass Choir, which comprises singers from local churches. The concert will take place in the Crossroads Church and will be a communitywide celebration of African-American musical heritage.

To support commissions and premieres of new works including related educational activities. The premiere of "Symphonic Triptych," one of the last compositions by Pulitzer Prize-winning composer Gunther Schuller will take place. Schuller, who died in June 2015, was principal horn player for the orchestra (1943-45), National Council on the Arts member (1974-80), and NEA Jazz Master in 2008. Two concertos for orchestra, works that feature virtuosic treatment of individual instruments, will be commissioned and premiered by composers Thierry Escaich and Zhou Tian. Educational activities may include pre-concert lectures, residency activities for schools and community groups, and panel discussions.

To support the MusicNOW Festival and the required product of copies of each score. The festival will include commissions by composers Daniel Bjarnason and Caroline Shaw with related educational activities. Repertoire will explore the intersections of contemporary and traditional classical music and indie rock. The festival will be curated by Music Director Louis Langree and composer, guitarist, and Cincinnati native Bryce Dessner, member of the rock band The National. Educational activities will include pre-concert lectures and school and community programs with the visiting composers and artists.

To support the MusicNOW Festival. The festival will include premieres and a recording of commissioned works by composers David Lang and Nico Muhly. Concerts also will feature music by composers Bryce Dessner, the festival's artistic director and guitarist in the rock band The National; Jonny Greenwood, guitarist, and keyboard player of the rock band Radiohead; and composer Krzysztof Penderecki. Educational activities will include master classes, workshops, pre-concert lectures, career discussions by Ensemble-in-Residence Eighth Blackbird, and a composer's forum for college students by Lang and Muhly.

To support planning for a series of concerts. The Becoming Heroes festival will explore heroism and celebrate how heroes enrich our society. Repertoire may include Shostakovich's Symphony No. 7 Leningrad, Richard Einhorn's Voices of Light: The Passion of Joan of Arc, and Benjamin Britten's War Requiem.

Purpose: To support the Columbus Symphony Orchestra's Making Music Matters, an educational program for school students. Additional Project Description: The Making Music Matters program is an after-school group music class for children taught by orchestra musicians throughout the school year. The program is available to Title I schools without instrumental music programs and is designed to teach the skills of self-discipline, concentration, and teamwork to enrich the students' lives and to diversify arts participation in the community. The Orchestra Up Close program presents hour-long programs to groups of children in the classroom and around the community allowing for an "up close" experience where musicians perform and talk about their instruments and children have the opportunity to make observations, ask questions, and to play the instruments in an "instrument petting zoo." Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed project will benefit elementary students in the Columbus, Georgia, area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

To support education programs for school students. The Orchestra Up Close program includes multiple visits throughout the school year by small ensembles in public schools, master classes, and instrument petting zoos. Making Music Matters is an after-school group class for children taught by orchestra musicians. A sensory-friendly program will be offered for students with special needs with particular focus to individuals on the autism spectrum. Project activities may take place in-person or online as necessary.

To support education programs for school students. The Orchestra Up Close program includes multiple visits throughout the school year by small ensembles in public schools, master classes, and instrument petting zoos. Making Music Matters is an after-school group violin class for children taught by orchestra musicians. The program will be available to Title I schools without instrumental programs in the county school district and is designed to teach students self-discipline, the power of concentration, and the importance of teamwork.
To support The Orchestra Up Close, an education project. Plans include multiple visits throughout the school year by small ensembles in public schools, and instrument petting zoos.

To support free outdoor video simulcasts of orchestral concerts and a radio broadcast. The opening and closing season concerts in the Ohio Theater, conducted by Music Director Jean-Marie Zeitouni, will be videotaped live and projected on large video screens to audiences on the Columbus Commons Park.

Purpose: To support a commission and premiere of a new work alongside performances of Vivaldi's "Gloria" performed by the Chamber Orchestra of Philadelphia with related educational programs. Additional Project Description: Composer Evan Williams's commissioned work will be a musical response to Vivaldi's "Gloria," both oratorios. The performances will be conducted by the composer, and the chorus will be made up of students in Temple University's Concert Choir. Performances will take place in venues such as Temple University's Performing Arts Center, the Esperanza Arts Center, and Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts. Educational programs will include school visits, family concerts, and a workshop focusing on young female composers. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit audiences throughout the Philadelphia area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support the Music that Matters initiative by the Chamber Orchestra of Philadelphia. In partnership with Melmark, a community agency that provides support for adults and children with developmental disabilities, the initiative will feature programs for Melmark residents and will include open rehearsals at the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts, chamber ensemble performances, and concerts by the orchestra and Melmark's resident handbell choir, the Joybells which will feature a recently commissioned work by Music Director Dirk Brosse.

Purpose: To support a concert series of performances, recordings, and educational activities. Additional Project Description: Each concert will feature composers and/or musicians who have immigrated to the United States. Educational activities will include workshops and demonstrations for school students. Performances will be livestreamed online. Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed project will benefit Hartford-area and online audiences. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

column9: Challenge America: Arts Engagement in American Communities
column12: To support music appreciation classes for students and the community, as well as a concluding concert. Classes and live performance are intended to produce a deeper understanding and appreciation of music and music education.

column9: Challenge America: Arts Engagement in American Communities
column12: To support a series of formal concerts. Young musicians will rehearse and perform at several locations under the direction of professional musicians.

Purpose: To support the Kim Noltemy Young Musicians Program, a free instrumental music program for students. Additional Project Description: Students will receive musical instruments at no-cost, participate in weekly orchestral music instruction after school, participate in community performances, and have the opportunity to attend Dallas Symphony Orchestra concerts. The program is inspired by the El Sistema youth orchestra model that supports children's emotional and physical health as well as music learning. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve students in Dallas, many of whom have limited access to music education. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

column9: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
column12: Purpose: To support personnel expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organization’s constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

To support the commission and premiere of a new work by composer Jessie Montgomery with related educational activities. Educational activities may include pre-concert talks, young student composer workshops, and discussions with high school and college students.

To support ReMix, a concert series. Designed to engage new audiences and break barriers to cultural experiences, concerts of shorter duration without intermission will take place in the Moody Performance Hall. The series, offered at reduced ticket prices, will feature experimental programing with players and conductors interacting with the audience during the concerts. Repertoire will include Tabula Rasa by the Estonian composer Arvo Pärt, a work for violins, chamber orchestra, and prepared piano.

To support ReMix, a new-format concert series. Designed to engage new audiences and break barriers to cultural experiences, concerts of shorter duration without intermission will take place in the Dallas City Performance Hall. The series, offered at reduced ticket prices, will feature experimental programming with players and conductors interacting with the audience. Repertoire may include Alfred Schnittke's Concerto Grosso No. 2 for violin, cello, and orchestra, which also features electric guitar, drum kit, and brake drum.

To support premiere performances of new orchestral works with related educational activities. The world premieres of works by two American composers, Jeremy Gill and Christopher Rouse, will take place at the Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center. The works are Gill's "Serenada Concertante" for oboe and orchestra, written for Principal Oboe Erin Hannigan, and Rouse's Symphony No. 5. Both works will be conducted by Music Director Jaap van Zweden. Educational activities will include the participation by the composers in workshops, master classes, and school programs.

To support a residency and commission by composer and pianist Conrad Tao. Project plans include Tao performing with the orchestra and for the premiere of his own work, as well as the curation of the new ReMix series of genre-bending experimental orchestral performances. Tao also plans to create a series of contemporary chamber performances in collaboration with orchestra musicians. Educational activities will include master classes and workshops with local students.

To support outreach concerts with related educational activities. Plans include concerts, master classes, side-by-side performances, and open rehearsals in communities surrounding Dallas. Repertoire to be performed will include traditional classical works or light classics.

To support the commissioning and premiere of a new work by 17-year-old composer Conrad Tao in observance of the 50th anniversary of the assassination of John F. Kennedy with related educational activities. Plans include four performances of the work, master classes by the composer with high school students, a radio broadcast, and collaborative events with the Sixth Floor Museum, the Mayor's Office, and the Dallas Office of Cultural Affairs.

column9: Challenge America: Arts Engagement in American Communities
column12: To support presentations of "Beethoven Lives Upstairs," to introduce school children to classical music. In concert with the symphony, Classical Kids Music Education will offer musical excerpts interwoven with the story of Beethoven's life and times. Cross-curriculum guides will be provided to as many as 6,500 4th and 5th graders and their teachers.

Purpose: To support staff salaries and artist fees related to free musical training for advanced orchestra students. Additional Project Description: Designed as a talent development program, teaching artists will provide pre-professional training to select orchestra students in the advanced level orchestra ensembles, focusing on mentoring and helping students craft a professional career trajectory. Students will receive private lessons throughout the school year and participate in a summer music chamber program free of charge. Mentors will support students in identifying and applying for college music scholarships, and preparing for auditions. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will benefit students in Washington, D.C. area, with a focus on students traditionally underrepresented in the field of classical music. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support teaching artist and guest artist fees for the Children's Orchestra, an after-school string orchestra program for public school students in Title I elementary schools in Washington, D.C. Teaching artists will provide instrumental music instruction through group and private lessons and string orchestra rehearsals. Students will also have the opportunity to perform with professional musicians. The free program is inspired by El Sistema, which supports the emotional and physical health of children as well as music learning.

To support the Children's Orchestra, an after-school string orchestra program for public school students in Title I elementary schools. The program is inspired by El Sistema, Venezuela's youth orchestra movement supporting the emotional and physical health of children as well as music learning. At no cost to the students or the school, teaching artists will provide instrumental music instruction through group lessons and orchestra rehearsals. In addition, activities will include side-by-side performances and master classes with professional musicians and the opportunity for students to perform in local professional concert venues.

To support the Children's Orchestra, an after-school string orchestra program for D.C. public school students in Title I elementary schools. At no cost to the students or the school, teaching artists will provide as many as two hours of instrumental music instruction three times each week through group lessons and string orchestra rehearsals. In addition, the project will include side-by-side performances and master classes with professional musicians, such as those from the National Symphony Orchestra, and the opportunity to perform in professional concert venues, such as The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and THEARC.

To support staff costs and guest artists for for the Children's Orchestra. The project is an El Sistema inspired, after-school string orchestra program focused on Title I D.C. public elementary school students. At no cost to the students or the school, teaching artists will provide as many as two hours of instrumental music instruction three times each week through group lessons and string orchestra rehearsals.

Purpose: To support a national commissioning and performance consortium project featuring a new work by composer Jennifer Higdon. Additional Project Description: The commission is part of the New Music for America collaborative commissioning program by small-budget orchestras. The new work will be an orchestral suite from Higdon's opera "Cold Mountain." The project will provide resources to assist subsequent premieres by participating orchestras with marketing and residency activities. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit small-budget orchestras participating in the commissioning program as well as in-person audiences in Wilmington and surrounding communities. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

Purpose: To support a concert performance in Craighead County, Arkansas, and related activities. Additional Project Description: A guest violinist will perform with the Delta Symphony Orchestra in a concert performance providing free admission for youth. The guest artist will also provide school and community music workshops. Intended Beneficiaries: Residents and visitors in Craighead County, Arkansas, including economically disadvantaged communities, will benefit from the programming. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Purpose: To support Voices of America, a concert program of works by American composers. Additional Project Description: Programming will feature works by composers Samuel Barber, William Grant Still, Joel Thompson, and George Gershwin. The performances also will be available online through the Live from Orchestra Hall webcasts. Intended Beneficiaries: The performances will benefit audiences throughout the Detroit metropolitan area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.
To support a residency with Wynton Marsalis and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra. Plans include online performances and education events with Detroit Symphony.

To support performances with related community engagement activities. Plans include performances of Black Bottom by composer Nkeiru Okoye inspired by the Detroit neighborhood of the same name. Community engagement activities may include school visits, pre-concert talks, live webcasts, and community events with the composers and artists.

To support a series of concerts celebrating works by American composers and related community engagement activities. The celebration will include all-American programs with several orchestra musicians featured as soloists as well a world premiere by composer Kristen Kuster. Other composers to be featured may include John Luther Adams, Anna Clyne, Aaron Copland, George Gershwin, Philip Glass, Steve Reich, Cindy McTee, Juliet Palmer and Joan Tower. Community engagement activities may include pre-concert lectures, live webcasts, youth workshops, and school visits.

To support the French Festival concert series and related educational activities. Led by Music Director Leonard Slatkin, programming will include works by Berlioz, Debussy, Ravel, Saint-Saens as well as contemporary French composer Guillaume Connesson. Other activities may include pre-concert lectures, interviews with artists and composers, chamber music performances, and free webcasts.

To support a series of performances. Scheduled to take place during the annual conference of the League of American Orchestras, the concert will be webcast live and feature the works by Sarah Kirkland Snider, Mason Bates, Mohammed Fairouz, and Jonathan Bailey Holland. Project plans also include a performance in the Mix at the Max series by musician Shigeto, who creates a blend of electronic, jazz, and hip-hop music.

To support performances of the works of composer Mohammed Fairouz with related educational activities. The featured work will be the premiere of Fairouz's Cello Concerto with Maya Beiser as soloist performed in the Max M. and Marjorie S. Fisher Music Center in Detroit and in venues in the surrounding suburbs. Educational outreach activities will include pre-concert lectures by the composer, a live webcast of the premiere, school visits and performances by the composer and soloist, and discussions with the composer and soloist with local cultural groups.

To support the expansion of DSO Classroom, a web portal intended for educational use. In addition to its existing archive of performances, Detroit Symphony Orchestra's (DSO) web portal will include composer and artist interviews, behind-the-scenes features, custom playlists, and other educational materials. Access to the portal will be available for free to all teachers and students participating in DSO educational activities and to students in DSO's Civic Youth Ensembles.

To support a performance of composer Terence Blanchard's "A Tale of God's Will (A Requiem for Katrina)," with related educational activities. In commemoration of the tenth anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, the suite of 13 original pieces will be performed by Blanchard and members of his band along with symphony musicians. Educational activities will include a pre-concert talk by Blanchard, a pre-concert performance by student musicians of the symphony's Civic Jazz Orchestra, a jazz community forum, a workshop on film scoring, and a community screening of the documentary "When the Levees Broke" which features Blanchard's score.

To support Orchestra Solos! with related educational activities. Plans include a series of concerts and a live webcast that will feature orchestra musicians as soloists, solo and chamber recitals, and related educational activities. Repertoire will include composer Elliott Carter's "Remembrance" for trombone and orchestra, John Williams' Tuba and Flute Concertos, Allan Gilliland's Harp Concerto, and Vivaldi's Concerto for Four Violins. Solo and chamber recitals by symphony musicians will take place in community venues and for students.

To support the Tchaikovsky Festival components on DSO's "Live From Orchestra Hall" webcast series. In addition to concerts, the webcasts will include features on Tchaikovsky's life, a behind-the-scenes look at the orchestra, and real-time discussions on Facebook and Twitter

To support performances of a complete cycle of Beethoven symphonies and related educational activities. All nine Beethoven symphonies plus the three "Leonore" Overtures, the "Fidelio" Overture, and "Creatures of Prometheus" will be performed, conducted by Music Director Leonard Slatkin, over a three-week period.

column7: Dr. Shirley Linzy Young Artists Orchestra of Las Vegas
column12: Purpose: To support the presentation of cultural artists and events. Additional Project Description: The Las Vegas Young Artists Orchestra is the only tuition-free, professional training youth orchestra in Nevada. The orchestra will present concerts featuring a mix of local, emerging, and established visiting artists. Guest artists also will participate in free lectures, master classes, coaching, and mentorship for the young musicians. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve area youth in the orchestra, professional artists, and audiences from the Las Vegas area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

column7: Dr. Shirley Linzy Young Artists Orchestra of Las Vegas
column12: To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

column7: Dr. Shirley Linzy Young Artists Orchestra of Las Vegas
column12: To support a professional artistic development program and the presentation of guest artists. Plans include providing students with professional coaching, mentorship, recorded events, and collaborative performance opportunities with local and visiting professional artists. Some activities may take place virtually as needed.

column9: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act

column12: To support the expansion of the Las Vegas Young Artists Orchestra programs and the presentation of guest artists. The tuition-free youth music program will develop a new percussion ensemble and a new chamber orchestra program. In addition, guest artists in the classical, jazz, and world music fields will perform alongside students as soloists and collaborators.

column12: To support venue costs and music director fees for community performances. The Las Vegas Young Artists Orchestra will perform at various community locations, such as libraries and performing arts centers, and will feature a guest artist at a performance. The orchestra, led by Music Director Yunior Lopez, is a tuition-free professional training youth orchestra based in Henderson, Nevada.

To support a residency featuring violinist Midori. In addition to a public performance with the Dubuque Symphony Orchestra, Midori's residency will include a series of engagement activities at venues throughout Dubuque and the surrounding rural area. These activities are scheduled to be held at local elementary and middle schools, including Title I schools, as well as at a nursing home and a residential care facility for adults with disabilities, and may include master classes, workshops, and question-and-answer sessions.

column9: Challenge America: Arts Engagement in American Communities
column12: To support a concert performance and associated community outreach activities. Guest violinist Augustin Hadelich will join the symphony orchestra for the performance that will include a musical duel representative of the rivalry between Antonio Salieri and Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. Community outreach activities will include lectures at an area shopping mall and local senior living facilities.

Purpose: To support a free after-school string instrument program for low-income students. Additional Project Description: The program will take place at two elementary schools in Illinois School District U46 in Elgin. Each student will be provided a violin and will learn basics of instrument care. Students will participate in after-school music classes and interactive demonstrations throughout the school year. At the end of the year, students will showcase their progress at a concert performance for the fellow students and the general public. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve participating low-income students in Elgin, Illinois and surrounding communities. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Purpose: To support a musical collaboration between composer Adrian Gordon and students. Additional Project Description: Students in an El Sistema-inspired program will participate in a workshop with Gordon to learn about musical storytelling and improvisation. After the workshops, students will continue to explore the material with their instructors. Sound elements created by the students will be recorded and arranged by Gordon into a new musical piece. The resulting work will be presented to the public. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve low-income youth in Schenectady, New York. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support a Latinx outreach program and performances. Additional Project Description: Eugene-Springfield Youth Orchestras will improve current programming to reach the Latinx youth population. Activities will include hiring a Spanish-speaking teacher, translating the website to Spanish, and a series of performances and classes targeted specifically for a Latinx audience. Intended Beneficiaries: This project will primarily serve Latinx youth in Eugene, Oregon. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

To support Adventures in Music education concerts including a new commission by composer David Ott. The new work will be scored for nine instruments with a narrator. Adventures in Music is a new initiative intended to reach students aged five through eight, an age group not currently served by the orchestra's educational and outreach programs. The work will be performed in conjunction with a hands-on, meet-and-greet session with the musicians. Teacher materials will be developed such as lesson plans, suggested classroom activities, and recordings.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. .

To support music performances by Amit Peled and the Peabody Peled Cello Gang, with associated education programs. Cellist and composer Amit Peled will perform and teach master classes for students in local high schools. He will collaborate with lead teachers to customize the experience to each high school environment. The school performances will be followed by a public concert. Students and their families will receive free tickets to attend the concert.

To support the residency and collaboration of pianist Simone Dinnerstein with the Fairfax Symphony Orchestra. Interactive performances of J.S. Bach's "Inventions" will be held for up to five Title I elementary public schools to connect the music of Bach to jazz, rap, techno, and other contemporary music. A culminating event will include a rehearsal and performance.

To support performances, workshops, and related outreach activities featuring pianist Awadagin Pratt. The guest artist will be in residence with the Fairfax Symphony Orchestra conducting free master classes for community members. He will also provide lecture-demonstrations for local Title I schools and senior community centers. Pratt's residency will culminate in a public performance with the Fairfax Symphony Orchestra at George Mason University's Center for the Arts, which low-income students will receive free tickets to attend.

To support a concert featuring Ricardo Morales, principal clarinetist of the Philadelphia Orchestra, and a series of outreach activities that will engage Latino and Hispanic residents in Virginia. Morales will provide bilingual workshops for students attending Spanish immersion schools, an open rehearsal for students, a visit to the Levine School of Music, lectures for adults in Fairfax, and transportation to the concert will be provided by Fairfax Symphony Orchestra to students attending Fairfax County Public Schools.

To support the International Aimusic Festival. Firebird Youth Chinese Orchestra members, regional music groups, and master artists from China will present concerts, lectures, and master classes that will foster a deeper understanding and appreciation of Chinese opera. The youth orchestra will receive special musical instruction from Firebird faculty to prepare for the concerts, which will be presented without electronic amplification, allowing the audience to hear the music as it was originally intended to be heard.

To support the International Airmusic Festival: Intangible Chinese Heritage Celebration. Performers from China and other Asian countries will showcase a variety of traditional Asian operas, as well as offer a seminar on Chinese opera. As many as 20 groups are expected to present performances that will include Kunqu Opera, Peking Opera, Yueju Opera, and Tibetan Opera.

To support a Chinese traditional music concert and a summer music camp for children. Master musicians will present a concert of traditional Chinese folk music and traditional operas. During a summer camp, students will receive instruction in the "dizi" (bamboo flute), "erhu" (two-stringed violin), "liuqin" (treble lute), "pipa" (four-stringed lute), "ruan" (four-stringed guitar), "sheng" (mouth organ), "suona" (double-reed oboe/trumpet), "yangqin" (dulcimer), and "zheng" (zither), as well as various percussion instruments.

To support a project to teach young musicians to perform the modern Chinese traditional instrument orchestra setting of Red Detachment of Women, an important work written during the Cultural Revolution. During weekly classes held at the San Jose City College Music Department, students will practice the score individually, in sections, and as a full ensemble leading to culminating concert performances throughout the Bay Area.

They will use these materials to create and produce school performances. The CHS will curate a portable exhibit that will showcase the students' compilations. Purpose: To support concerts with guest artists and related educational activities. To support Soul Strings, a music-informed therapy program hosted collaboratively with the Arc of Greater New Orleans. Working with children and adults who have developmental disabilities and older adults with cognitive impairments, orchestra musicians and licensed music therapists will provide weekly sessions including music-listening to improve attention and memory; singing to improve communication; movement to improve balance and attention; music-making to improve communication, memory, and attention; and discussion groups to improve communication through reflection. Additional key partners include St. Michael Special School and Poydras Home, a New Orleans retirement community.

Educational activities may include a pre-concert talk by the composer, programs with music composition students at local schools, a master class, a reading of student compositions, an open rehearsal of the new banjo concerto, and a family concert.

Plans include a free concert of music that will explore how composers have envisioned Louisiana's natural environment, a composer competition, chamber performances, a symposium and art exhibition in collaboration with the Historic New Orleans Collection, and educational materials on CD and DVD.

The guest artist will talk to the audience about the music during the performance and the audience will have the opportunity to ask questions or share their thoughts about the experience.

To support a performance of "Sephardic Journeys" by composer/violinist Ittai Shapira. Performed by the Mankato Symphony Orchestra and featuring Shapira and cellist Tony Ross as soloists, the concert is intended to serve a growing immigrant community in Mankato, Minnesota, and facilitate understanding between the rapidly diversifying population. Supplementary activities will include visits to local schools, a panel discussion on music and the immigrant experience, and outreach work by the guest artists and symphony staff and musicians to bring awareness of the performance to rural and nontraditional communities.

To support Cancion de las Americas, a concert featuring percussionist and vocalist Estaire Godinez. Intended to serve the Hispanic and Latino community, bilingual narration will enhance the performance.

To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support a period instrument performance project. The chamber orchestra, with Artistic Director Antoine Plante and guest artist tenor Nicholas Phan, will perform a multimedia concert of Franz Schubert's Die Winterreise arranged for the Mercury orchestra and tenor at the Wortham Center's Cullen Theater in downtown Houston. Video projections will enhance the live performance experience.

To support Mercury's period instrument performance project. The chamber orchestra will present a multimedia concert of composer Franz Schubert's Die schöne Müllerin arranged for the Mercury orchestra and tenor. It will be set for string orchestra and wind quintet to highlight the expressiveness and lyricism of the composer's setting and Müller's poetry and will include video materials projected during the performance that will include artwork, photographs, and primary source texts relating to the work. Artistic Director Antoine Plante will conduct the concert of Schubert's song cycle featuring guest artist tenor Nicholas Phan with the ensemble at the Wortham Center's Cullen Theater in downtown Houston.

To support a performance project by the Mercury Chamber Orchestra. The chamber orchestra will present a multimedia project featuring the music of a circle of Romantic-era composers Clara Wieck Schumann, Robert Schumann, Friedrich Wieck (Clara Schumann's father), and friend and colleague Johannes Brahms. The programming will weave spoken word and projected visuals with the performances of their music works. The project will explore the lives and relationships of the artists and will be expanded by historical photographs and personal correspondence.

To support the development and presentation of a cross-disciplinary music education workshop in at-risk Houston schools. Per 9/6/17 scope chg, will perform a different cross-curricular concert for the 2017-18 season instead of a Physics workshop - SG.

To support "8 Seasons," a free outdoor concert in Houston's Hermann Park. The 16-member orchestra, under the direction of Artistic Director Antoine Plante, will perform a concert program that will juxtapose Antonio Vivaldi's "Four Seasons" (written in 1723) with "The Four Seasons of Buenos Aires" suite composed by Argentinean composer Astor Piazzolla from 1964-70.

Purpose: To support the world premiere orchestral performance of Zodiac Suite by composer Mary Lou Williams, arranged and accompanied by pianist Aaron Diehl, and related activities. Additional Project Description: Zodiac Suite by composer Mary Lou Williams was originally composed in 1945 for piano, upright bass, and drums, while Diehl's arrangement will be the first for a full orchestra. Activities will focus on the significance of Mary Lou Williams, her contemporaries, and their contributions to American music and culture. Related community engagement opportunities may include master classes for area students, a book discussion and performance series with the Milwaukee Public Library, and a pre-concert discussion series for general audiences. Activities may be conducted virtually. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit artists and audiences in Milwaukee. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support efforts to increase onstage representation of BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color) artists, conductors, and composers throughout the orchestra's programming. Additional Project Description: Performances at Bradley Symphony Hall will include new works by composers such as Jessie Montgomery and Wynton Marsalis, along with works by Florence Price and William Grant Still, as well as additional guest artists. The orchestra will partner with organizations such as the Black String Triage Ensemble for community engagement events. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve audiences in Greater Milwaukee. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Purpose: To support orchestral education programs for youth. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve Milwaukee youth who face barriers to music education and intensive music study. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

To support a community engagement project. The initiative, Common Chords Detroit Lakes, is a partnership with the community of Detroit Lakes, located approximately 205 miles northwest of Minneapolis. Through a week-long residency, the orchestra will perform free concerts and participate in engagement activities ranging from outreach performances by the orchestra's chamber music ensembles to educational workshops. Activities will take place at venues such as the Historic Holmes Theatre, Detroit Lakes Middle School, the Little Detroit Lake Pavilion, Holy Rosary Church, the Detroit Lakes Public Library, as well as the Ecumen Detroit Lakes Nursing Home and the Lodge on Detroit Lakes.

To support a community engagement project in Bemidji, Minnesota. Titled "Common Chords Bemidji," the intitiative is a partnership with the community of Bemidji, located more than 200 miles north of Minneapolis. Through a week-long residency, the orchestra will offer free performances and engagement activities, including outreach performances by the orchestra's chamber music ensembles, a late night jazz "jam" with the orchestra and local musicians at a local pub, and educational workshops and orchestral concerts at Bemidji High School and Sanford Center.

Activities will include open rehearsals, interactive workshops, and residencies in venues such as schools, libraries, community centers, stores, daycare centers, and health centers.

column12: To support performances of "Tchaikovsky Discovers America" featuring actors from Classical Kids Live. Intended to serve economically disadvantaged communities within Muncie and Delaware County, the performance piece will depict Tchaikovsky's arrival in New York City for the opening of Carnegie Hall in 1891 and his travels to Niagara Falls.

To support a performance project with the Spartanburg Philharmonic featuring Bela Fleck and Abigail Washington. Music Director Stefan Sanders will lead programming featuring Grammy Award-winning banjo musicians Bela Fleck and Abigail Washburn along with the orchestra. Activities will include community engagement events such as a teaching residency with banjo musician Kristin Scott Benson, a film screening of Fleck's documentary Throw Down Your Heart, and a master class with Washburn.

To support the Spartanburg Philharmonic Orchestra's performance and artist-in-residence project featuring percussionist Dame Evelyn Glennie. Programming will feature a new percussion concerto featuring the waterphone by composer Sean O'Boyle written specifically for Glennie. In addition, the project will include a percussion master class and a lecture-demonstration exploring the importance of listening skills with Glennie. The orchestra will also hold outreach events at venues including the South Carolina School for the Deaf and Blind and Converse College.

Purpose: To support the Cleveland Orchestra's concert performances of Giacomo Puccini's opera La Fanciulla del West, conducted by Franz Welser-Möst. Additional Project Description: Set in the mid-19th century amidst the movement of settlers into the American West, the opera explores the promise and peril of the California Gold Rush. The performances will be part of an opera and humanities festival with a focus on the contemporary relevance of classical works. The orchestra also will partner with local organizations on related community engagement activities such as film screenings and interactive discussions. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit artists and audiences in Cleveland. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support a performance and community engagement project. Additional Project Description: The Cleveland Orchestra Presents Outsiders in Opera and Music will include a free annual Martin Luther King, Jr. Community Concert and Open House, Giuseppe Verdi's "Otello," educational concerts for elementary schoolchildren, and other events based on the theme of "outsiders." Performances of festival concerts, educational concerts, and orchestral concerts will be presented with in-person and socially-distanced seating in Severance Hall. Intended Beneficiaries: Audiences of all ages, including students in the Cleveland Metropolitan School District, will be served by the project. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support a digital performance and community engagement project. The digital content the orchestra will produce and share with the community will include the In Focus concert series, a series of recorded performances posted to the orchestra’s digital streaming platform, as well as short videos by guest artists, performances, and educational content posted to the orchestra’s social media outlets.

To support planning for The Cleveland Orchestra's concert performance of Alban Berg's opera Lulu. The opera will be part of a festival curated by Music Director Franz Welser-Möst titled The Cleveland Orchestra Performs Forbidden Music, a performance project of musical works banned during the Nazi era in Germany of the 1930s and 1940s. .
