To support The Cleveland Orchestra's new semi-staged production of Ariadne auf Naxos by Composer Richard Strauss with related educational and engagement activities. The opera is based on the Ariadne myth of Prince Theseus of Athens. Educational activities will include an open rehearsal for vocal students from area universities and conservatories, a lecture-demonstration on set design, and an opera lecture on Ariadne auf Naxos. As many as three performances will take place at Severance Hall.

To support a new production of "Pelleas et Melisande" by composer Claude Debussy at the Cleveland Orchestra. The production will weave technology and theater into the music. The creative team will include director Yuval Sharon and conductor Franz Welser-Most. The cast includes baritone Elliot Madore, soprano Martina Jankova, bass-baritone Hanno Muller-Brachmann, and mezzo-soprano Nancy Maultsby. Audiences will be reached through performances at Severance Hall, a radio broadcast, a lecture series, and through related education workshops to engage college students in the creation, staging, and production of the opera.

To support the Cleveland Orchestra's performances of Bela Bartok's opera "Bluebeard's Castle," reimagined as an opera/ballet. The Joffrey Ballet will collaborate to create newly commissioned choreography, which will be added to the orchestral interlude opening the fourth scene and to further the expression of the silent wives in the last scene. The artistic team will include bass Mikhail Petrenko and soprano Katarina Dalayman. Audiences will be reached through performances at Severance Hall, a radio broadcast, and through related education workshops to engage college students in the creation, staging, and production of this opera/ballet.

To support the development of an online archive celebrating the centennial anniversary of The Cleveland Orchestra. Focused on the Prometheus Cycle, the archive will be organized around 12 curated essays. Each essay will include an exploration of the music and will feature audio recordings spanning the orchestra's 100 year history. A video interview by Music Director Franz Welser-Most will introduce the archive. The archive will be free to the public.

To support The Cleveland Orchestra's performance of a new work by composer Ryan Wigglesworth. In addition to the premiere performance under the direction of Music Director Franz Welser-Most, the project will include related educational and audience engagement activities such as pre-concert lectures, rehearsals with the orchestra and its youth orchestra musicians, a composer's forum for college students, and in-school visits in the greater metropolitan area of Cleveland. The project will conclude Wigglesworth's two-year residency as the orchestra's Young Composer Fellow.

To support The Cleveland Orchestra's semi-staged performances of Leos Janacek's "The Cunning Little Vixen," and related educational and outreach activities. These productions will use animation and videography to bring the operatic fantasy to life on the concert-hall stage.

To support the world premiere performances of a newly-commissioned orchestral work by composer Sean Shepherd by The Cleveland Orchestra and music director Franz Welser-Most. The project will include pre-concert lectures, composition seminars, school visits, and master classes with the award-winning composer, who will be completing a two-year residency with the orchestra as its Daniel R. Lewis Young Composer Fellow.

column7: National Philharmonic Orchestra & Chorale of Montgomery County, Inc.
column12: To support a series of school-based community concerts and educational activities featuring guitarist Mark Edwards. The concerts will occur in conjunction with school events attended by students and families. The musical program will include commentary, demonstrations, and audience participation in an informal setting, designed to keep the audience engaged. The performances will be free and open to the public.

column7: National Philharmonic Orchestra & Chorale of Montgomery County, Inc.
column12: To support "The American Virtuoso Violin" concert featuring violinist Elena Urioste and the Maryland Classical Youth Orchestra, with related outreach activities. Urioste and the orchestra will travel to Ward Five, located in Washington, DC, and provide master classes for students at Doar Charter School.

column7: National Repertory Orchestra, Inc. Colorado Philharmonic
column12: To support a professional development project for emerging orchestral musicians including master classes, a summer seminar program, and performances. Under the direction of Music Director Carl Topilow and guest conductors such as JoAnn Falletta, Clair St. James, and Mei-Ann Chen, the Training Tomorrow's Classical Music Leaders project. The orchestra of young musicians (selected through audition) will perform orchestral and chamber music concerts and participate in community outreach activities at the Breckenridge Riverwalk Center and other venues in towns such as Dillon, Frisco, Silverthorne, and Vail, Colorado.

column7: National Repertory Orchestra, Inc. Colorado Philharmonic
column12: To support a professional development program for emerging orchestral musicians. Under the direction of Music Director Carl Topilow and guest conductors, the project will include master classes, a summer seminar program, and performances. The orchestra of young musicians, selected through audition, will perform concerts and participate in community outreach activities at the Breckenridge Riverwalk Center and other venues in Denver and Dillon.

column7: National Symphony Orchestra Association of Washington, DC
column12: Purpose: To support musician salaries for an artist residency for composer Carlos Simon. Additional Project Description: The residency will feature world premiere commissions, concerts highlighting Simon's existing works, and community engagement activities. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit artists and audiences in Washington, DC. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

column7: National Symphony Orchestra Association of Washington, DC
column12: Purpose: To support musician salaries for a performance project celebrating composer George Walker. Additional Project Description: The concert will feature Walker's Sinfonia No. 1 and Sinfonia No. 4 and will be performed at Howard University, a historically Black university. A Washington, D.C. native who performed his first public piano recital at Howard at the age of 14, Walker was the first African-American composer to win the Pulitzer Prize for music. The free concert will be complemented by free public programs, including educational programs led by the Kennedy Center's composer-in-residence Carlos Simon, chamber music performances with music students at Howard University, pre- and post-concert discussions, and an exhibition in the lobby of the Kennedy Center. Student engagement will include Dunbar High School and the Duke Ellington School for the Arts in Washington, D.C. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will engage diverse audiences of all ages in the greater Washington, D.C., metropolitan area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

column7: National Symphony Orchestra Association of Washington, DC
column12: To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

column7: National Symphony Orchestra Association of Washington, DC
column12: To support musicians' fees for a performance project celebrating the Women’s Suffrage Centennial. Programming for Girl Power! Celebrating Women in Music will showcase women composers, conductors, and performers in programming designed for young people and families. Guest artist Michelle Merrill, music director of the Coastal Symphony of Georgia, will join the orchestra in performances at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

column7: National Symphony Orchestra Association of Washington, DC
column12: To support musician salaries for a performance project of contemporary orchestral music. The orchestra and Music Director Gianandrea Noseda will perform works by living composers, including ARCTICA by Lera Auerbach and Itaipu by Philip Glass. A co-commission by the orchestra (NSO) and the National Geographic Society, Auerbach's work will be scored for full orchestra and chorus and is inspired by an Arctic expedition the composer took with Dr. Enric Sala, a marine ecologist and National Geographic Explorer-in-Residence. The Washington Chorus will join the orchestra in its world-premiere performance. Presented on a different concert program with the Choral Arts Society will be the NSO's first performance of Itaipu by Glass. The 1989 work is a four-movement symphonic cantata for orchestra and chorus about the Itaipu Dam, the world's largest hydroelectric dam located on the Parana River between Paraguay and Brazil. The libretto is based on the creation myth of the Guarani, a South American indigenous people, and will be sung in traditional Guarani. The concerts will be performed at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

column7: National Symphony Orchestra Association of Washington, DC
column12: To support musician and stage personnel salaries for the In Your Neighborhood community engagement initiative. The orchestra will present one-week residencies across neighborhoods of Washington, D.C., such as the Downtown/Penn Quarter, Brookland/NoMa, Columbia Heights, and Capitol Hill/H Street areas. Through the In Your Neighborhood residencies, the orchestra musicians will perform full orchestral repertoire for the community, as well as a number of chamber music concerts in schools, libraries, community centers, and performing arts spaces. The initiative will also include a full-orchestra concert at Washington Union Station.

column7: National Symphony Orchestra Association of Washington, DC
column12: To support the In Your Neighborhood community engagement initiative. The orchestra will conduct a week-long artist residency in the Southeast/Southwest neighborhoods of Washington, D.C. Through the sixth In Your Neighborhood residency, the orchestra musicians will perform full orchestral repertoire for the community, as well as a number of chamber music concerts in schools, libraries, community centers, and performing arts spaces. Guest artists will join the orchestra in concert at larger venues such as THEARC. In addition, the musicians will return to previously visited D.C. communities such as Columbia Heights, the U Street Corridor, NoMa, Capitol Hill, and Downtown/Penn Quarter.

column7: National Symphony Orchestra Association of Washington, DC
column12: To support The National Symphony Orchestra's Sound Health initiative. The free, year-round program strives to create a healthier, more enriching environment in leading health care institutions by providing live classical music performances for their patients, family members, medical staff and visitors. The orchestra will partner with medical facilities in the greater Washington, D.C. area, such as the National Institutes of Health, Children's National Medical Center, and Walter Reed National Military Medical Center. Programming will be tailored to fit the needs of each partner and will include chamber music performances, instrument "Petting Zoos," and an annual full-orchestra concert.

column7: National Symphony Orchestra Association of Washington, DC
column12: To support symphonic concerts during the John F. Kennedy Center for Performing Arts' international festival celebrating the performing arts of Portugal and Spain. The orchestra, under the direction of guest conductor Jesus Lopez-Cobos, will perform works by composers that were from or influenced by Spain and Portugal, including from countries of Spanish and Portuguese heritage. Programming will include works such as "La vida breve" by Manuel de Falla, "Espana" by Emmanuel Chabrier, "Images - Iberia" by Claude Debussy, and Isaac Albeniz's "Suite Espagnola." The performances will be presented at the Kennedy Center and broadcast locally on WETA 90.9 FM Public Radio, as well as WETA's website at WETA.org.

column7: National Symphony Orchestra Association of Washington, DC
column12: To support New Moves: Symphony + Dance, a performance project featuring works by American composers. Programming for the festival, directed by Guest Conductor Joseph Wilkins, will include works by John Adams, Leonard Bernstein, Duke Ellington, Michael Daugherty, George Gershwin, Marc Neikrug, and William Schuman, and will feature guest violinist Leila Josefowicz and two NSO principals, bassoonist Sue Heineman, and timpanist Jauvon Gilliam, as well as American dance companies KEIGWIN + COMPANY, the New Ballet Ensemble, and Jessica Lang Dance Company.

column7: National Symphony Orchestra Association of Washington, DC
column12: To support the NSO In Your Neighborhood: Howard University/Shaw/U Street project. The orchestra will participate in a week-long residency, which will include two full-orchestra concerts: one led by music director Christoph Eschenbach and the other by NSO Pops principal conductor Steven Reineke, small ensemble concerts, and education and outreach activities in community venues of the Shaw neighborhood of DC.

To support the multimedia concert performance, "Short Ride on a Fast Machine," featuring pianist Jon Kimura Parker. Parker will perform with a timed light show, dramatic sign language interpreters, and on-stage screens with visuals for an enhanced orchestra experience for people who are deaf and hard of hearing. Outreach activities will include collaborations with Columbus Deaf Services, Columbus School for the Deaf, and other local school American Sign Language programs.

To support Atlantic Crossing, a performance project with San Francisco Chanticleer, the male a cappella vocal chorus. Programming under the direction of Music Director Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg will focus on music by European composers living and working in America during the years between the two world wars, as well as works from the great American Songbook canon by composers Cole Porter, George Gershwin, and Duke Ellington.

Purpose: To support a concert series and related community engagement activities. Additional Project Description: The program will focus on works by three historic Black composers: Margaret Bonds, Florence Price, and Helen E. Hagan, and will be presented at the Lyman Center for the Performing Arts and additional community venues in New Haven, Connecticut. Works to be performed include Bonds' Montgomery Variations (1964), inspired by the civil rights movement and composed in seven parts; Price's 1934 Piano Concerto in One Movement, which incorporates spirituals as well as the Juba, a dance originated by enslaved people; and Hagan's 1912 Concerto in C Minor, written in a late Romantic style interspersed with Ragtime. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will benefit audiences in New Haven and surrounding communities in Connecticut. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the orchestra's Harmony Fellowship. Additional Project Description: The program will provide professional development across musical, administrative, and board levels of the classical music industry, with a focus on individuals from underrepresented communities. Participants will perform alongside orchestra musicians, receive mentoring from leadership and staff, develop and conduct individual projects to advance their career goals, and engage in community and educational programming. Harmony Quartets, consisting of instrumentalists in the program, will conduct in-school ensemble visits and performances for schoolchildren in New Haven Public Schools. Intended Beneficiaries: In addition to the fellows mentored annually, programming will benefit audiences of all ages. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

column9: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
column12: Purpose: To support personnel expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organization’s constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

To support the presentation of excerpts of The Snowy Day by composer Joel Thompson. The new opera work tells the story a young African American boy named Peter who is exploring a city after the year’s first snowfall. Published in 1960, The Snowy Day was one of the first children’s books to feature a black protagonist.

To support concert programs that will explore classical works alongside contemporary works. Programming will feature orchestral works by composers such as Antonin Dvorák and Florentine Price, youth and family concerts, and free neighborhood community concerts by the orchestra's Harmony Quartets. The project will take place at Lyman Center for the Performing Arts at Southern Connecticut State University and in neighborhood spaces in low-income communities in New Haven and Shelton, Connecticut.

To support a performance and community engagement project commemorating the 80th anniversary of Marian Anderson's April 9, 1939, concert at the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C. The orchestra and Music Director William Boughton will perform a concert program titled To Thee We Sing, featuring guest artist soprano Harolyn Blackwell. Programming will include orchestral works including Old and Lost Rivers by Tobias Picker; an arrangement of traditional spirituals by Joel Martin; Lincoln Portrait, Down a Country Lane, and John Henry by Aaron Copland; Hip-Hop Essay #1 by Daniel Bernard Romain; and Joseph Schwantner's New Morning for the World. Accompanying visual images will be curated by Peabody Award-winning broadcaster, producer, and director Elliott Forrest. Students from local public schools will also have the opportunity to perform side-by-side with orchestra musicians. The concert will take place at Lyman Center for the Performing Arts at Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven.

To support a commissioning and performance project of a new work by composer Hannah Lash. The orchestral work, titled "The Lash/Voynich Project," by New Haven Symphony Orchestra's composer-in-residence Lash, will explore the Voynich Manuscript dating back to the 15th or 16th century. Housed at Yale University's Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, the manuscript is one of the most searched-for items in the collections. The orchestra will perform the second of the four-movement work in this phase of the project.

To support the Christopher Brubeck educational residency. Within the framework of the Orchestral Jazz Initiative, the multi-instrumentalist, band leader, and composer will conduct monthly residency visits and community concerts at the James Hillhouse and Cooperative Arts and Humanities public high schools. Brubeck also will lead 12 Young People's Concerts, (including the premiere of a new work) and be featured in two NHSO Classics Series performances. Additionally, he will participate in the Young Composer project, conduct professional development sessions for NHSO musicians and teachers, and engage in various community engagement activities.

To support an artist residency and premier of a new work by composer Christopher Theofanidis. The Orchestra and Music Director William Boughton will collaborate with Theofanidis for the premiere performances of the work, "Virtue," based on Hildegard von Bingen's allegorical morality play of the same name.

To support a winter festival exploring music inspired by William Shakespeare's plays. The orchestra will collaborate with The Shakespeare Theatre of New Jersey, Montclair State University Chorale, and Manhattan School of Music Symphonic Chorus and will perform works by composers such as Hector Berlioz and Felix Mendelssohn. Festival concerts, as well as related educational and community engagement activities, will take place in Newark, Morristown, New Brunswick, and Princeton, New Jersey.

To support a professional development project for emerging composers. The week-long composition institute will culminate in a public concert of world premieres of the resulting new works and will include reading sessions by the orchestra, coaching sessions with composer Steven Mackey, and career development seminars with leaders in the music field. The orchestra will collaborate with Princeton University's Department of Music and participants will be selected through a nationwide search.

Purpose: To support a multi-faceted project of orchestral performance and education celebrating Earth Day. Additional Project Description: Titled OCEANA, programming will include works by Argentinean composer Oliver Golijov and Vietnamese American composer Viet Cuong performed in partnership with Choral Arts Society of Washington and the Montgomery County Public Schools Fine Arts program. The concert will be presented at Strathmore Music Center in North Bethesda, Maryland. Accompanying educational activities may include curriculum development and the production of online teaching materials in partnership with Montgomery County Public Schools, and in-person teaching visits by Cuong. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve audiences of all ages living in the Washington, DC, area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support an orchestral performance project celebrating Día de los Muertos. Additional Project Description: Programming by the ensemble will include a commissioned work and creation of an immersive musical environment for the event. In addition to a live concert, which will be recorded for online access, the project will include a discussion with Artistic Director Alejandro Hernandez-Valdez and Ix-Nic Iruegas, Cultural Attache to the Embassy of Mexico, who will discuss the Día de los Muertos holiday and give insight to the concert program. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will engage audiences of all ages, including the Hispanic community living in the Washington, D.C., area. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support a performance project honoring the legacy of Nelson Mandela. The concert series will feature the premiere performance of a new work by South African composer Mokale Koapeng, as well as the overture to Ludwig van Beethoven's Fidelio and works by Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky and George Frideric Handel. Concerts will be presented in Washington, D.C., and in Bridgewater, Virginia.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

column8: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
column9: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
column12: To support personnel and facilities costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support a national tour of the New Orleans Jazz Orchestra. Featured artists will be Grammy Award-winning recording artists Irvin Mayfield and Dee Dee Bridgewater. Project plans include performances nationwide, as well as ancillary elements such as educational clinics conducted by orchestra musicians for student musicians.

column9: Challenge America: Arts Engagement in American Communities
column12: To support tenth anniversary concert performances. The concerts will include a photo-choreographed visual presentation of images to complement the musical selection. Commemorative marketing material also will be produced, documenting the accomplishments of the symphony orchestra.

To support a chamber music program for middle and high school students from communities in northeast Massachusetts and southern New Hampshire. Professional musicians will coach small ensembles in which advanced students from the larger youth orchestra learn the art of chamber music preparation and performance during weekly rehearsals and master classes. The project will culminate with the students performing free public concerts.

To support a concert and related educational programming, with a focus on Northwestern classical composers and musicians. Koichiro Yamamoto, principal trombonist of the Seattle Symphony Orchestra, will perform for the public, as well as participate in Symphony for Students, the Northwest Symphony Orchestra's outreach initiative intended to serve low-income students in South King County. In partnership with the Highline School District, Yamamoto will lead master classes for underserved youth.Youth participants will also receive free tickets to attend the public performance at the Highline Performing Arts Center. The concert will include music composed by Northwest composers Samuel Jones and Sumi Tonooka. The guest composers will give a pre-concert lecture and participate in a question-and-answer session after the performance.

column9: Challenge America: Arts Engagement in American Communities
column12: To support Symphony for Schools and "Carmina Burana," as well as lectures and mini concerts at Top of the World Communities. Orchestra members will present master classes with supporting materials to students in as many as 20 public schools and partner with West Port High School in a joint production of "Carmina Burana."

Purpose: To support the presentation of Emerging Markets concerts, a series of informal musical events. Additional Project Description: Promoted concerts and rehearsals, as well as unexpected pop-up events will take place across the city, in areas such as farmers markets, flea markets, Reading Terminal, Chinatown, and local businesses. Emerging Markets was started to give professional musicians an opportunity to continue performing during the COVID-19 pandemic. The events will offer free and "pay as you wish" admission to provide greater equity for ethnically and socio-economically diverse audiences. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit audiences in Philadelphia. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support a performance touring project. The orchestra will perform a program featuring George Crumb's American Songbooks at historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs) in the southern United States. The seven volumes of American Songbooks are the Pulitzer Prize-winning Crumb's explorations of America's folk song heritage that are based on Appalachian ballads, African-American spirituals, New England hymns, Native American chants, and Western cowboy tunes. Touring to Louisiana and Mississippi, the concerts will feature artists such as soprano Ann Crumb (the composer's daughter) and baritone Randall Scarlata with the orchestra's Artistic Director Jayce Ogren. Project activities will include panel discussions and master classes with orchestra musicians.

To support a performance touring project. The orchestra will present concerts featuring George Crumb's "American Songbooks" to audiences in Arizona and New Mexico. Outreach activities include open rehearsals, pre-concert panels, and "Percussion Petting Zoos."

Purpose: To support an orchestra concert that promotes visibility of Black and Indigenous composers and artists, and related activities. Additional Project Description: The concert will feature a Black and Indigenous chorus and soloists performing Beethoven’s Symphony No. 9 paired with contemporary composer Joel Thompson’s Seven Last Words of the Unarmed. Targeted engagement activities will encourage low-income, Black, and Indigenous members of the community to participate in the arts. Intended Beneficiaries: Programming will focus on serving local Black and Indigenous audiences, artists, and businesses in Cedar Rapids and Iowa City, Iowa. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support Orchestra Iowa's Jazz  Beyond Celebration festival. The week-long festival will include presentations by local jazz artists and ensembles, programs for local high school and college jazz bands, community lectures, panel discussions, and a master class. The festival will conclude with performances featuring saxophonist and NEA Jazz Master Branford Marsalis. The performances will take place at the newly reconstructed Hancher Auditorium in Iowa City and at the Paramount Theatre in Cedar Rapids.

To support new productions of Igor Stravinsky's ballets. Stravinsky works under consideration are "The Rite of Spring," "The Firebird," and "Petrouchka." The productions will feature Orchestra Iowa's music director and professional musicians in a collaborative partnership with Ballet Quad Cities from Rock Island, Illinois.

Purpose: To support instructor and musician fees related to instrumental music education programs for youth. Additional Project Description: Through the Washington Heights  Inwood Music Project and the American Youth Orchestra ensemble, music instructors will provide students with musicianship classes, private lessons, and ensemble experiences. The young musicians will have the opportunity to perform for the public and will have access to free tickets to performances by visiting guest artists. The program is inspired by the El Sistema youth orchestra model that supports the emotional and physical health of children as well as music learning. Programming may be offered virtually as necessary. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will benefit students from underserved communities throughout New York City. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Purpose: To support instructor and musician fees for an instrumental music education program for youth. Additional Project Description: Through the Washington Heights  Inwood Music Project and the American Youth Orchestra ensemble, music instructors will provide musicianship classes, private lessons, and ensemble experiences to students. The young musicians will have the opportunity to perform for the public and will have access to free tickets to performances by visiting guest artists. The program is inspired by the El Sistema youth orchestra model that supports the emotional and physical health of children as well as music learning. Programming may be offered virtually as necessary. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will benefit students from underserved communities throughout New York City. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

To support music instructor fees for an instrumental music education program for youth. Music instructors will provide in-person and/or virtual musicianship classes, private lessons, and ensemble experiences to students from underserved communities throughout New York City. Students will have the opportunity to perform and will have access to free tickets to performances by visiting guest artists. The program is inspired by the El Sistema youth orchestra model that supports the emotional and physical health of children as well as music learning.

column12: Purpose: To support personnel expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organization’s constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Purpose: To support the Resonate Festival, a classical musical festival with concerts and community events. Additional Project Description: The festival will feature performances with clarinetist Anthony McGill, the Orlando Philharmonic Orchestra's 2022-23 Artist-in-Residence. Engagement activities will include the presentation of Anthony McGill at Grand Avenue Neighborhood Center; a workshop for Central Florida high school students; and subsidized tickets for Title I elementary and middle school students and their families to attend the festival. Intended Beneficiaries: The festival will benefit audiences in Orlando, including elementary and middle school students and college students participating in the engagement activities. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support a performance touring project. Additional Project Description: During a national tour, the chamber orchestra will present diverse programming and live performances in states such as Colorado, Florida, Illinois, Indiana, Massachusetts, New Mexico, New York, Pennsylvania, and South Carolina. Orchestra musicians will conduct in-school classroom visits at partner public schools throughout the tour. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve audiences of all ages across the country. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support artists salaries and wages for a performance touring project. Additional Project Description: During a national tour, the chamber orchestra will present diverse programming and live performances in states such as Alabama, Arizona, Kansas, Nebraska, New York, Pennsylvania, Texas, and Virginia. Orchestra musicians will conduct in-school classroom visits at partner public schools throughout the tour. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will engage audiences of all ages across the country. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support musician salaries and guest artist fees for virtual performances and a touring project. During a national tour, the chamber orchestra will present diverse programming in states such as California, Illinois, and New York.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support musician salaries and guest artist fees for a performance touring project. During a national tour, the chamber orchestra will present diverse programming, including a new work by composer and violinist Jessie Montgomery, who will serve as Artistic Partner for the project. Orchestra musicians will conduct in-school classroom visits at partner public schools throughout the tour.

To support musician salaries and guest artist fees for touring performances. During a national tour, the chamber orchestra will present diverse programming and will be joined by guest artists including pianists Nobuyuki Tsujii and Javier Perianes, mandolinist Avi Avital, accordionist Ksenija Sidorova, and cellist Steven Isserlis. Orchestra musicians will conduct in-school classroom visits at partner public schools throughout the tour. The project will engage audiences through live performances in Florida, Illinois, Missouri, New York, North Carolina, and Pennsylvania.

To support musician salaries and guest artist fees for a performance touring project. During a national tour, the chamber orchestra will present diverse programming and be joined by guest artists including pianist Andre Watts, violinist Lisa Batiashvili, cellist Truls Mork, and trumpeter Tine Thing Helseth. Orchestra musicians will conduct in-school classroom visits at partner public schools throughout the tour. The project will engage audiences through live performances in states such as Alabama, Florida, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky and Nebraska.

To support a performance touring project. During a national tour, the chamber orchestra will present diverse programming and be joined by guest artists such as pianist Christian Zacharias, violinist Vadim Gluzman, and cellist Alisa Weilerstein. Orchestra musicians will conduct in-school classroom visits at partner public schools throughout the tour. The project will engage audiences through live performances in states such as California, Florida, Georgia, Massachusetts, New York, Minnesota and Pennsylvania.

To support a performance touring project. The chamber orchestra will present diverse programming during a national tour and will be joined by guest artists such as pianist Khatia Buniatishvili, violinist Augustin Hadelich, cellist Jan Vogler, violinist Mira Wang, and violinist, violist, conductor, and pedagogue Pinchas Zukerman. Orchestra musicians will conduct in-school classroom visits with partner public schools throughout the tour. The project will engage audiences through live performances in states such as California, Florida, Massachusetts, Michigan, New Hampshire, New York, and Pennsylvania.

To support a performance touring project. The chamber orchestra will be joined by guest artists including pianist Jonathan Biss, violinist Jennifer Koh, as well as composer/pianist Fazil Say. Orchestra musicians will conduct in-school classroom visits with partner public schools throughout the year.

To support a performance touring project. The programming for the tour will include guest-artists clarinetist Martin Frost, violinists Christian Tetzlaff and Ryu Goto, Japanese pianist Nobuyuki Tsujii, and jazz pianist Brad Mehldau.

Purpose: To support a chamber music performance project. Additional Project Description: The PSO Off the Record project will engage the community by creating an unintimidating pathway to classical music appreciation and relatability to the art form. The orchestra will perform both new music and familiar chamber classics through this program, and more affordable tickets will be offered to break down barriers to access to classical music performances. Intended Beneficiaries: Performances will serve audiences of all ages in Paducah, Kentucky. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support PSO Off the Record, a chamber music performance and community engagement project. Ensembles of orchestra musicians will perform in local venues such as museums, with "pay-as-you-wish" attendance designed to engage non-traditional audiences by creating an unintimidating pathway to classical music appreciation.

column9: Challenge America: Arts Engagement in American Communities
column12: To support performances in area high schools. The Paducah Symphony Orchestra will perform concerts at public high schools in McCracken County, Kentucky, incorporating each school's ochestra band, and chorus programs.

To support The Latin American Songbook, orchestral concerts of Spanish language songs. Works will feature folkloric music, bolero, tango, zamba, and other categories of music with Latin American origins. The project is intended to serve the Hispanic community residing in Montgomery County, MD. Guest performers include vocalist Carlos Enrique Pena from Guatemala and vocalist Sofia Rei from Argentina.

Purpose: To support musical performances and community engagement activities. Additional Project Description: The Paragon Ragtime Orchestra will conduct performances in pre-1930s historic American theaters across the nation, showcasing works by American composers from the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The works will be presented with narration, rare original early-jazz and ragtime orchestrations, and authentic instrumentation. Related activities will include master classes and coaching of student ensembles by orchestra musicians, as well as lectures by Artistic Director Rick Benjamin. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit general audiences in touring locations nationwide, including students and participating performers. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support musical performances and community engagement activities. Additional Project Description: The Paragon Ragtime Orchestra will conduct as many as four performances in pre-1930s historic American theaters, showcasing works by American composers from the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The works will be presented with narration, rare original early-jazz and ragtime orchestrations, and authentic instrumentation. Related activities will include master classes and coaching of student ensembles by orchestra musicians, as well as lectures by Artistic Director Rick Benjamin. Intended Beneficiaries: Performances and outreach will serve general audiences in central Pennsylvania, including students and performers. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support the Paragon Live performance and outreach project. The Paragon Ragtime Orchestra will conduct performances in pre-1930s historic American theaters showcasing works by American composers from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, presented in a show-style manner with narration, use of rare original early jazz and ragtime orchestrations, and authentic instrumentation. Related activities may include master classes and coaching of student ensembles by orchestra musicians and lectures by Artistic Director Rick Benjamin.

To support the Paragon Live performance and outreach project. The Paragon Ragtime Orchestra will conduct a number of performances showcasing works by American composers from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, presented in a show-style manner with narration, use of rare original orchestrations, and authentic instrumentation, in pre-1930s historic American theaters.

Paragon Live in Historic American Theaters will feature performances of works by American composers from the late 19th and early 20th century, presented in a show-like manner with narration, use of rare original orchestrations, and authentic instrumentation, in pre-1930s historic theaters. Ancillary activities may include master classes and coaching of student ensembles by orchestra musicians; lectures by Artistic Director Rick Benjamin on topics relating to the performances; silent film viewings with live orchestral accompaniment; and performance programs adapted for school audiences with classroom study guides made available to teachers prior to the performances.

Purpose: To support Orchestra of New Spain's production of Apolo y Dafne by composer Sebastian Duron. Additional Project Description: The creative team will include director Federico Figueroa, choreographer Jaime Puente, costume designer Antonio Bartolo, and conductor and artistic director Grover Wilkins. Vocalists for the Spanish Baroque work will be selected by audition. The production will include educational components such as an artist residency and field trips to experience the production, with visuals and video provided to area schools as preparation for the experience. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit diverse Dallas-area audiences, with a focus on serving the Hispanic community. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support performances and professional recording of "Achille In Sciro" by the Orchestra of New Spain. Alluded to in Homer's epic poem "Illiad" and included in other ancient Greek works, composer Francisco Courcelle's opera is an episode in the life of Achilles when he disguised himself as a woman at the court of the King of Skyros, fell in love with a princess, and married her before leaving for Troy to become a Greek hero of the Trojan War.

To support a new production of "Iphigenia en Tracia" by composer Jose de Nebra and librettist Nicolas Gonzalez Martinez. The Orchestra of New Spain's creative team may include set designer Nicolas Boni, costume designer Antonio Bartolo, stage director Gustavo Tambascio, and Joseph Jones who will create the English translation. The opera will be sung in Spanish with English supertitles. An integral part of the company's outreach is to the local Hispanic community.

To support the Peoria Symphony Orchestra's Student Concerts, an American composition-themed performance series, featuring the music of Aaron Copland, Leonard Bernstein, and guest artist Bela Fleck. The concerts, intended to serve economically disadvantaged students, will also include performances by young regional artists.

Purpose: To support the Philadelphia Orchestra's collaborative neighborhood concerts and community music-making programs. Additional Project Description: Through its community engagement project, the orchestra will perform free neighborhood concerts; free Our City, Your Orchestra collaborative community programs, including the annual Martin Luther King, Jr. Tribute Concert; and several neighborhood residencies in partnership with diverse businesses, schools, and community organizations. Programming will include live and virtual activities. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve people of all ages from diverse communities in the greater Philadelphia area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the Philadelphia Orchestra's free neighborhood concerts and PlayINs. Additional Project Description: Through its community engagement project, the orchestra will perform two free neighborhood concerts. Orchestra musicians will lead community PlayINs for amateur musicians of all ages and skill levels. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve people of all ages from diverse communities in the greater Philadelphia area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the Philadelphia Orchestra's free neighborhood concerts, PlayINs, and community residencies. Orchestra musicians will lead community PlayINs for amateur musicians of all ages and skill levels and will curate several collaborative neighborhood residencies that will be presented online for free.

To support The Philadelphia Orchestra's free neighborhood concerts, PlayINs, and community residencies. Through its Engaging Philadelphians in Playing, Exploring, and Enjoying Orchestral Music project, the orchestra will perform free neighborhood concerts, including the orchestra's annual Martin Luther King, Jr. Tribute Concert and a surprise "Pop-up" concert. Orchestra musicians will lead community PlayINs for amateur musicians of all ages and skill levels, and will curate several collaborative neighborhood residencies.

To support education and outreach programs including free neighborhood concerts, community residencies, and PlayINs. The orchestra, conducted by Music Director Yannick Nezet-Seguin, will perform free neighborhood concerts including the orchestra's annual Martin Luther King, Jr., Tribute Concert and a surprise "Pop-up" concert. In addition, orchestra musicians will lead community PlayINs for amateur musicians of all ages and skill levels. Collaborative neighborhood residencies will be curated in partnership with community organizations in sections of Philadelphia where residents are underrepresented in the concert hall.

To support a music therapy program for Philadelphia's homeless population in partnership with Broad Street Ministry. Broad Street Ministry provides a wide array of services for Philadelphia's chronically homeless, many of whom suffer from mental illnesses. Orchestra musicians and music therapists collaboratively will provide weekly music therapy for the ministry's guests, to increase hope, self-expression, and coping skills. Temple University's Arts and Quality of Life Research Center will provide the music therapists, training for the musicians, and project evaluation.

Broad Street Ministry provides a wide array of services for Philadelphia's chronically homeless, many of whom suffer from mental illnesses. Orchestra musicians and music therapists collaboratively will provide weekly music therapy for the ministry's guests, to increase hope, self-expression, and coping skills. Temple University's Arts and Quality of Life Research Center will provide the music therapists, training for the musicians, and project evaluation.

To support the Philadelphia Orchestra's Free Neighborhood Concerts and a community composer residency program. Through its Engaging Diverse Communities and Musicians project, the orchestra will perform free neighborhood concerts including the orchestra's annual Martin Luther King, Jr., Tribute Concert and a surprise "Pop-up" concert. Also planned is a composer residency by Hannibal Lokumbe and the Philadelphia Orchestra String Quartet titled "Healing Tones."

To support The Philadelphia Orchestra's Free Neighborhood Concerts and PlayINs. Through its Engaging Diverse Communities and Musicians project, the orchestra will perform free neighborhood concerts, including the orchestra's annual Martin Luther King, Jr. Tribute Concert, and conduct ancillary activities in several Philadelphia locations. Programming will be conducted by Music Director Yannick Nezet-Seguin and Associate Conductor Cristian Macelaru. In addition, an interactive initiative called PlayINs for musicians of all ages and all skill levels will be offered for specific instruments.

To support Free Neighborhood Concerts and PlayINs. The orchestra will perform free concerts and conduct ancillary activities in several Philadelphia locations, such as the Great Plaza on Penn's Landing, reaching underserved audiences. Programming will be conducted by Music Director Yannick Nezet-Seguin and Associate Conductor Cristian Macelaru. In addition, an interactive initiative called PlayINs for musicians of all ages and all skill levels will be offered for specific instruments. Piloted in 2012, the first PlayIN engaged 200 community cello players at the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts. Since the inaugural event, the orchestra has conducted PlayINs for violin, woodwinds, harp, brass, and double bass.

To support Free Neighborhood Concerts. The orchestra will perform free concerts and conduct ancillary activities in several Philadelphia locations, including the Great Plaza on Penn's Landing, reaching underserved audiences. Programming will be conducted by Music Director Yannick Nezet-Seguin and Associate Conductor Cristian Macelaru.

To support Neighborhood Concerts. The orchestra will perform free concerts and conduct ancillary activities in several Philadelphia locations, including the Great Plaza on Penn's Landing and Martin Luther King Jr. High School, reaching underserved audiences.

Purpose: To support staff salaries and teaching artist fees for a free, after-school instrumental music education program for youth. Additional Project Description: Teaching artists will provide free music instruction to students in schools and community centers across Philadelphia. On Saturdays, students from all the sites will have the opportunity to experience playing in a large ensemble together. Students and their parents also will have the opportunity to attend free professional symphony concerts. The program is inspired by the El Sistema youth orchestra model that supports the emotional and physical health of children as well as music learning. Intended Beneficiaries: Students from low-income neighborhoods in the Philadelphia area will benefit from the program. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Purpose: To support staff salaries and teaching artist fees related to an after-school instrumental music education program for underserved students in elementary, middle, and high school. Additional Project Description: Teaching artists will provide free music instruction to students in schools and community centers. On Saturdays, students from all the sites may meet to experience playing in a large ensemble together. Students will have the opportunity to perform in the community, as well as attend free professional concerts. The program is inspired by the El Sistema youth orchestra model that supports the emotional and physical health of children as well as music learning. Intended Beneficiaries: Students from low-income neighborhoods in the Philadelphia area will benefit from the program. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Purpose: To support performances of works by George Frideric Handel, Heinrich Ignaz Franz Biber, and Mason Bates. Additional Project Description: The Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra and Chorale will perform works by George Frideric Handel, Heinrich Ignaz Franz Biber, and Mason Bates in partnership with Newport Classical. This performance will take place at The Breakers in Newport, RI, one of the festival’s summer performance venues. Conducted by PBO Music Director Richard Egarr, this concert will feature the premiere of Mason Bates’ Appalachian Ayre. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve audiences in the Newport, RI area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support performances of the rarely-performed Handel opera Amadigi di Gaula, in a new co-production with Boston Baroque. Additional Project Description: The work will be directed by German/American stage director Louisa Muller and star Anthony Roth Costanzo in the title role alongside a diverse cast of American opera stars Intended Beneficiaries: San Francisco Bay Area audience members and public school students will benefit from the performances and education programs. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support performances of Aci, Galatea, e Polifemo by George Frideric Handel, with re-imagined recitatives by composer and sound designer Mark Grey. Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra will collaborate with nonprofit musical producer National Sawdust to present a modern interpretation of the Baroque work. Performances will take place during winter 2020.

To support a music performance project. Titled "Corelli The Godfather," the project will feature guest conductor and keyboard artist Richard Egarr. Programming will include works by Arcangelo Corelli, George Frederic Handel, and Gottlieb Muffat, and will explore Corelli's influence on Handel's compositions. The orchestra and chorus will join Egarr in performances of works such as Handel's organ concerti and Corelli's "Concerto Grosso Opus 6, No. 10 in C Major." Performances will be held in several venues of the Bay Area.

To support performances of "Le Temple de la Gloire" by composer John-Philippe Rameau with a libretto by Voltaire. Premiered as a five-act opera-ballet at Versailles to celebrate the French victory of the Battle of Fontenoy, the work was subsequently revised to a three-act opera. The performances-of the original version that has not been performed since the premiere in 1745-will mark the company's first fully staged opera and will include a full orchestra, chorale, six principal singers, and eight baroque dancers. Organizational partners Cal Performances and Centre de Musique Baroque de Versailles (Versailles, France) will help develop a series of lectures and excerpted performances for University of California at Berkeley students.

To support period-instrument performances of an All Mozart concert program. Under the direction of Music Director Nicholas McGegan, the project will feature guest artist keyboardist Kristian Bezuidenhout, who will perform on the pianoforte. Programming will include such works by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart as Concerto for Fortepiano no. 23 in A major, Symphony No. 27 in G major, and Symphony No. 39 in E-flat major. The project will celebrate Nicholas McGegan's 30th anniversary as music director of the orchestra.

To support period-instrument performances of Gioachino Antonio Rossini's "La cambiale di matrimonio (The Marriage Contract)." Under the direction of Music Director Nicholas McGegan, the project will feature tenor Brian Thorsett and soloists from San Francisco Opera's Adler Fellowship Program in the orchestra's first collaborative effort with the opera company, with staging by stage director Ted Huffman. Performances of Rossini's first professional one-act opera will be presented in concert venues in Berkeley, Palo Alto, and San Francisco, with pre-concert lectures for the Bay Area events.

To support performances of Antonio Vivaldi's oratorio "Juditha Triumphans." Under the direction of Music Director Nicholas McGegan, the project will include guest artists soprano Dominique Labelle and mezzo-sopranos Vivica Genaux, Diana Moore, Cecile van de Sant, and Virginia Warnken, as well as the Philharmonia Baroque Chorale.

To support the concert presentation of Handel's opera "Teseo." Under the direction of music director Nicholas McGegan, the project will include guest artists sopranos Dominique Labelle, Amanda Forsythe, Amy Freston, and Celine Ricci, and countertenors Robin Blaze and Drew Minter.

Purpose: To support the expansion of the Paul J. Ross Fellowship Program. Additional Project Description: With a focus on emerging Black musicians, the program provides talented pre-professional musicians with an immersive learning experience and training to prepare them for careers as professional orchestral musicians. Fellowship activities include performance opportunities, master classes, and audition support. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit the participating fellows, musicians, audiences in the Pittsburgh area, and the orchestra field nationwide. Intended Outcome: Arts leaders develop professional skills and strategies.

To support a commissioning and performance project celebrating the orchestra's 125th anniversary. Programming under the direction of Music Director Manfred Honeck will feature new works by composers such as Mason Bates, Kathryn Bostic, Michael Daugherty, and commissioned composers Stacy Garrop, James MacMillan, and Gloria Isabel Ramos Triano. Performances will be presented at Heinz Hall.

To support a series of performances celebrating the 125th anniversary of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra. Programming directed by Music Director Manfred Honeck will celebrate both the orchestra's anniversary and the 250th anniversary of Ludwig van Beethoven's birth. The orchestra will perform of all sixteen Beethoven string quartets in Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh branches and offer free performances of seven Beethoven symphonies throughout the city.

To support a commissioning and performance project celebrating Music Director Manfred Honeck's tenth anniversary season. The project will feature works by the orchestra's former Composers of the Year, such as Jennifer Higdon, Steven Stucky and Reza Vali. Jennifer Higdon will be commissioned to write a new concerto for tuba which will be premiered by the orchestra with guest conductor Atlanta Symphony Orchestra's Music Director Robert Spano. Performances will be presented at Heinz Hall.

To support a commissioning and performance project celebrating contemporary composers who are also performers. Titled Return of the Composer Performer, the project will feature performances of a new work by composer/percussionist Stewart Copeland (former drummer of The Police), as well as a transription of Rachmaninoff's "Rhapsody on a Theme by Paganini" by composer/organist Cameron Carpenter. The composers will be the featured soloists with the orchestra, conducted by Music Director Manfred Honeck and guest conductor Marcel Lehninger, at Heinz Hall, and will participate in community engagement activities as part of the residency with the orchestra.

To support a commissioning and performance project of new orchestral works. The commissioned score is the required product. The orchestra will perform world premiere performances of a commissioned work by composer Jake Heggie written specifically for principal cellist Anne Martindale Williams and a previously commissioned work by composer Alan Fletcher for principal oboist Cynthia Koledo DeAlmeida. In addition, the project will feature American composer Mason Bates, in residence at the orchestra, performing three of his works.

To support a digital archive portal. The portal includes a fully searchable performance history directory with hundreds of digitally preserved performance recordings, numerous oral history interviews, and records from the Pittsburgh Symphony's 118-year history. Content and project developments related to the Archives Portal will be featured on Pittsburgh Symphony Radio. The project will also incorporate educational activities through established Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra programs.

To support the Composer of the Year Residency Program. The project, titled the Year of the Pittsburgh Composer, will be directed by Music Director Manfred Honeck and will include world premieres and commissions. Featured composers include Richard Danielpour, Christopher Rouse, David Stock, Nancy Galbraith, Patrick Burke, Bomi Jang, Mathew Rosenblum, Reza Vali, and Amy Williams.

To support the Composer of the Year project, an artist residency with composer Mason Bates. The orchestra will perform the composer's The B-Sides with principal guest conductor Leonard Slatkin and Desert Transport, a work inspired by a helicopter flight over the Arizona landscape, to be conducted by Juanjo Mena.

column9: Challenge America: Arts Engagement in American Communities
column12: Purpose: To support a mariachi performance in Plano, Texas. Additional Project Description: The Plano Symphony Orchestra (PSO) will feature international guest artists Mariachi Vargas de Tecalitlán for a one-night performance. Part of an effort to expand representation, PSO aims to highlight Mexican culture and history through the performance and community outreach activities. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit the community of Plano, Texas, with a focus on the Latino population. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support an education and community engagement project. The orchestra's EncoreYouth comprehensive education programs will expand their reach with free and low-cost events and curriculum for underserved children and families of North Texas. Activities will include school concerts, instrument instruction, instrument petting-zoos, young artist competitions, and music therapy for youth in the Collin County Juvenile Detention Center.

To support the School Concert Education Program, a music education and engagement program. Students throughout the region will benefit from concerts and a classroom presentation toolkit with music audio clips. Orchestra musicians also will visit students prior to performances and distribute concert programs. Students will experience live performances by the orchestra with Music Director Hector Guzman at the Charles W. Eisemann Performing Arts Center in Richardson, Texas.

To support an educational outreach program. The orchestra's School Concert Education Program will engage and educate students throughout the region through concerts and a classroom presentation toolkit with music audio clips. Orchestra musicians also will visit students prior to performances and distribute concert programs. Students will experience live performances by the orchestra with Music Director Hector Guzman at the Charles W. Eisemann Performing Arts Center in Richardson, Texas.

To support New Music for America, a national commissioning and performance consortium project. Featuring a new work by American composer Christopher Theofanidis, at least one small-budget orchestra from each of the 50 states will perform the new work at least once. The project will build on the success of two previous Ford Made in America projects which provided services and resources to orchestras with smaller operating budgets.

Purpose: To support a performance project by the Portland Symphony Orchestra with related outreach activities. Additional Project Description: The orchestra will perform Giuseppe Verdi's Requiem with Portland's ChoralArt choir to commemorate the 80th anniversary of the first performances of the work at the Terezin concentration camp during the Holocaust. The project will include a residency featuring the Violins of Hope collection curated by Amnon Weinstein, and related live and online community events. Performances at Merrill Auditorium will be accompanied by outreach activities such as a museum exhibition and events at the Maine Jewish Museum, radio broadcasts, online concert presentations, and educational programs at public schools in the area. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will engage audiences in the greater Portland, Maine, metropolitan area, including area public school and college students. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support a performance project celebrating Music Director Robert Moody's decade-long tenure with the orchestra. Programming will feature the New England premiere performances of new works by American composer Mason Bates, including works for chorus and orchestra. An elite choir bringing singers together from around the country will perform works such as Leonard Bernstein's Symphony No. 1 Jeremiah," Karl Jenkins's The Armed Man," and Bates's "The Book of Matthew," a shorter work for choir and organ.

To support "Nine for Ninety: Beethoven and His Infinite Inspiration," a performance project celebrating the orchestra's 90th anniversary season. Under the artistic leadership of Music Director Robert Moody, the orchestra, will perform three of the nine Beethoven symphonies. Programming will include a new work written by a young composer selected through a national juried competition.

To support "Tune Up Maine," a statewide performance and community outreach tour. The orchestra, with Music Director Robert Moody, will celebrate its 90th anniversary by presenting free community concerts throughout Maine.

Purpose: To support a new production of Rossini's Barber of Seville. Additional Project Description: Performances will be presented during the orchestra's annual summer festival. The creative team will include stage director James Marvel, scenic designer Blair Mielnik, and conductor Rossen Milanov. The production will be set in Seville, Spain but will feature Cubist imagery in the set designs by Mielnik. As many as three outdoor performances will be presented at the grounds of Morven Museum  Garden in downtown Princeton. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will engage diverse audiences in the Princeton, New Jersey, area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support an artist residency and community engagement project. The PSO will host a free community event featuring author Sandra Cisneros and composer Derek Bermel. Cisneros will discuss her experiences growing up amidst two cultures and how those experiences informed her book The House on Mango Street. The discussion will be augmented by performances of excerpts from Bermel's Mango Suite, which was inspired by Cisneros' book. Composer Derek Bermel will also participate in songwriting workshops in local schools. Project partners will include Princeton Public Schools, Trenton Public Schools, and the Mercer County Cultural and Heritage Commission, among others. Performances will take place at Richardson Auditorium in Princeton.

To support a performance and community engagement project celebrating the 35th anniversary of the Princeton Symphony Orchestra. The orchestra, under the artistic direction of Rossen Milanov, will perform the Passion and Affection concert program featuring a new work by Princeton-based composer Sarah Kirkland Snider. The composer, whose first orchestra teacher and conductor was Portia Sonnenfeld, Princeton Symphony Orchestra's founding artistic director, will create a work that represents the creativity of women and will be a meditation on home, family, heritage, and identity. The project will include a series of community engagement events, such as a chamber music concert, lectures, and workshops designed to introduce the music and inspirations behind Snider's composition.

To support Freedom to Move: The Migration Series Project. In commemoration of the 150th anniversary of the Emancipation Proclamation, the musical work will feature performances of composer Derek Bermel's "The Migration Series," a concerto for jazz band and orchestra inspired by the late visual artist Jacob Lawrence's 60-painting-sequence by the same name.

column7: ProMusica Chamber Orchestra of Columbus, Inc.
column12: To support the commissioning and performance of a new work for violin and chamber orchestra by composer David Fulmer. The premiere will feature guest artist Stefan Jackiw in performance with the orchestra at the historic Southern Theatre in Columbus.

column7: ProMusica Chamber Orchestra of Columbus, Inc.
column12: To support the commissioning and performance of a new work for chamber orchestra and cello by composer Aaron Jay Kernis, including educational outreach activity. Featuring cellist Joshua Roman and music director Dr. Timothy Russell, the project will include open rehearsals for older adults, post-concert discussions with the composer, and a master class for local conservatory students.

To support Karkinos, a commissioning and performance project featuring a new oratorio by composer Jacob Bancks. The work will explore cancer and its impact on individuals and those closest to them. It will be scored for chorus and small chamber orchestra. Activities will include creating art for stage production and exhibition in partnership with Living Proof Exhibit, a visual arts organization that provides the therapeutic benefit of the arts to people affected by cancer.

To support a performance and educational programming by the Kaia String Quartet. Prior to their public performance, the Kaia String Quartet will present music workshops at Lincoln-Irving Elementary, a bilingual school in the Floreciente neighborhood of Moline, Illinois. The public performance will take place at the Boys and Girls Club of the Mississippi Valley in Moline. The concert will be part of a series focused on work by Latino composers that is intended to help expand the diversity of the orchestra’s audience.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

column12: To support an artist residency. Hornist Jeremiah Frederick will perform in concert as a guest artist with the Racine Symphony Orchestra, engaging in a pre-concert conversation with audience members. Frederick also will travel to schools in the Racine Unified School District and local senior living facilities to conduct mini-concerts and provide other age-appropriate programming. These site visits will bring live music performances to populations that otherwise would not have the ability to attend them.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support an artist residency project featuring performances and community engagement activities. The Sweet Plantain Quartet will join the Reading Symphony Orchestra in celebrating National Hispanic Heritage Month. The quartet will conduct in-school educational visits with students of the Reading School District. In addition, the quartet will perform at local universities and other venues.

Purpose: To support a performance project with Music Director Ransom Wilson. Additional Project Description: The concert program, titled "National Pride," will include works such as "Overture No.2 for Orchestra in E-flat Major," by Louise Farrenc, "Wood Notes" by William Grant Still, and Symphony No. 2 in D Major, Opus 43 by Jean Sibelius. The performance will be held at Memorial Chapel at the University of Redlands. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve artists and audiences of all ages in the Redlands, California, area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support the commission of a new work by composer Liliya Ugay. Titled From Shore to Shore, the work for orchestra and voice will explore the immigrant experience in America. Project activities will also include the development of a media plan to promote the commission's premiere and planning for related community engagement events such as a master class with the composer and an educational program with middle and high school students.

Purpose: To support a commissioning and performance project featuring a new work by composer William Bolcom. Additional Project Description: The chamber orchestra, with conductor Delyana Lazarova, will perform the new work at the Church of St. John the Divine. The performance will be offered for both in-person and livestream audiences. Intended Beneficiaries: Audiences of all ages will be served by the project. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support a composer residency project with Derek Bermel. The project will include the commissioning of three new works by the composer, one for chamber orchestra, one for chamber ensemble, and one for solo instrument. The premiere of the work for chamber orchestra will be conducted by Music Director Shiyeon Sung at the Church of St. John the Divine.

Purpose: To support artist fees for a care and wellness initiative. Additional Project Description: The initiative offers open rehearsals, individual musician and ensemble visits, a sensory-friendly concert, and other tailored programming for individuals in nursing homes, hospitals, schools, and other community organizations. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit children and adults, including those with disabilities, and their families. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries experience advances in their health and well-being.

To support in-person musical experiences for those with autism, cognitive delays, physical disabilities, or rare genetic syndromes. The project will feature four ensemble visits, one for each instrument family, through a partnership with Mary Cariola Children's Center.

To support artists fees and production costs for performances celebrating Susan B. Anthony and the 19th amendment. The orchestra will mark the event with multi-week programming highlighting Rochester's famous resident and her contribution to women's rights. This project honors the Women's Suffrage Centennial.

To support a music education and engagement project for young people. Orchestral repertoire, conducted by the Principal Conductor for Education and Community Engagement Michael Butterman, will range from works by Johann Sebastian Bach and Ludwig van Beethoven to John Williams and Maurice Ravel. Age-appropriate teaching guides will be available on the orchestra's website for teachers and will include lesson plans, vocabulary lists, suggested activities, and links to YouTube videos of the upcoming programming. The project will teach children basic music terms, listening skills, and instruments of the orchestra. The orchestra's music education programs for youth will reach more than 16,000 students through Tiny Tots Concerts for preschoolers and kindergarteners; Primary Concerts for students in grades 1-3 in Kodak Hall at the Eastman Theatre; and Intermediate Concerts for students in grades 4-6, also in Kodak Hall.

To support concert performances of Howard Hanson's opera "Merry Mount" in Rochester and as part of the Spring for Music festival at Carnegie Hall in New York. Directed by Guest Conductor Michael Christie, performances of the work by Nebraska-born Hanson, director of the Eastman School of Music for 40 years, will feature vocalists from the school. Commissioned by the Metropolitan Opera, the the opera is loosely based on the Nathaniel Hawthorne story "The Maypole of Merry Mount" with a libretto by Richard L. Stokes.

To support the commissioning and premieres of new works by Douglas Lowry and Karen Tanaka. The project will include a composer residency by Tanaka and workshops with high school and college-level composers, as well as with musicians of the Rochester Philharmonic Youth Orchestra and the Eastman School of Music.

To support Leonard Bernstein at 100, a music festival celebrating the centenary of American composer Leonard Bernstein. Programming will include the composer's orchestral, choral, chamber, vocal, opera, and musical theater works. Archival recordings of Bernstein's Young People's Concerts, Harvard lectures, and documentaries may be presented with the collaboration of the Leonard Bernstein Center. Among the works that will be performed will be "On the Town," "Serenade" with the Rockford Dance Company, and concert music performed by the Rockford Wind Ensemble.

To support a performance and community engagement project. The orchestra will pair professional Mariachi performers with orchestra musicians to provide free virtual matinee concerts for students. The project will also include online master classes for youth and an afternoon concert for the public as part of an annual city-wide Cinco de Mayo festival.

Purpose: To support travel costs and artist fees for the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra's performances of new and recent works by American composers. Additional Project Description: The St. Louis Symphony Orchestra will perform as many as five recent works by American composers as part of its classical concert series. Featured works will include the world premieres of two commissions—Concerto for Orchestra by Kevin Puts and Visions of Cahokia by James Lee III—and the St. Louis premieres of Wynton Marsalis' Violin Concerto, Mason Bates' Anthology of Fantastic Zoology, and Gabriela Lena Frank's composition Apu. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit in-person and radio broadcast audiences. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support planning, rehearsal and promotion costs for a performance project featuring a new orchestral work by composer Nathalie Joachim, commissioned by the Saint Louis Symphony Orchestra in collaboration with its resident IN UNISON Chorus. Additional Project Description: The Grammy Award-nominated composer's symphonic and choral work will be based on oral histories collected through conversations with members of the IN UNISON Chorus. Established in 1992, the 120-member, all-volunteer auditioned ensemble performs a wide range of repertoire, with a focus on the interpretation, performance, and preservation of the music of African-American and African cultures. Intended Beneficiaries: Participating artists will be served by the project. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support personnel costs associated with the performance of Maurice Ravel: A Musical Journey, a symphonic play by playwright and stage director Didi Balle. Cancellation of the performance per COVID-19.
