To support performances celebrating American conductor Leonard Slatkin. The project will salute the 50th anniversary of Slatkin's debut with the SLSO Conductor Laureate's return to the podium in Powell Hall. Programming will juxtapose works associated with his tenure in St. Louis and new music by American composers, such as Loren Loiacono's Smothered by Sky, and Leonard Bernstein's Kaddish Symphony. Also included will be the world premiere of a new song cycle by Emmy Award-winning composer Jeff Beal which was commissioned by the orchestra as a tribute to Slatkin. The performance will feature Grammy Award-winning soprano Hila Plitmann. Project activities will include pre-concert conversations and related community engagement, including a rehearsal with the Saint Louis Symphony Youth Orchestra which Slatkin founded in 1970.

To support a concert series celebrating the 50th anniversary of Powell Hall. The iconic American concert hall opened in 1968 and has showcased new music works ever since. Programming will feature works including Thomas Ades' "Powder Her Face" Suite, Guillaume Connesson's "Flammenschrift," and Peter Ruzicka's "Elegie: Remembrance for Orchestra" (U.S. premiere). The repertoire also will include "Swing Symphony" by composer and trumpeter Wynton Marsalis, who will perform the work with the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra. Performances will be augmented by pre-concert lectures and related community engagement activities.

To support performances of "The Gospel According to the Other Mary" by composer and NEA Opera Honoree John Adams with a libretto by Peter Sellars. The work for soloists, chorus, and orchestra tells the story of Christ's last days from the perspective of three people closely attached to him: Mary Magdalene, her sister Martha, and their brother Lazarus. The libretto draws from Biblical texts, as well as stories of social injustice in modern America from works by Dorothy Day, Rosario Castellanos, June Jordan, Louise Erdrich, and Primo Levi. The creative team includes Pulitzer Prize-winning composer John Adams, conductor David Robertson, mezzo-sopranos Kelley O'Connor and Michaela Martens, tenor Jay Hunter Morris, and counter-tenors Daniel Bubeck, Brian Cummings, and Nathan Medley. Performances will take place at Powell Hall in St. Louis and at Carnegie Hall in New York City.

To support Messiaenic Landscapes, an "Imagine Your Parks" project. French composer Olivier Messiaen's "Des canyons aux etoiles... (From the canyons to the stars...)" will be paired with visual imagery by photographer Deborah O'Grady. Programming will explore the relationship between art and nature, incorporating images of the National Parks that inspired the composer: Cedar Breaks, Zion, and Bryce Canyon, among others. Concerts, under the direction of Music Director David Robertson, will be presented in St. Louis and as part of the orchestra's California tour.

To support a performance project featuring concert performances of Giuseppe Verdi's opera "Aida" with audiovisual enhancement. The project, under the direction of Music Director David Robertson, will feature guest artists such as soprano Lucrezia Garcia, mezzo-soprano Ekaterina Semenchuk, and tenor Antonello Palombi. Performances will engage audiences in an immersive concert experience at Powell Hall through a collaboration with visual artist S. Katy Tucker, who will create a series of multi-sensory video and light productions to supplement the music and story line of the opera and give concertgoers a 3D environment. Each concert will be preceded by conversations led by Robertson.

To support Beethoven Reloaded: The Brett Dean Project, a performance project juxtaposing the works of Beethoven and Australian composer and violist Brett Dean. Among the featured works will be Dean's "Testament" for 12 violas (inspired by Beethoven's Heiligenstadt Testament) and his Viola Concerto, both performances featuring Dean in performance with the orchestra, and Beethoven's Symphony No. 3 ("Eroica").

To support the "Peter Grimes Project: A Celebration of the Genius of Benjamin Britten" in St. Louis and at Carnegie Hall in New York. The project, a celebration of the composer's 100th birthday anniversary, will feature concert performances of Britten's opera with the 130-member St. Louis Symphony Chorus, performances of Britten's solo instrumental works, and educational activities for children and young adults.

Purpose: To support a series of programs highlighting the contributions of women in the field of classical music. Additional Project Description: Orchestra musicians Eunae Koh, Maureen Nelson, and Tabea Zimmerman will curate the series, which will feature the historic and contemporary works of women composers. Performances will take place throughout the Twin Cities region, and will include works by Valborg Aulin, Louise Farrenc, Fanny Mendelssohn-Hensel, Clara Schumann, and Hilary Tann. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit artists and audiences in the greater Minneapolis/St. Paul area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support workshops and performances of Johann Sebastian Bach’s Goldberg Variations. Additional Project Description: James Ferree arranged this piece specifically for the Saint Paul Chamber Orchestra, and project activity will include workshopping, rehearsing, and sharing performances with the community. One performance will be livestreamed. Intended Beneficiaries: Performances at the Ordway Concert Hall and related project activities will serve diverse Minneapolis/St. Paul audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

column12: Purpose: To support personnel expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organization’s constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support the Northside Celebration. The project will feature two performances at North High School in Minneapolis and one at the Ordway Concert Hall in Saint Paul. The Celebration will include a specially-formed community choir, youth choir, spoken word artists and SPCO musicians.

To support Tapestry19, a festival celebrating life stories through music, including performances of new orchestral works. The festival will explore the concept of "home" through music composed and performed by artists of diverse backgrounds. The three-week festival will be curated by the orchestra's Music Alive Composer-in-Residence Lembit Beecher. Programming will include premiere performances of new works such as a previously commissioned collaboration by Minneapolis-based Bharatanatyam dancer and choreographer Ashwini Ramaswamy and composer, DJ, and author Jace Clayton; A Requiem for Zula by composer and interdisciplinary artist PaviElle French in a tribute to his mother, who grew up in St. Paul's historically African-American Rondo neighborhood; a new work by composer and clarinetist Kinan Azmeh which will expand on his previous work Do Not Repeat After Me about the collective memories of growing up in Syria in the 1980s; and a new work by Beecher inspired by the poetry of Chris Santiago, the son of Filipino immigrants. The artists will participate in interviews, community engagement, and educational activities through the orchestra's music education program in elementary schools.

To support a festival celebrating life stories through music. The No Fiction Festival will examine relationships between people and their communities. The two-week festival, comprising concerts, education, and community engagement events, will feature the performance of a new work titled "Fanm d'Ayiti" (Women of Haiti) for flute, vocals, and electronics with string quartet by flutist and composer Nathalie Joachim through which the Brooklyn-born artist will examine her Haitian heritage. Programming will include chamber music concerts exploring the theme of sisterhood through chamber works by women composers from the 12th-century German mystic, visionary, and composer Hildegard von Bingen to the 21st-century New Zealand composer of Maori heritage, Dame Gillian Whitehead. Concert programs will include works by sisters Nadia and Lili Boulanger, and Jessie Montgomery. On the theme of place, the composer, sound artist, and writer Brian Harnetty will present "Shawnee, Ohio," a musical work with sampled sound archives, video, and field recordings about the history and ecology of Appalachian Ohio.

To support a festival celebrating the music of Nordic roots. The project, titled Where Words End (inspired by the Finnish composer Jean Sibelius's quote "For me, music begins where words end"), will focus on the themes of immigration and cultural identity and will feature Pekka Kuusisto, a group of artists from Iceland's Bedroom Community including Mariam Wallentin (a Swedish vocalist with Middle Eastern roots), as well as composer and performer Gabriel Kahane and conductor Eric Jacobsen. The three-week festival will feature concerts in new 1,100-seat concert hall at Ordway Center for the Performing Arts, as well as in a range of neighborhood venues throughout the metropolitan area of the Twin Cities.

To support artist fees and travel costs for a performance project of contemporary musical works. Titled "Edgy Collaborators Lead SPCO into the Future", the project will feature performances of chamber works by composers such as Nico Muhly and Erkki-sven Tuur. The concert program will feature two new SPCO Artistic Partners: Finnish violinist and concertmaster Pekka Kuusisto and Moldovan violinist Patricia Kopatchinskaja, and will be presented in the new, intimate, 1,100-seat Concert Hall at Ordway Center for the Performing Arts. Community engagement activities will include a free club2030 event with the guest artists, as well as pre-concert lectures.

To support a performance project featuring Ludwig van Beethoven's symphonies. Programming will feature the composer's Symphonies #2, #4, and #9 with conductors Steve Copes and Andrew Manze, culminating a three-year Beethoven Festival of his complete symphony cycle. Works by composers such as John Adams, Peter Lieberson, Felix Mendelssohn, Sergei Prokofiev, and Igor Stravinsky will be juxtaposed with Beethoven's works. The project will celebrate the orchestra's 30-year history of performing at the 1,900-seat Music Theater at the Ordway Center for the Performing Arts before it moves into a new and more intimate 1,100-seat concert hall at the Ordway.

To support the Benjamin Britten Centenary Celebration, a performance project of the composer's works. Programming will include Britten's "Simple Symphony, Op.4," "Variations on a Theme of Frank Bridge," and chamber opera "The Turn of the Screw," as well as Arvo Part's "Cantus in Memoriam Benjamin Britten."
To support the Living Composers Project. The program will feature premiere performances of a new work by composer Matthias Pintscher, as well as works by John Adams and George Crumb.

Purpose: To support an orchestral performance project. Additional Project Description: The concert program will highlight symphonic works by women composers of color such as Florence Price, Zenobia Powell Perry, Renee Baker, Margaret Bonds, and Chanda Dancy. Guest artists, such as soprano Lettrice Lawrence and the San Bernardino Ballet Ensemble, will join Music Director and Conductor Anthony Parnther and the orchestra at the California Theatre of the Performing Arts in downtown San Bernardino. Intended Beneficiaries: Audiences of all ages will be served by the project. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the Music for All Ages concert with youth orchestra Symphonie Jeunesse and associated activities. In partnership with the local school district, visual artist Michal Madison will work with students to create original pieces of art based upon the students' interpretations of the music to be performed. The students' artwork and poetry will be projected overhead at the concert and participating students and their families will receive free admission.

To support a concert of orchestrated traditional Latin American music. The Mosaico Music Festival programming will be selected by Music Director and Conductor Frank Fetta and the concert will be conducted by guest artist Mateo Oliva.

To support "Classics Revisited," featuring violinist Lindsay Deutsch, with associated outreach activities. As many as 350 San Bernardino-area youth and their families will be invited to attend the concert at no charge and complimentary tickets will be given to 50 San Bernardino City Unified School District Honors Orchestra students and their parents.

Purpose: To support artist fees and travel costs for a performance project featuring Cantata Criolla by Antonio Estevez and conducted by Rafael Payare. Additional Project Description: The piece, which is scored for orchestra, chorus, and two soloists, will tell the story of a singing contest between the forces of good and evil. The multimedia outdoor production will feature video projections designed by Alberto Arvelo. Supplementary materials about the history and context of the work will be provided to audience members in English and Spanish. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit artists and audiences in San Diego. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support an online chamber orchestra festival. Curated by percussionist and conductor Steven Schick, the virtual "To the Earth" festival will celebrate the region's natural environment and will highlight works by composer-in-residence John Luther Adams. Additional repertoire will include works by composers such as Tan Dun.

To support a co-commissioning and performance project of a new trumpet concerto by saxophonist, clarinetist, composer, and NEA Jazz Master Paquito D'Rivera. The orchestra will perform the U.S. premiere performance of the new work with Music Director Rafael Payare and Venezuelan trumpeter Pacho Flores. The work will be the result of a co-commissioning effort with Orquesta de Minería (Mexico), Orquesta de Valencia (Spain), and the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic (Great Britain).

To support Hearing the Future, an annual festival of new music. The month-long festival will explore the very beginning of the creative process and how visionaries help shape the future of the arts. Programming will be directed by Festival Curator and composer Matthew Aucoin and will feature the orchestra's Music Director Designate Rafael Payare and soloists including as cellist Alisa Weilerstein and pianist Rodolfo Leone. Repertoire will include musical works by Aucoin, as well as Don Juan by Richard Stauss, a tone poem for orchestra written when the composer was 24-years-old, and Symphonie Fantastique composed by Hector Berlioz. The Jazz at the Jacobs concert will be curated by jazz trumpeter, bandleader, composer, and educator Gilbert Castellanos.

To support a music festival exploring the connection of rhythm and beat in the human experience. The month-long "It's About Time" festival will feature diverse groups of percussionists playing indigenous instruments in both traditional and non-traditional venues. The repertoire will include works by composers including John Luther Adams, Charles Mingus, Roberto Sierra, Igor Stravinsky, and Toru Takemitsu. Programming will be curated by percussionist and University of California-San Diego Professor Stephen Schick and will include lectures, collaborations with local organizations such as La Jolla Symphony and Chorus and the San Diego Opera; and New York-based Paul Taylor Dance Company. In addition, there will be opportunities for the public to participate in performances and make their own percussion instruments.

To support a music festival celebrating the development of the unique American musical voice. Titled Our American Music, the month-long festival will focus on the personal and collective immigrant experience through performances of works by American composers, as well as visiting composers who were inspired by the country's diverse musical heritage and landscapes. The orchestra will perform works by composers such as John Adams, Leonard Bernstein, Aaron Copland, Charles Ives, Igor Stravinsky, Steven Stuckey, and John Williams, as well as music from the Great American Songbook, chamber, jazz, and bluegrass. The festival activities will be held at the Jacobs Music Center's Copley Symphony Hall.

To support a performance and community engagement. Programming will include the world premiere of a new orchestral work featuring text by United States Poet Laureate Juan Felipe Herrera and music by composer Javier Alvarez Fuentes.

Purpose: To support the New Works Program, a commissioning and performance project in collaboration with the San Francisco Conservatory of Music's Emerging Black Composers Project. Additional Project Description: Programming will feature newly commissioned chamber orchestral works by composers Shawn Okpebholo and Trevor Weston. Composer readings, rehearsals, and performances will be held in the greater Bay Area including Berkeley, Palo Alto, and San Francisco. Discussions and workshops will be included as part of the project. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve audiences and musicians of all ages. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support artist fees for a co-commissioning and performance project in collaboration with the San Francisco Conservatory of Music. Additional Project Description: Composer readings, rehearsals, and performances will be held in the greater Bay Area including Berkeley, Palo Alto, and San Francisco. Discussions and workshops will be included as part of the project. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve audiences and musicians of all ages. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support a commissioning and performance project of a new work by composer Michael Gilbertson. The orchestra will partner with Volti and Piedmont Choirs to perform the new song cycle Denial. The work will explore the issues of climate change. Free premiere performances will be presented in San Francisco, Berkeley, and Palo Alto.

To support an educational community engagement project. Very First Concerts will be presented for toddlers and very young audiences and their families. Family Concerts will include the Side-by-Side program in which young pre-professional musicians participate in master classes and perform with the orchestra musicians in concert. Performances under the direction of Music Director Benjamin Simon will be offered free-of-charge at the Crowden Music Center and other venues, such as public libraries, in the San Francisco Bay Area.

To support a performance project celebrating the legacy of American contralto Marian Anderson. The orchestra's annual Martin Luther King Day Concert, which honors the life and legacy of the Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and features the music of African-American artists, will be a salute to Anderson's historic 1939 concert performed on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C. The orchestra will be joined by guest artist soprano Caroline McKenzie and will be directed by Music Director Guido Lamell. The concert program will include works such as Samuel Francis Smith's "America (My Country, 'Tis of Thee)," Gaetano Donizetti's aria "O Mio Fernando," Franz Schubert's "Ave Maria," and the spirituals "Gospel Train," "Trampin'," and "My Soul is Anchored in the Lord."

Purpose: To support New Music Works, a performance project featuring new orchestral and chamber works, as well as a composition workshop for young composers. Additional Project Description: The project will include distinct concert programs featuring varied contemporary repertoire designed to attract a broad audience and foster an appreciation of symphonic music. Programming will include new works by composers such as Angelique Poteat (the orchestra's composer-in-residence). Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve diverse audiences of all ages in the greater Seattle metropolitan area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support a performance project featuring new orchestral and chamber works, as well as a composition workshop for young composers. Additional Project Description: Directed by Music Director Thomas Dausgaard, the project will comprise distinct concert programs featuring varied contemporary repertoire designed to attract a broad audience and foster an appreciation of symphonic music. Programming will feature new works by composers such as Reena Esmail (the orchestra's composer-in-residence), Ellen Reid, and Angelica Negron. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve diverse audiences of all ages in the greater Seattle metropolitan area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support a performance project featuring new orchestral and chamber works. Directed by Music Director Thomas Dausgaard, the project will comprise distinct concert programs featuring varied contemporary repertoire designed to attract a broad audience and foster an appreciation of symphonic music. Programming will feature new works by composers such as Reena Esmail (composer-in-residence), Enrico Chapela, Zhou Long, Erick Muhly, Sven Helbig, Erkki-Sven Tuur, and Hans Abrahamsen. Performances will be presented virtually as necessary.

To support a performance project featuring new orchestral and chamber works, as well as a composition workshop for young composers. Directed by Music Director Thomas Dausgaard, the project will comprise distinct concert programs featuring varied contemporary repertoire designed to attract a broad audience and foster an appreciation of symphonic music. A Young Composers Workshop will be led by composer Charles Corey.

To support a performance project featuring new orchestral and chamber music works, as well as a composition workshop for young composers. Directed by Music Director Ludovic Morlot, the project will comprise distinct concert programs featuring varied contemporary repertoire designed to attract a broad audience and foster an appreciation of symphonic music. The Young Composers Workshop will be led by composer Derek Bermel. Repertoire may include works by composers such as Kinan Azmeh, Luciano Berio, Pierre Boulez, John Harbison, Vijay Iyer, Hannah Kendall, Edward Perez, Caroline Shaw, George Walker, and Chen Yi. Performances and related activities will be held at Benaroya Hall in Seattle.

To support a performance project featuring new orchestral and chamber music works, and a composition workshop for young composers. The project will comprise distinct concert programs, including innovative and varied contemporary repertoire designed to attract Seattle's diverse communities through the creation, performance, and appreciation of symphonic music. Guest artists participating in the project will include composer Alexandra Gardner.

To support a performance project featuring new orchestral works and a composition workshop for young composers. The project will comprise of distinct concert programs, including innovative and varied contemporary repertoire, designed to attract Seattle's diverse communities through the creation, performance, and appreciation of symphonic music. Guest artists participating in the project include composers Judd Greenstein and Aaron Jay Kernis. Performances and related activities will be held at Benaroya Hall in Seattle.

To support a performance project featuring new orchestral works and a composition workshop for young composers. Titled New Music Works, the project will comprise distinct concert programs, including innovative and varied contemporary repertoire, designed to attract Seattle's diverse communities through the creation, performance, and appreciation of symphonic music. Guest artists participating in the project will include composers Huck Hodge, John Adams, William Brittelle, Anna Clyne, and Michael Gordon.

To support a performance project featuring new orchestral works, as well as a composition workshop for young composers. New Music Works will comprise distinct concert programs, including innovative and varied contemporary repertoire, designed to attract Seattle's diverse communities through the creation, performance, and appreciation of symphonic music.

To support the New Music WORKS performance project featuring new orchestral works by Janice Giteck, Richard Karpen, Gabriel Prokofiev, Luis Tinoco, and Du Yun. The programming will feature compositions that bridge traditional and contemporary cultures, a new co-created community composition involving northwest Native-American youth and artists, skill development opportunities for young composers, and educational engagement activities.

To support the American Commissions and Premieres project featuring new works by Elliott Carter and John Luther Adams. The programming will feature the world premieres of the two new American works along with works by Johannes Brahms, Robert Schumann, Gioachino Rossini, and Dmitri Shostakovich.

Purpose: To support a commissioning and performance project featuring a new work by composer Jimmy Lopez-Bellido. Additional Project Description: The project will expand the repertoire for youth orchestras with a new orchestral composition that is flexible to support musicians of different experience levels and ensembles of varying size. Performances will be presented in a concert hall and in a community setting. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve young musicians across the organization's five orchestras (entry level to advanced) and audiences of all ages. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support 75th Anniversary Season performances and the 2019 Marrowstone Music Festival. The anniversary season will include as many as six performances with SYSO alumni and local musicians at Benaroya Hall and the Meany Center for the Performing Arts.

To support SYSO in the Schools. The program provides instrumental music instruction to elementary and middle school students in Seattle area schools, as well as mentoring services for middle and high school band and orchestra directors. Through the Endangered Instrument Program, students will participate in individual and small group lessons on instruments such as oboe, bassoon, viola, double bass, and French horn. Through the Southwest String Project, students will receive free instrumental music coaching from teaching artists. Seattle-area school instrumental music directors will receive professional development from SYSO coaches through the Secondary Orchestra Mentoring Program. All program components will enhance and expand the existing public school instrumental music programs.

To support SYSO in the Schools. Through the Endangered Instrument Program, students will participate in individual and small group lessons on instruments such as oboe, bassoon, viola, double bass, and French horn. Through the Southwest String Project, low-income students will receive free instrumental music coaching. Seattle-area school music directors will receive professional development from SYSO coaches through the Secondary Mentoring Orchestra Program.

To support SYSO in the Schools. Students will receive instrumental music instruction in small group lessons, sectional rehearsals, and have the opportunity to perform side-by-side with a full orchestra.

Purpose: To support Tulare County Symphony's Young People's Concerts. Additional Project Description: The educational performance project will focus on students in grades 3-5 and will incorporate a curriculum-based classroom educational module, an interactive multimedia component, and professional development for teachers. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit artists and general audiences, students, and teachers in the San Joaquin Valley of California. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support an educational performance and rural outreach project. The orchestra will present its annual Youth Education Concert Series for elementary school children. The project will include a classroom education module, an interactive multimedia component, and will culminate in a live orchestral concert in one of several of Tulare County's largest incorporated cities, such as Porterville. The orchestra will create a classroom toolkit and conduct workshops to engage rural school districts throughout the county.

Teachers will provide pre- and post-visit resources to students for corresponding concerts. High school students will be able to participate in an after-school peer mentoring program. In collaboration with Austin College, a music education summer camp will be offered for middle and high school students. Intended Beneficiaries: The programs will serve students in Sherman, Texas and nearby areas of Oklahoma. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts

The concert is designed to feature young African-American or Latino musicians in a public performance. In addition to performing with the South Bend Symphony Orchestra, Powe will visit a local school, perform for the students, and engage in a question-and-answer session. The performance and engagement activities will support the orchestra’s objective to build more diversity in classical music.

column12: To support the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Day celebration concert. The performance will include a full-orchestra concert that will be led by African-American conductors Dr. Marvin Curtis and Chelsea Tipton, and feature soloist Maria Sanderson - a Sphynx Competition-winning violinist - and the Olivet AME Church Choir. The program is designed to feature outstanding young Black or Latino musicians to promote diversity in symphony orchestras. The concert is the finale of the citywide celebration of Martin Luther King, Jr. Day.

column12: To support community outreach and educational activities. Prior to the orchestra's public concerts, musicians will visit senior living facilities and give outreach presentations focusing on the upcoming feature selections. Orchestra members will also perform a concert for youth that illustrates the connections between orchestral music and mathematics.

column7: South Bend Symphony Orchestra Association Inc
column12: To support a Martin Luther King Day celebration concert and associated outreach activities. The concert, highlighting music created by African-American composers, will bring together artists such as narrator David Buggs, the Symphonic and Gospel Choirs of Indiana University South Bend, and the 2013 Junior Laureate of the Sphinx Competition, Lev Mamuya.

Purpose: To support the Music Composition Academies. Additional Project Description: The program will take place in Sisseton and Spearfish, South Dakota. Participants will include Native American and non-Native youth who will work with a team of composition teachers, individually and as a group, to write their own chamber music compositions. The orchestra's string quartet and woodwind quintet will rehearse each new composition with the student composers and perform the works in the students' home communities and across South Dakota. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit youth participating in the program as well as audiences throughout South Dakota. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Purpose: To support the Bridging Cultures Project, a performance and community engagement project. Additional Project Description: The week-long program will feature artists in residence such as virtuoso tabla player Zakir Hussain and composer Malek Jandali. In addition to orchestral performances, activities will include a series of recitals, talks, and question-and-answer sessions at schools and community centers in Sioux Falls. Intended Beneficiaries: The project is expected to engage diverse audiences of all ages in the greater Sioux Falls area. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

To support the Lakota Music Project. The orchestra will continue its focus on developing in-depth relationships through artist residencies in South Dakota locations such as Sisseton Wahpeton Indian Reservation, the City of Sisseton, and Pine Ridge Indian Reservation near Rapid City, South Dakota, and Crazy Horse Memorial. Activities will include chamber music concerts in schools, retirement communities, and community centers delivered by its chamber ensembles, the Dakota String Quartet and the Dakota Wind Quintet, and Native American artists. A new chamber orchestral program based on Lakota and non-Lakota cultural heroes will be presented in a collaboration with Lakota artists and narrated by Chris Eagle Hawk.

To support the Lakota Music Project. The orchestra will focus on creating in-depth relationships through artist residencies in several South Dakota locations such as Sisseton Wahpeton Indian Reservation, the City of Sisseton, and Pine Ridge Indian Reservation near Rapid City, South Dakota. The orchestra's composer-in-residence, Native American composer Jerod Impichchaachaaha' Tate, will lead music academies on the Sisseton Wahpeton Indian Reservation. Programming will include the performance of Tate's Lakota song cycle titled "Waktegli Olowan," which honors five Lakota Warriors-Red Cloud, Gall, Crazy Horse, Sitting Bull, and Two-Strike. Activities will include chamber music concerts in schools, retirement communities, and community centers delivered by its chamber ensembles, such as the Dakota String quartet and the Dakota Wind Quintet, and will be partnered with a Native American artist. Repertoire will include works written by students in the composition academies.

To support Music as Medicine, a partnership with Sanford Health and Avera Health that will offer live music as a form of therapy. Musicians from SDSO will perform as ensembles-in-residence in a variety of healthcare settings, working with cancer patients, older adults, children with behavioral or cognitive development challenges, and their caregivers. In addition to the healing power of the music this program provides, it also serves as a bridge between medical providers in Sioux Falls, illustrating the value of constructive collaboration and serving as a catalyst for other non-traditional partnerships.

To support a performance project exploring music as a means to creating openness and cultural understanding. Under the artistic leadership of Music Director Delta David Gier, the project will focus on the relationship between Syria and Iran through a musical dialogue between Syrian-American composer and pianist Malek Jandali and Persian-American composer Behzad Ranjbaran. Programming will include works by both composers and others, and will feature violist Roberto Diaz. Performances will be accompanied by events such as lectures and post-concert dialogue among the audience, project partners, and the composers.

To support a performance project exploring America's Indianist movement of the early 1900s. The orchestra's Dvorak and America project will be a fusion of the orchestra's existing Lakota Music Project and the Dvorak and America program created by musicologist Joseph Horowitz. Programming will provide a context surrounding Antonin Dvorak's "New World Symphony" through performances of musical works, conducted by Music Director David Gier, including Brent Michael Davids's "Black Hills Olowan," which will be performed with featured guest artists - the Creekside Singers. Concerts and related activities will be presented in Sioux Falls and Sisseton, South Dakota.

To support the Lakota Music Project. An initiative developed between 2005-08 through collaboration between the orchestra and the United Sioux Tribes of South Dakota to build bridges between Native Americans and non-Native Americans, the project will premiere a new work by Native American composer Jerod Impichchaachaaha Tate at a concert held at Crazy Horse Memorial on Native Americans Day.

Purpose: To support artist fees for educational concerts for school children. Additional Project Description: The orchestra program designed for elementary and middle school students will feature multimedia, costumes, props, and narration to explore the plight of Florida's coral reef. Following the concerts, students will have the opportunity to meet the performers and play real instruments from the orchestra. Learning materials will be provided to teachers prior to the concert to help prepare the students. The concerts will take place throughout South Florida. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit elementary and middle school students throughout South Florida. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the Orchestra of St. Luke's visiting composer program featuring Jessie Montgomery. Additional Project Description: The orchestra will collaborate with composer Jessie Montgomery to curate the Sounds  Stories virtual series which is designed to give audiences a unique audio-visual experience. The composer also will curate community concerts combining narrative and music to tell stories and connect audiences to artists. Montgomery also will be involved in curriculum development and at least one masterclass for the Youth Orchestra of St. Luke's. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit audiences throughout the New York City area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the Orchestra of St. Luke's performances of free chamber music concerts throughout New York City. Additional Project Description: Through the Music in Color initiative, ensembles of the orchestra's musicians will perform a repertoire of chamber music by composers Tania León and Amadeo Roldán y Gardes. In addition, through the Youth Orchestra of St. Luke's Embedded Creativity Curriculum, elementary and middle school students will learn music composition, improvisation, and performance. Related outreach activities may include master classes, family workshops, and virtual concert broadcasts. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit diverse New York City audiences of all ages, including students served by the educational programs. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the Orchestra of St. Luke's performances of free chamber music concerts throughout New York City. Through the Music in Color project, ensembles of the orchestra's musicians will perform a repertoire of chamber music by composers from the Gabriela Lena Frank Creative Academy of Music. In addition, through the Youth Orchestra of St. Luke's Embedded Creativity curriculum, 2nd through 8th grade students will learn music composition, improvisation, and performance. Related outreach activities will include post-concert talks, family workshops, and integrated programming with community partners. Project activities may take place virtually as necessary.

To support the Orchestra of St. Luke's performances of free, virtual chamber music concerts. Through the Music in Color project, the orchestra will partner with flutist and composer Valerie Coleman. Ensembles of the orchestra's musicians will perform a repertoire of chamber music by Coleman, as well as composers such as Josephine Baker. Related outreach activities will include post-concert talks.

To support Orchestra of St. Luke's performances of free chamber music. Through the Music in Color project, the orchestra will partner with composer Eleanor Alberga. Ensembles of the orchestra's musicians will be presented in virtual performances featuring repertoire of chamber music by Alberga. Performances will take place as a series of curated online Facebook posts.

To support Orchestra of St. Luke's series of free chamber music The orchestra will present ensembles of its musicians in hour-long performances throughout the city, featuring repertoire of chamber music from the Renaissance period to the present. Performances in all five boroughs of New York City. Activities include added engagement for concertgoers with post-concert talks, family workshops, and integrated programming with community partners.

To support Orchestra of St. Luke's Subway Series of free chamber music. The orchestra will present ensembles of its musicians in hour-long performances throughout the city, featuring repertoire of chamber music from the Renaissance period to the present. Performances will take place in nontraditional and emerging art spaces, including locations in mass transit hubs, in all five boroughs of New York City.

To support Orchestra of St. Luke's Subway Series of free, family-friendly chamber music performances. The orchestra will present ensembles of its musicians in hour-long performances throughout New York City, featuring repertoire of chamber music from the Renaissance period to the present. Performances, accompanied by a narrator, will take place in historically underserved communities in an informal and accessible format thoroughout all five boroughs of New York City.

To support the development and promotion of a web portal. OSLmedia will provide users with access to the Orchestra of St. Luke's complete discography, instructional videos and games, artist interviews, podcasts, livestream events, and other interactive features.

To support Orchestra of St. Luke's OSL Subway Series of free chamber music. The orchestra will present ensembles of its musicians in hour-long performances throughout the city, featuring repertoire of chamber music from the Renaissance period to the present. Performances will take place at outdoor venues in all five boroughs of New York City.

To support Orchestra of St. Luke's Subway Series of free chamber music concerts. The orchestra will present ensembles of its musicians in hour-long performances throughout the city, featuring repertoire of traditional and contemporary music by composers from the Renaissance period to living composers.

To support the Orchestra of St. Luke's "Subway Series" of free chamber music concerts. The orchestra will present ensembles of its musicians in hour-long performances throughout the city, featuring repertoire of traditional and contemporary music by composers from the Renaissance period to living composers.

To support the production and national distribution of three live broadcasts. Presented from the Orchestra of St. Luke's DiMenna Center for Classical Music in New York City, these performances will be broadcast by WQXR and offered for national syndication through affiliated stations.

Purpose: To support an artist residency by the Dali Quartet. Additional Project Description: Plans include public performances and an education residency for area school students. The ensemble, known for their Latin American repertoire, will appear as guest soloists with Orchestra Lumos, formerly known as the Stamford Symphony Orchestra. The residency is part of an initiative to engage new and more diverse audiences in Stamford. Educational activities will include school visits, after school programs in community centers, and free student tickets to orchestra performances. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit audiences and youth throughout Stamford, Connecticut. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support free community concerts. Additional Project Description: The orchestra, which is dedicated to blending the classical and jazz music genres, will be joined by guest composer and conductor Christopher Zuar for one performance. A second program will feature newly commissioned works by composer and saxophonist Remy Le Boeuf. The free public concerts will take place at the University of California Long Beach's Carpenter Performing Arts Center. Education outreach activities will take place at elementary schools in Long Beach and South Central Los Angeles. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit audiences comprising low-income, underserved communities of Long Beach and South Los Angeles, California, including local elementary school students and seniors from nearby care centers. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support free community concerts. Additional Project Description: One program will feature newly commissioned works by composer and keyboardist Remy Le Boeuf. The second performance will be themed as a "family jazz hour" and feature Chris Woods (violin), Ann Patterson (saxophone), Christian Jacob (piano), Nedra Wheeler (bass), Clayton Cameron (drums), Francisco Torres (trombone), and Emile Martinez (trumpet). The free public concerts will take place at the University of California Long Beach's Carpenter Performing Arts Center and at the Robert Frost Auditorium in Culver City, CA. Educational outreach activities will take place at elementary schools in Long Beach and South-Central Los Angeles. Intended Beneficiaries: The programming will benefit audiences comprising low-income, underserved communities of Long Beach and South Los Angeles, California, including local elementary school students and seniors from nearby care centers. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support free community concerts. The free public concerts will take place virtually and will include educational outreach materials to be distributed to elementary schools in Long Beach, California. Recorded versions of the concerts will also be made available to elementary schools.

To support free community concerts. The Orchestra will perform up to two free public concerts with a guest artist at the University of California Long Beach's Carpenter Performing Arts Center. Ancillary educational activities at an elementary school in Long Beach as well as several elementary schools in South Central Los Angeles may include onsite performances and workshops focused on the histories of classical music and jazz.

To support free community concerts. The 67-member Orchestra will perform at the University of California Long Beach's Carpenter Performing Arts Center. The performances will include guest artist Miguel Zenon performing works commissioned by the Orchestra.

To support a free concert that will blend jazz and classical music, as well as related outreach activities. Economically disadvantaged residents will have the opportunity to attend a concert featuring jazz saxophonist Ernie Watts. Outreach activities will serve individuals affiliated with the local VA hospital, and the Osher Lifelong Learning Institute, an organization that engages the local senior community.

To support a free jazz concert, as well as related workshops about improvisation and the history of jazz. Economically disadvantaged residents will have the opportunity to attend a concert featuring jazz guitarist and composer Lee Ritenour. Outreach activities will serve low-income youth attending Title I schools located in Long Beach and South-Central Los Angeles.

To support a free jazz concert for economically disadvantaged students featuring multi-instrumentalist and composer Miguel Atwood-Ferguson, with related outreach. 1/8/14--per FDR, change in venue and partner.

Purpose: To support a concert commemorating "Watch Night" on the eve of Florida's official Emancipation Day. Additional Project Description: The historic event refers to the gathering of Black Americans in churches on New Year's Eve to await news that President Lincoln had signed the Emancipation Proclamation. The concert may include works by William Grant Still, Will Marion Cook, "Lincoln Portrait" by Aaron Copland, and traditional spirituals. The concert will take place at the amphitheater in Cascades Park. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit audiences throughout Tallahassee, Florida. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support a commissioning and performance project featuring a new work by composer Joel Thompson. The composition for orchestra, chorus, and vocalists will commemorate the City of Tallahassee's historic 1956 bus boycott during the Civil Rights Era. Organizational partners will include the John G. Riley Center for African American History  Culture and the Concert Choir of Florida AM University, a historically Black university. In addition to the premiere performance, local youth will be offered free access to the dress rehearsal and/or a streamed version of the concert.

To support a concert performance by the Tallahassee Symphony Jazz Orchestra. The orchestra's 50-piece big band and strings ensemble TSO Jazz aims at re-creating the sounds of the Glen Miller and Tommy Dorsey orchestras by performing a program featuring both traditional and modern big band standards.
To support a free concert by the musical trio Time for Three, as well as residency activities for the Gadsden County School District.

To support a performance project featuring the premiere of a newly commissioned work by American composer Ellen Taaffe Zwilich. Under the leadership of Music Director Alexander Jimenez, the orchestra will perform a new ballet work with the Tallahassee Ballet Youth Company and its Artistic Director Tyrone Brooks. A native of Florida, Zwilich--a Pulitzer Prize-winner--will be in residence with the young musicians and will participate in rehearsals while they prepare to perform the work in public. The concert performance will be presented at Florida State University's Ruby Diamond Concert Hall.

To support a performance project of baroque music featuring works by composer Georg Reutter the Younger (1708-72). Programming will include orchestral performances of his work, as well as performances, a video recording, and touring of an orchestral program with arias and instrumental music, including modern premiere performances.

To support an early music performance project. The project will feature music inspired by great works of literature, including William Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream, Miguel de Cervantes' Don Quixote, the Roman poet Ovid's Metamorphoses, and Moliere's The Hypochondriac. The baroque orchestra of strings, winds, continuo, and percussion will perform repertoire including The Fairy Queen by Henry Purcell, Georg Philipp Telemann's Don Quixote Suite, the ballet Pygmalion by Jean-Philippe Rameau, and Marc-Antoine Charpentier's The Hypochondriac. The performances will take place at the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts in Philadelphia.

To support a performance project, Telemann 360. To support concerts and a public talk show that "reclaims" composer Georg Philipp Telemann's fame for today's US audiences on the occasion of the 250th anniversary of his death. Major project components are two all-Telemann concert programs that include modern-premiere performances of rediscoveries and a live, public talkshow with Telemann's music performanced by Philadelphia Baroque Orchestra Tempesta di Mare, and hosted by Live from Lincoln Center's Fred Child. An interacted, web-based discovery tool centered on Telemann, embedded in a search-engine-optimized and mobile responsive new website design, augments the project and its audience reach.

To support a performance project of French baroque orchestral music. Titled Comedie et Tragedie (Comedy and Tragedy), the project will be a finale of a two-year curatorial focus on rarely-performed French baroque orchestral music for the theater. Directed by Co-Artistic Directors Gwyn Roberts and Richard Stone, programming will include works such as Jean-Phillippe Rameau's opera-ballet "Les Fetes de Polymnie (The Festivals of Polyhymnia)" (1745) and Jean-Marie Leclair's opera "Scylla et Glaucus (Scylla and Glaucus)" (1746). In addition, performances will be augmented by educational outreach activities such as a play-in for local youth orchestra instrumentalists and workshops in baroque style and techniques of wind and string articulation.

To support a performance and community engagement project. The Temple Symphony String Quartet will perform and present educational programs in several local public school districts, as well as area retirement and assisted living facilities. Thematic concert programs will be designed to demonstrate the relationship between music and other art forms, such as dance, visual arts, and folk traditions.

The Murfreesboro Symphony Orchestra will present a series of free outreach performances, such as a Fourth of July concert, a concert celebrating Latin culture, and a family-oriented performance. Free tickets will be provided to veterans for a concert celebrating Veterans Day. Also, professional musicians will perform in local schools and conduct educational programs. The orchestra will work closely with school band directors and administrators when developing programs, which will be provided at no cost to the schools or students.

The Murfreesboro Symphony Orchestra will present a series of outreach performances, such as a free Fourth of July concert, a celebration of Latin music, and a Veterans Day concert. The orchestra also will send professional musicians into schools to perform and provide educational programming.

To support a series of symphonic music concerts and associated educational activities. Performances will feature guest pianist Scott Holden. The symphony will tour free concerts to geographically remote regions in Utah such as Price, Richfield, and Delta. The symphony will also work with school districts in each location to reach students and their families, providing educational programs in the schools.

To support a series of free, classical music concerts and associated outreach activities. The project will provide transportation to the concerts for high school students in Utah. Soprano Melissa Heath will perform and the Timpanogos Symphony will present accessible, family-friendly classical repertoire, such as John Williams' "Star Wars (Suite for Orchestra)."

Purpose: To support "Here I Am," the creation of a world premiere recording. Additional Project Description: The chorus will record "Here I Am" and "Notebooks of Leonardo da Vinci," two large-scale works by Jocelyn Hagen, each commissioned or co-commissioned by True Concord. The composer, who is known for addressing timely and important themes in her music, intends for the music to serve as a reminder that women continue to fight for equality both at home and abroad. The album, to be released at a later date, will be distributed nationwide and via YouTube to make the music widely available at no-cost. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve audiences nationwide and around the world. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support performances by True Concord's chamber orchestra and choir in concert programs featuring works by American composers. Programming will include a new work by composer Gerald Near for choir, orchestra, and soprano based on poems and letters of American poet Emily Dickinson. Another concert program will honor U.S. service personnel and veterans with performances of works such as Aaron Copland's "Fanfare for the Common Man," Samuel Barber's "Adagio for Strings" and Jake Runestad's "Dreams of the Fallen." The concerts will be presented in several locations in Tucson.

To support a performance project in New York City. The ensemble will perform works by American composer Stephen Paulus in Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center, coinciding with the release of its CD recording of previously unrecorded works by the late composer. Repertoire will include Paulus's oratorio "Prayers and Remembrances," which was commissioned for the ensemble for the tenth anniversary of the attacks on September 11, 2001, and premiered in Tucson, as well as other works from the forthcoming album. In addition, the ensemble will present open rehearsals and educational outreach activities in local New York schools.

Purpose: To support instructor and musician fees related to the Young Composers Project, a music composition program. Additional Project Description: Students will receive instruction in music theory, ear training, score reading, and music composition. Students will compose original works for full orchestras and small ensembles, working side-by-side with professional composers and performers. The program will culminate in public reading sessions of the students' original works performed by a professional ensemble, and the student compositions will be professionally recorded. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will benefit elementary, middle, and high school students in the Tucson area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

To support the Young Composers Project, a music composition program. Students will receive instruction in music theory, ear training, and score reading, as well as music composition. Students will compose original works for full orchestra and small ensembles, working side-by-side with professional composers and performers. The program will culminate in public reading sessions of the students' original works performed by the Tucson Symphony Orchestra and the student compositions will be professionally recorded.

To support the Young Composers Project, a music composition program. Elementary through high school students will learn music theory, ear training, score reading, and will compose original works for orchestra by collaborating with professional composers and musicians. Students will observe a conductor and orchestra at work, learn how orchestral pieces come together in live performance, and interact with professional musicians and ensembles to receive feedback about their own compositions. The program will culminate in public reading sessions of the students' original works performed by the Tucson Symphony Orchestra (TSO) and the TSO String Quartet.

To support the Young Composers Project (YCP). Elementary through high school students learn to compose original works for orchestra by working with professional composers and musicians. Students regularly interact with the professional musicians and ensembles, writing sketches for these professionals and receiving critique and input. The young composers learn basic theory, ear training, score reading, and use Finale software in the YCP lab. The program culminates in public reading sessions of the students' original works performed by the Tucson Symphony Orchestra (TSO) and the TSO String Quartet.

To support the Young Composers Project (YCP). Elementary through high school students will learn to compose original works for orchestra, culminating in public reading sessions of their work by the Tucson Symphony Orchestra (TSO) and TSO String Quartet. Sessions will include basic theory, ear training, and score reading as students learn about clefs, keys, modes, notation, chords, rhythm, form, ranges, and transposition. Each session also will include a listening component with score study focused on orchestral repertoire. Students will attend monthly rehearsals and meet guest artists and composers whose work is being performed by the TSO. Students will observe the conductor and the orchestra at work and learn how orchestral pieces come together in live performance. At the end of the project, professional ensembles will provide public readings of the student work, providing real-time interactions between students, the orchestra, and the conductor.

To support the Young Composers Project (YCP). Elementary through high school students will learn to compose original works for orchestra, culminating in public reading sessions of their work by the Tucson Symphony Orchestra (TSO) and TSO String Quartet. Saturday sessions will begin with basic theory, ear training, and score reading as students learn about clefs, keys, modes, notation, chords, rhythm, form, ranges, and transposition. Each session will include a listening component with score study focused on orchestral repertoire. Students will learn to use Finale music notation software in the YCP lab to create their own works. At the end of the project, professional ensembles provide public readings of the student work, providing real-time interactions between students, the orchestra, and the conductor.

To support the Young Composers Project. Students will learn to compose original works for orchestra, culminating in public reading sessions of their work by the Tucson Symphony Orchestra (TSO) and TSO String Quartet. Saturday sessions will begin with basic theory, ear training, and score reading as students learn about clefs, keys, modes, notation, chords, rhythm, form, ranges, and transposition. Each session will include a listening component with score study focused on orchestral repertoire. Students will learn to use Finale music notation software in the YCP lab to create their own works. At the end of the project, professional ensembles provide public readings of the student work, providing real time interactions between students, the orchestra, and the conductor.

To support the Young Composers Project. Students will learn to compose original works for orchestra and their training will culminate in a reading and recording of their pieces by the Tucson Symphony Chamber Orchestra or the Tucson String Quintet.

To support a collaborative performance project commemorating the legacy of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre. In partnership with the Tulsa Race Massacre Centennial Commission, the orchestra and festival chorus will perform with guest artist Wynton Marsalis and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, featuring Marsalis' blues suite All Rise. The concert will culminate a weeklong series of commemorative activities.

To support a concert and related community engagement activities featuring the music of composer Eric Whitacre. Whitacre will conduct the Tulsa Symphony and Tulsa Oratorio Chorus in a concert of his own music. Other activities may include a pre-concert conversation with Whitacre, an open rehearsal for local music students, a master class with high school students, and an onstage interview.

To support a commissioning and performance project. Under the direction of Artistic Director Daniel Hege, the orchestra will perform a new work by Chickasaw Nation composer Jerod Impichchaachaaha' Tate. The work, titled "Muskogee Song Cycle," will be written for children's choir and orchestra. Performances will feature a children's choir from the Muscogee (Creek) Nation, singing hymns in the original Creek language. The premiere performance will take place at the 2017 OK Mozart International Festival in Bartlesville, Oklahoma. Community engagement activities may include workshops with the Emmy Award-winning composer in area schools and tribal locations, an interview with the composer in pre-concert conversations, programs on Native American music and culture as part of the Festival's showcase events, as well as radio broadcasts of the performance.

To support the presentation of This Land is Your Land: A Celebration of Woody Guthrie. The Tulsa Symphony will partner with the Woody Guthrie Center and the Guthrie Green to present the free public concert with composer David Amram as the conductor. The project will provide transportation for local elementary students and their families to the concert.

To support concerts featuring the pianist duo Christina Naughton and Michelle Naughton. In addition to a public performance, the pianists will perform in the TSO Young Person's Concert, targeted to benefit economically disadvantaged students attending a Title I elementary school located in Tulsa.

To support Mark O'Connor and Friends, a concert and related student workshops featuring fiddler/violinist/composer Mark O'Connor with violinist Kelly Hall-Tompkins. Complimentary tickets and to the concert will be provided to economically disadvantaged students.

To support a festival for high school and community orchestras that includes music clinics, rehearsals, and public performances. Guest artists will teach and demonstrate the art of preparing, staging, and performing a surround sound concert to Utah orchestras and directors. The artists will also perform and share their original music. Participating orchestras will prepare and perform both individually and as a larger group, in order to learn about the style of a surround sound concert.

To support the Four String Festival, and associated outreach activities. Guest artists, the Fry Street Quartet, will conduct sectionals, group ensemble, master classes, and a side-by-side concert with festival participants, as well as perform with the Utah Philharmonic Orchestra. Outreach activities for underserved youth from small, low-income Utah communities will include a string clinic for school-age students.

Purpose: To support the annual Summer Festival Tour. Additional Project Description: The Vermont Symphony will tour the state with concerts featuring trumpeter Ray Vega, in a program inspired by the Great American Songbook, music of NEA Jazz Masters, and more. The project will support the orchestra's strategic objectives to provide meaningful and high-caliber musical experiences statewide. The tour also will include related educational and community programs, such as an event for young brass players to meet with guest artist Vega, as well as attend a concert for free; a musical petting zoo; and Band Connect, which will allow volunteer town bands and school brass bands the opportunity to perform at each tour venue. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit the participating musicians and artists, technical crew, volunteers, and staff, as well as audiences of all ages in rural Vermont communities. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support a performance project featuring newly commissioned works by composers Daniel Bernard Roumain and Matthew Evan Taylor and associated educational programs. Additional Project Description: The orchestral and choral concerts, as well as educational programs, will be presented online and in-person, in and around Burlington, Vermont, in collaboration with the orchestra's chorus and local gospel choirs. Both composers will participate in panel discussions about their work. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve audiences of all ages at the Flynn Center and nationwide through virtual presentations. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.
To support general operating costs due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support the 22nd annual Made In Vermont Music Festival Tour, a performance touring project in underserved rural communities. The orchestra will present concert programs and educational outreach activities and will include the commissioning and premiere performances of a new work by native Vermont composer Paul Dedell. The composer will join Music Director Jaime Laredo and orchestra musicians in engaging high school and college students and members of each community in engagement activities, such as the Green Room Program, workshops, and public lectures.

To support a performance touring project in underserved rural communities. The composer will join Music Director Jaime Laredo and orchestra musicians in engaging high school and college students and members of each community in outreach activities, such as the Green Room Program, workshops, and public lectures.

To support the Made in Vermont Music Festival tour. To support an after-school music partnership program serving underserved communities. In collaboration with the John F. Kennedy Elementary School in Winooski, Vermont, the orchestra will provide an instrumental music instruction program for students from economically disadvantaged areas. Project activities will include two levels of string training and a percussion class, with free instrument rental, and a number of free performances for the students and their families. There also will be a participatory school-day performance at the Elley-Long Music Center, home to the Vermont Youth Orchestra Association.

Purpose: To support a performance and community engagement project. Additional Project Description: In collaboration with the orchestra's Harmony Project partners and inspired by Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.'s concept of Beloved Community, programming will feature works by composers William Grant Still, Samuel Coleridge, Adolphus Hailstork, Antonin Dvorak, Duke Ellington, Florence Price, Chen Yi, and Jessie Montgomery. Performances and discussions will be presented at Norfolk State University, a historically Black university, historically black churches, and community centers, including the Philippine Cultural Center. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will engage diverse audiences of all ages in the Hampton Roads area of Virginia. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the Virginia Symphony Orchestra's community engagement project. CommUNITY Play-In and Sing-Along, the annual free, public event will offer active music-making for more than 1,000 Hampton Roads citizens at Scope Arena in downtown Norfolk. Activities will include orchestral "play-ins" by community musicians and sing-alongs, as well as the participation of local performing arts groups and U.S. military ensembles.

To support a community performance and engagement project by the Virginia Symphony Orchestra. Titled Generations in Unison, the interactive music therapy-inspired program will serve adults living with Alzheimer's and dementia through music. Along with a board-certified music therapist overseeing the program, orchestra musicians will visit assisted living facilities, perform therapeutic and energizing music while residents participate in interactive activities which stimulate memory, strengthen fine motor skills, and benefit overall health. Volunteer students from partner schools will assist the musicians during the visits. The project will include as many as four partner locations in the Hampton Roads community.

To support a commissioning and performance project by the Virginia Symphony Orchestra. The orchestra will premiere a new work by American composer Michael Daugherty-concerto for orchestra, "Night Owl." The Grammy Award-winning composer will draw inspiration from the 1950s black-and-white photographs of railways, trains and industry by American photographer O. Winston Link (1914-2001). A commercial photographer, Link helped establish rail photography as a hobby and pioneered night photography. In addition to orchestral performances, programming will include forums hosted by representatives from the Virginia Museum of Transportation and the O. Winston Link Museum, both located in Roanoke, Virginia.

To support the Harmony Project, a community partnership project with historically African-American churches in Hampton Roads, Virginia. Under the direction of Music Director JoAnn Falletta, activities will include ensemble and full orchestra performances, workshops,and a Martin Luther King, Jr., tribute concert.

To support a statewide performance and outreach touring project. Programming will include works by Ludwig von Beethoven, Johannes Brahms, Adolphus Hailstork, and Antonin Dvorak.

To support the annual YOSA Invitational music festival featuring youth bands and orchestras. The multi-day event will engage as many as 1,000 students from local public high schools and middle schools in free performances at the Tobin Center for the Performing Arts, located next to the San Antonio River Walk. The student ensembles will be selected from an online application process from schools within a 75-mile radius of the Tobin Center. In addition, the ensembles will receive professionally recorded audio of their live performances.

To support Mozart at the Opera. Soprano Shana Blake Hill and baritone Zachary Gordin will visit local high school choirs to work with student singers and invite them to the culminating concert, with a focus on underserved, economically disadvantaged schools in the San Antonio area. The concert will feature the guest soloists with the Youth Orchestra of San Antonio. Selections from "The Magic Flute," "The Marriage of Figaro," "Don Giovanni," and Cesar Franck's "Symphony in D minor" will be performed.

To support the production of Carl Orff's "Carmina Burana" and associated outreach activities. Soloists Ava Pine, Ryland Angel, and Jose Adan Perez will rehearse and perform with the YOSA Philharmonic, the San Antonio Choral Society, and the Children's Chorus of San Antonio. The soloists will conduct workshops, and free tickets will be provided wto the concert, for choral students at local underserved and low-income schools.

To support the commission and premiere of a new concerto for electric violin composed by Kenji Bunch and performed by electric violinist Tracy Silverman, with associated outreach activities. Silverman and Bunch will lead free workshops for economically disadvantaged youth at elementary, middle, and high schools located in San Antonio and work with as many as 40 youth string players who participate in the Orchestra's free, daily after-school music program; students and their families will receive complementary tickets to the concert.
